title: Brazils Ousted President
description: Brazil has had four elected presidents since democracy was restored in 1985. Two served out their terms. On Wednesday, Dilma Rousseff was the second to be ousted while in office amid political upheaval and allegations of wrongdoing.

title: Supreme Court Blocks North Carolina From Restoring Strict Voting Law

title: Spokesmans Death Will Have Islamic State Turning to Its Deep Bench
description: WASHINGTON  The reported death of the Islamic States senior propagandist and strategist, Abu Muhammad al-Adnani, in an American drone strike in northern Syria on Tuesday casts in sharp relief the immediate challenge the terrorist group faces in replacing one of its pivotal founding members.

description: HONOLULU  President Obama set off on a trans-Pacific voyage on Wednesday, his 10th trip to Asia as president and most likely his last chance to showcase two of his most cherished projects: the focus on Asia and the campaign to curb climate change.

title: Caroline Wozniacki Rallies From Early Deficit to Win
description: From the players box at Arthur Ashe Stadium, Piotr Wozniacki was desperately trying to calm his daughter down below. His signals were nothing fancy or too intricate. Just palms down: Take it easy. Hands pushing forward: Move up toward the baseline during rallies.

description: A year after two men, one a former aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, were killed in Brooklyn in separate episodes amid the predawn celebration known as Jouvert, Mayor Bill de Blasio and the police are promising that the annual event will be safer this time.

description: Dr. Joy Browne, the syndicated radio and television psychologist who dispensed advice and earnest inspiration over the air for nearly four decades, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 71 and still hosting her daily three-hour radio program.

title: Having a Variable Identity
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Its very hard to be an objective judge of a puzzle when the theme affects you personally, so Ill just admit that Ben Tausigs puzzle struck me right in the heart. And its not just because it manages to pull off a really neat constructing trick called a Schrdinger theme (described below), but also because I have a young adult child who happens to be GENDER FLUID. And this concept of gender existing on a continuum instead of a binary (male or female only) is the theme of our crossword puzzle today.

title: French Group Suspends Three Players for Unprofessional Behavior

title: Mr. Robot Season 2, Episode 9: A Bad Dream
description: Sure, the Full House meets ALF mash-up sequence from two episodes ago got the most ink. (Understandably!) But when it comes to painstaking recreations of outmoded aesthetics, the shows slasher parody The Careful Massacre of the Bourgeoisie is clearly the retro Rosetta stone for Mr. Robot. While no one was murdered onscreen, this weeks episode carried over its predecessors horror-movie vibe, and then some. Flickering lights, dark hallways, doppelgngers, menacing knocks at the door, a generalized sense of impending doom: eps2.7_init_5.fve was about as creepy as you can get without a serial killer or supernatural entity stalking the cast.

Having fired his campaign chairman and retooled his message, Mr. Trump was still far behind Hillary Clinton in the polls, and Republicans were running away from him.

But with less than 10 weeks to go before Election Day, a blustering Trump told an expectant audience in Arizona that he wasnt reneging on his signature promise. After failing to address the issue with Pea Nieto in a serious way  bringing back nothing concrete and providing no further details  he blithely told a rally in Phoenix:

The heat wave and the crowds are just old news, the Drifters sang in 1964, a year after the club opened, in their ode to another summer gone by, but Ive still got some sand in my shoes.

title: Explaining What Donald Trump Wants to Do Now on Immigration

Trump laid out a 10-point immigration plan on Wednesday in Phoenix that reverted to the tough, uncompromising talk on the issue that has powered his appeal to his strongest supporters. While he is no longer talking about immediately deporting the estimated 11 million people in the United States illegally, he also distanced himself from any notion that they could gain legal status anytime soon.

title: Traveling Alone, With Help
description: I was driving through the Nevada desert on a hot morning in late July, going from Las Vegas to Los Angeles in a brand-new silver Nissan Versa. This was my first time driving in the United States and my first time driving an automatic car. I had asked for a manual transmission, but the rental agency didnt have one. In my country, Argentina, everyone drives a manual.

title: How to Tickle Someone
description: Stop, start again, be surprising, says Marina Davila-Ross, a professor at Britains University of Portsmouth who studies laughter and play. Unpredictability is the key element of tickling, which is why you cannot tickle yourself. Brains are prediction machines; if your own hand reaches in for a tickle, your brain will foresee and cancel out the results. (Research shows that some schizophrenics are able to tickle themselves because they dont make the same distinctions between self and other.) Davila-Ross has tickled humans, chimpanzees, bonobos, orangutans and gorillas, and she says sometimes just the pretouch anticipation evokes laughter. Only the great apes regularly tickle one another, although many animals, including rats, cats and dogs, enjoy it. (In one study, rats kept in social isolation and exposed to regular electrical shocks exhibited less fear and lower catecholamine stress hormones when tickled daily by a researcher.)

title: A Midtown Apartment, the Opposite of Nice and Quiet

title: The Crispy Decadence of the Patty Melt
description: As great dinner sandwiches go, it is hard to beat the patty melt: ground beef, Swiss cheese and caramelized onions griddled on rye bread until they become a crisp, oozing package of salty-sweet delight. They are one of the truly great underappreciated sandwich creations of all time, said Ed Levine, founder of the Serious Eats website, where he maintains a list of his five favorite versions from across the country. No one thinks about them, he said. They havent gotten their due!

description: With cancer, there are generally two scenarios  you either have it or you dont. But I am somewhere in the middle, stuck inside a vortex. title: Why Is Turkey Accusing Me of Plotting a Coup?
description: WASHINGTON  On the night of July 15, elements of the Turkish military attempted a coup. It was a poorly organized effort that was defeated by a combination of people power, loyal units and serendipity. What made this failed effort remarkable was the putschists extreme brutality against civilians who resisted or happened to be in their way. Some 240 people were killed.

title: Does Germany Understand Its Own Strength?

Because she didnt want to become responsible for violence and possibly death at her countrys border, she ordered the German government  and by extension, German society  to take in thousands of refugees who had been sent westward by Hungarys prime minister, Viktor Orban.

title: Bags of Cocaine Worth $56 Million Are Found at Coca-Cola Factory in France

title: Chinas Core Socialist Values, the Song-and-Dance Version

title: 1941: Japan Seeks Peace With U.S.
description: TOKIO  As the European war enters its third year, Japan has abandoned hope of an early termination of the conflict. A feeling of having been let down by German promises of a quick conclusion was noticeable here today. The Japanese have become aware of the necessity of adopting realistic diplomacy instead of idealistic. The announcement that Japan is negotiating with the United States for a settlement of Far Eastern issues has created a problem for the government from the point of view of public peace and order.  New York Herald Tribune, Sept. 2, 1941

title: 1966: Desegregation in Trouble
description: MONTGOMERY  As public schools prepare to reopen, it is increasingly clear that the U.S. Office of Education has serious enforcement problems with desegregation guidelines throughout the Deep South. Resistance to the guidelines has been so strong in hard-core segregationist areas that in a great majority of cases the Education Office has accepted token compliance rather than invoke Title 6 of the 1964 Civil Rights Act and withdraw federal assistance. As a result, more than 96 percent of some 1,500,000 Negro pupils in Alabama, Georgia, Mississippi, Louisiana and South Carolina will be attending all-Negro schools as they return to classes.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 2, 1966

title: Violence After Gabon Elections Leaves One Dead
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Postelection violence in Gabon left one person dead on Thursday after officials declared the incumbent president, Ali Bongo Ondimba, the winner in a race that the opposition said had been marked by fraud.

title: A Call From Outer Space, or a Cosmic Wrong Number?
description: Its probably just a piece of cosmic spam, the astrophysical equivalent of butt dialing. But nobody really knows for sure.

title: Georgetown University Working Group on Slavery Memory and Reconciliation Report
description: A report released Thursday by a committee convened last year to consider ways the university should address its history with slavery.

title: A Strategy Backfires, Increasing Teen Births
description: For more than two decades, educators with high hopes of preventing teen pregnancy have assigned their students computerized baby dolls, programmed to cry, coo, and make life complicated, just like a real baby.

title: African Elephant Population Dropped 30 Percent in 7 Years
description: The African elephant population is in drastic decline, having shrunk about 30 percent from 2007 to 2014, according to a survey published this week.

title: Depression Is Poorly Diagnosed and Often Goes Untreated
description: Using data from a survey that screened more than 46,000 Americans for depression, researchers found evidence that the condition is not properly diagnosed in many people. And even when diagnosed correctly, depression often goes untreated.

title: Transcript of Donald Trumps Immigration Speech
description: Following is a transcript of the remarks by Donald J. Trump on immigration in Phoenix on Wednesday, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

title: Tunneling Under the Border With Mexico
description: On the U.S.-Mexico border, a large fence has done little to deter enterprising drug smugglers. In Nogales, Ariz., theyve been digging out tunnels for years in order to cross the border undetected.

title: Do Those Travel Search Results Look Fishy? Heres Why
description: Famished after a two-leg cross-country flight rife with delays and scarce on nutrition, I tapped open Google Maps on my phone and scanned the area around my LAX airport hotel for someplace interesting to eat.

title: Tsion Cafe
description: Ethiopian with a nod to the Jewish diaspora at a former after-hours jazz haunt in Harlem.

title: At Tsion Cafe in Harlem, Food From Ethiopia via Israel
description: On one side lie eggs scrambled with lox over a drape of injera, the sour, springy Ethiopian flatbread as thin and pliant as a crepe and perforated like coral. On the other side, challah French toast, its egg coating spiked with awaze, a meld of earthy-hot berbere and tej, or Ethiopian honey wine, a drink of millenniums past.

title: Daily Report: When Things Go Very Wrong at a Start-Up
description: For many young engineers and business people, Silicon Valley is their version of Hollywood. If you want to make it big, go there, create your own company or sign on with a start-up on the way up, and get ready to make a fortune. Maybe you will even become famous.

title: Contraceptives Drive Teenage Pregnancy Down
description: The sharp decline in American teenage pregnancy and birthrates in recent years was driven exclusively by the increased use of contraceptives, a new study concludes.

title: Inside UrbanGlass
description: A workspace in Brooklyn provides ample room for glass blowers to create their works.

title: Turn Your Phone Into an Early Warning System
description: Q. What is the best way to get emergency weather alerts and information as quickly as possible on my phone?

title: Popcast: Stardom in the Age of Social Media
description: With celebrities so accessible online they have to go above and beyond when meeting fans in the arena.

title: She Made Me Bleed a Little: Alicia Vikander and Michael Fassbender
description: Its impossible to watch The Light Between Oceans  Derek Cianfrances tale of a childless Australian couple who discover a baby in a rowboat and keep it  and not assume that youre witnessing its stars, Alicia Vikander and Michael Fassbender, falling in love.

title: Popcast: The Pop Star Struggle in the Age of Social Media
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

title: Mother Teresa: The Life of a Saint
description: Before Mother Teresa became a saint, she was a nun, a nurse and a recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Anatomy | The Light Between Oceans
description: Derek Cianfrance narrates a scene from The Light Between Oceans featuring Michael Fassbender and Alicia Vikander.

title: Derek Cianfrance Narrates a Scene From The Light Between Oceans
description: In The Light Between Oceans, a married couple, Tom and Isabel (Michael Fassbender and Alicia Vikander) live on a remote island off the coast of Australia. They long to be parents but Isabel has suffered two miscarriages. In this scene, the two find a boat that washes ashore and are surprised to see whats inside.

title: Review: A Baby in a Boat Changes Everything in The Light Between Oceans
description: In The Light Between Oceans, Michael Fassbender exudes the war-weary stoicism of a man who has grown numb from witnessing too much senseless carnage. Tom Sherbourne, his character in this sweeping period romance adapted from M. L. Stedmans 2012 novel, is an embittered World War I veteran who takes a job as a lighthouse keeper on Janus Rock, a remote, uninhabited island on the edge of Western Australia. His hope is to get as far as possible from civilization and its savagery.

title: Venezuelans Push to Recall President
description: Protesters marched through Caracas, Venezuela, on Thursday, demanding a recall referendum this year against President Nicols Maduro.

title: A Report to Congress on Drug-Smuggling Tunnels
description: The Department of Homeland Security issued an annual report earlier this year on efforts to find and close cross-border tunnels.

title: As Donald Trump Calls for Wall on Mexican Border, Smugglers Dig Tunnels
description: NOGALES, Ariz.  On an embankment that runs along a towering steel fence separating this border town from its Mexican sister city, a patch of new concrete with a date carved into it stands out, marking the exit of a tunnel Border Patrol agents sealed in May.

title: Getting Burned by a Hot Story
description: Everything is running right about on cue. A sex scandal broke out on Sunday, with a Clinton campaign aide, Huma Abedin, facing more public embarrassment after a confessional call from her sexting husband. By Monday she was announcing plans to separate from him. And by the next morning the spotlight had turned to where it usually does in such matters: the media. The crime was producing coverage considered tawdry, overblown and blameful of the victim. I was out of town, but I came back to an inbox full of emails to the public editor taking aim at The New York Times.

title: Passionate Reactions to Impeachment
description: Both supporters and opponents of Dilma Rousseff, the former Brazilian president, took to the streets after she was removed and was replaced by Michel Temer.

title: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News  September 1, 2016
description: Times columnist Andrew Rosenthal on Colin Kaepernick, the sorry state of political debate and Gene Wilder. Susan Lehman is host.

title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
description: ISTANBUL  For five generations, Firat Arguns family has lived in Hasankeyf, an ancient town on the Tigris River in southeast Turkey where he runs a small bed-and-breakfast with a well-appointed garden.

title: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this podcast, Andrew Rosenthal, an Op-Ed columnist with the Times, talks about the news  the good, the bad and that which makes him mad.

title: Closing the Academic Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Hell: Prep School Sex Abuse Inquiry Paints Grim Picture
description: Sexual abuse was so rampant that it created a private hell for some students at an elite prep school in Rhode Island in the 1970s and 80s, investigators reported on Thursday, describing an atmosphere of terror in which at least 61 students were victimized and some staff members committed assaults for years before being forced out.

title: Hillary Clintons Graciousness
description: To the Editor:

title: Defending Obamas Record on National Monuments
description: To the Editor:

title: Report on St. George's School With Exhibits
description: The following is the report of investigators about sexual abuse accusations at St. George's School in Rhode Island.

title: As Trump vs. Clinton Captivates World, Netanyahu Is Unusually Silent
description: JERUSALEM  For three hours, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel held forth on all sorts of topics  on Israel and the Middle East, on his record and on his plans. One subject that Mr. Netanyahu studiously avoided in his expansive conversation with American visitors last weekend, though, was the United States election.

title: EpiPen Price Rises Could Mean More Riches for Mylan Executives
description: Heather Bresch, chief executive at Mylan, the pharmaceutical giant that has been vilified for price increases on its EpiPen allergy treatment, maintains that her company has attained a sort of capitalist nirvana  it does good for others while doing well for itself.

title: Timeless Pieces for Your Home  With a Graphic Punch
description: In an age when stores look increasingly like  homes  cozy and well-appointed spaces to hang, relax, stay awhile  it comes as little surprise that the interior designer Kelly Behuns newest pop-up shop at Barneys New York would be outfitted with one-of-a-kind furniture, custom wallpaper and art. The focal point of the shop was once installed in the late gallerist Holly Solomons own dining room: a bespoke, floor-to-ceiling neoprene panel, painted for Solomon by the artist Izhar Patkin. It was this very traditional theme of pastoral picnic and yet it was on this crazy very subversive material, and the fact that she would have that in her Park Avenue apartment  I was so intrigued by, Behun says, adding that the space itself is a homage to Solomon, who blurred the lines between art, craft and design in the 70s and 80s. It comes back to this idea of living with art and how you incorporate art and design in your world. And you create these sort of tableaus in your home that hopefully enrich you in some way.

title: A Morning in Chelsea with the Skate Kitchen
description: The stars of Crystal Moselles new short film for Miu Miu are six female skaters (and best friends), who took T along for a ride.

title: American Teenagers Tennis Game Shaped by Argentinas Clay
description: When Courtney Donaldson arrived at the airport in Buenos Aires for the first time, in January 2012, he was unfamiliar with the language and the customs of Argentina and did not know a soul there.

title: A Day at the Park With Fashions Favorite Girl Skateboarders
description: Crystal Moselle, the director most recently of the feature The Wolfpack, first spotted Nina Moran and Rachelle Vinberg on the G train, skateboards in tow. They swapped information on the platform. I was talking mad loud, and I noticed she was peeping us, but everybody peeps when youre a girl with a board on the train, Moran says. We gave her our email because were real. We waited to see if she was. To the girls surprise, Moselle reached out  and spent the next few months getting to know their all- female skateboard crew that also includes Ardelia Lovelace, Jules Lorenzo, Kabrina Adams and Ajani Russell.

title: Sergei Polunin, Ballets Bad Boy, Has a Change of Heart
description: LONDON  The first image is of a man kneeling in a misty white light, his head bowed, his tattoo-covered, muscular torso swaying rhythmically, side to side. Then we see an opera house, the audience arriving, musicians warming up. Backstage, the dancer  Sergei Polunin  in makeup and costume, is in his dressing room, taking various pills and potions. Soon I am going to be so high, he says gleefully, doing quick jumps to warm up, in front of a mirror.

title: The Best TV Shows and Movies New to Netflix, Hulu and More In September
description: At the beginning of every month, subscription streaming services like Netflix, Amazon Prime, Hulu and HBO Now add a new batch of movies and TV shows to their libraries. Some of those movies and TV shows are bad. Some are good. Below is a list of the good, broken down by service. Everything mentioned is available to stream starting today, Sept. 1, unless otherwise indicated.

title: She Didnt Get a Promotion. Should She Stay or Quit?
description: I applied for a promotion to replace my boss, who is retiring. I was the obvious choice and the only applicant with the degree and experience for the position. I also had the longest tenure. But the search team chose someone else. Since then, my new boss has hired many consultants because she doesnt know how to do the job herself. (I suspect she never will.) Worse, I never received a rejection letter after my interview. The disrespect is very discouraging. Should I take the bull by the horns and offer to resign or (fake) smile and go along with the company in perpetuity?

title: Donald Trumps Brexit Moment
description: Early in his long, loud and frightening immigration speech on Wednesday, Donald Trump claimed that illegal immigration costs our country more than $113 billion a year.

title: Yayoi Kusamas Dots Obsession  Alive, Seeking for Eternal Hope
description: Inside (and outside) the 87-year-old artists installation at Philip Johnsons Glass House in New Canaan, Conn.

title: An Icon of Modernist Architecture  Covered in Polka Dots
description: The Glass House, Philip Johnsons New Canaan, Conn. modernist paean to voyeurism (well, sort of), has played host to a number of site-specific projects over the last few years, ever since its exhibition series began with a show of Frank Stella sculptures in situ back in 2012. In almost every case, though, site-specific work at the Glass House has entailed inhabiting the unique exhibition space, often with contemporary dance or ambient music  not interfering with the house itself. (The closest anyone had come to date was Fujiko Nakayas Veil, which enveloped the house in a mist of fog once an hour in 2014.)

title: An Airport Survival Guide
description: Weather delays mean plenty of free time on our hands, but chances are, you fill it by checking flight information. How to make the most of your wait? You can settle in with a neck pillow and the latest Stephen King tome, of course, from the airport bookshop. Or check into a micro-hotel, listen to a string quartet, visit a museum or explore the quick service efforts of a rash of celebrity chefs at many of the following domestic terminals in 10 major airports across the country.

title: Cracking a Glass Ceiling With the Maestros Baton
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland  There were practical tips on wielding the baton, on using the left hand to inspire the orchestra, on when to go for clarity and when to go for passion. Then the conductor Marin Alsop offered a word of warning after one of the women she was coaching at a master class here made a delicate flourish while leading the orchestra.

title: He Used Us as Props: Conservative Hispanics Deplore Donald Trumps Speech
description: Donald J. Trump faced a backlash on Thursday from some of his top conservative Hispanic supporters, who said their hopes that he was softening his immigration policy had been dashed by his fiery speech Wednesday night, which they said was anti-immigrant.

title: Did Donald Trumps Mexico Gamble Pay Off?
description: To the Editor:

title: Latino Protesters Say No to Trump
description: Activists in Los Angeles and demonstrators in Phoeniz, Ariz., protested against Donald J. Trumps bid for the White House and denounced his recent visit to Mexico City.

title: When Im Mistakenly Put on an Email Chain, Should I Hit Reply All Asking to Be Removed?
description: No.

title: Kurds Fear the U.S. Will Again Betray Them, in Syria
description: ISTANBUL  For almost two years, Syrian Kurds, with American weapons, air cover and training, have fought and died in battle against the Islamic State. They have taken pride in their status as the United States most faithful proxy in the fight against the militant group, and they have hoped their effectiveness as warriors would lead to American support for Kurdish political gains inside Syria.

title: Swiss Open Criminal Investigation of Franz Beckenbauer
description: GENEVA  Franz Beckenbauer, one of German soccers most famed players and managers, is one of four top officials under investigation for fraud and other offenses related to Germanys bid to host the 2006 World Cup, the Switzerland attorney generals office said Thursday.

title: Five Interesting New Stores (and Retail Happenings) in New York
description: From Bergdorf Goodman's new ground-floor renovation to Balenciaga at Dover Street Market, the retail news to know.

title: Map of Tropical Storm Hermines Path
description: Live map of Hermine's forecasted path.

title: Review: Le Carr, the Con Mans Son: Writer, Liar, Survivor, Spy
description: Years ago, when he was thinking about writing an autobiography, John le Carr recounts, he hired two detectives to research him and his family. As the son of a flamboyant con man, as a spy for Her Majestys Secret Service, and as a novelist who spent his days making up things, truth and memory tended to blur together: Im a liar, I explained. Born to lying, bred to it, trained to it by an industry that lies for a living, practiced in it as a novelist. He was interested in learning the facts of his life, he told the detectives  since, as a maker of fictions, I invent versions of myself, never the real thing, if it exists.

title: Under New Policy for Homeless Families, Children Can Miss Less School
description: Homeless families in New York City have long been forced into a difficult choice: In order to apply for housing, they must have their children skip school.

title: Rising Drug Prices Put Big Pharmas Lobbying to the Test
description: Drug makers have been getting their $2.3 billion worth in Washington. That is how much they have spent lobbying Congress over the last decade. It may help explain why no legislative proposal to rein in rising prescription prices has gone anywhere. The latest outcry involving Mylan will put that hefty investment in influence to its biggest test.

title: For the Sake of Art: Risk and Reward at 2,000 Degrees
description: Even when temperatures reach 90 degrees, a certain type of New Yorker will choose to stand next to a 2,000-degree furnace. This is a glass blower. Since few of them are able to set up shop in their apartments, many head to UrbanGlass, which started in 1977 as an artists co-op in SoHo called the New York Experimental Glass Workshop. Under its current name and at its current location in Fort Greene, UrbanGlass gives glass artists, and those who try to be, access to the expensive and enormous equipment they need.

title: Israel Courts Foreign Money in Effort to Become Gas Exporter
description: LONDON  Israels energy minister laid on the charm as he spoke to a few dozen oil executives, contractors and analysts in a crowded hotel conference room about the countrys natural gas prospects.

title: Aimed at Zika Mosquitoes, Spray Kills Millions of Honeybees
description: The Monday morning scene at Juanita Stanleys apiary in Summerville, S.C., was ghastly and stunningly quiet: Everywhere one looked were clumps of honeybees, dead after a dousing on Sunday with the potent pesticide with which the local authorities had intended to kill mosquitoes.

title: Jackie Chan Is Among Winners of Honorary Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES  A legend of martial arts cinema, a film editor with 60 years of experience, a celebrated documentarian and the casting director for films like Tootsie and Fiddler on the Roof will receive honorary Oscars from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences at the organizations Governors Awards on Nov. 12.

title: Popcorn, Booing and Cheering: This Is Summer Mummers
description: Thousands of people pack the Yucca Theater in Midland, Tex., every summer on Fridays and Saturdays for a rowdy evening filled with popcorn throwing. The 67-year-old tradition is called Summer Mummers.

title: Producer Scott Sanders to Direct Westfield Entertainment
description: The Westfield Corporation, which recently opened a new mall in the World Trade Center Oculus, has tapped the Tony-winning producer Scott Sanders to direct its entertainment offerings.

title: Photo of F.S.U. Football Star Sitting With Boy Eating Alone at School Charms Internet
description: Travis Rudolph, a star football player at Florida State University in Tallahassee, is no stranger to the spotlight. He is famous for his award-winning athleticism, catching high and running far as a wide receiver.

title: The Bride and Groom Are Kittens. At Death They Did Not Part.
description: WHAT does it take to herd about 15 dead cats in Victorian dress to a wedding in Brooklyn?

title: Thousands March in Venezuela to Demand Presidents Ouster
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Thousands took to the streets here on Thursday to demand the ouster of President Nicols Maduro in what appeared to be the years largest display of frustration with Venezuelas economic collapse and leadership.

title: Birthday Wishes at a Homeless Shelter
description: A birthday party for children at a Manhattan homeless shelter.

title: Getty Images Announces Grant Winners for 2016
description: Photographers doing personal projects on social issues received $10,000 each on Thursday from the 2016 Getty Images Grants for Editorial Photography.

title: Getty Images Announces Grant Winners for 2016
description: PERPIGNAN, France  Photographers working on personal projects that focus on social issues received $10,000 each on Thursday from the 2016 Getty Images Grants for Editorial Photography. The awards were announced here at the Visa pour lImage festival.

title: Crying Wolf, Then Confronting Trump
description: Conservative commentators and die-hard Republicans often brush off denunciations of Donald Trump as an unprincipled hatemonger by saying: Yeah, yeah, thats what Democrats wail about every Republican theyre trying to take down. Sing me a song I havent heard so many times before.

title: Tests Confirm Mosquitoes in Miami Beach Are Carrying Zika Virus
description: WASHINGTON  Florida announced on Thursday that, for the first time, mosquitoes in Miami Beach had tested positive for the Zika virus, a disappointing confirmation that the virus is still active in the area.

title: Heres Hollywoods Newest Foreign Legion
description: From Fritz Lang to Alejandro G. Irritu, Hollywood has a long tradition of nabbing talent from abroad. This summer, the custom has found new life in a crop of genre pictures by foreign-born filmmakers directing in English.

title: From Toys to Art Treasures: The Teddy Bear Project
description: Children consider them beloved companions. Parents think of them as cuddly toys. Psychiatrists call them transitional objects, comforting possessions that help the young navigate their way from helplessness to independence. But right now at the New Museum, theyre playing an unexpected role: elements of art.

title: Presto! Pulp and Poetry: Chandu the Magician and Stranger on the Third Floor
description: Long ago, in a distant galaxy, Hollywoods superhero movies were as modest as the comic books or radio shows that spawned them, using special effects that now feel homespun to conjure fantasies with the artless quality of folk tales.

title: Which Power Conference Wont Vie for National Title? Sorry, Pac-12
description: There is a simple math problem at the heart of the college football season: five power conferences, four playoff spots.

title: Experimental Arts on Fire Island, and Music in the Hamptons
description: The Boffo Fire Island Performance Festival returns to the Pines; VH1 Save the Music hosts its Hamptons Live benefit.

title: Hillary Clinton Raised $143 Million in August for Democrats and Her Campaign
description: Hillary Clinton is raising huge amounts of cash for the Democratic National Committee and state parties, according to figures released by her campaign on Wednesday, laying the groundwork for a substantial investment in swing states during the fall.

title: David Brown, Dallas Police Chief, Announces Retirement
description: HOUSTON  Eight weeks after five officers were killed in an ambush in downtown Dallas, David O. Brown, the Dallas police chief, announced his retirement from the department on Thursday.

title: Experimental Arts on Fire Island, and Music in the Hamptons
description: Savor the final weekends of summer. The Boffo Fire Island Performance Festival, which showcases experimental dance, performance and music, took place Aug. 26 to 28 on the L.G.B.T.-friendly beaches of the Pines. The festival featured a pop-up shop, estate tour, beachside performances and a V.I.P. dinner with Casey Spooner. On Aug. 27, VH1 Save the Music held a benefit in Sagaponack, N.Y., featuring a performance by Fifth Harmony. The event raised $1 million to promote instrumental music education in public schools.

title: Factory Activity Dips, but Economic Growth Seems Promising
description: WASHINGTON (Reuters)  Factory activity contracted in August for the first time in six months as new orders and production tumbled, the Institute for Supply Management said on Thursday, but a low level of layoffs continued to point to a pickup in economic growth in the third quarter.

title: Review: In Morgan, a Snow White With Lips Stained Red
description: That Morgan is a movie about genetics is somehow appropriate, given that the origins of its director, Luke Scott, will be an inescapable component of any discussion of its merits. Unveiling a first feature seems stressful enough; but when your father is peeking over your shoulder as one of the producers, and hes none other than Ridley Scott  who, with Alien and Blade Runner, gave us two of the most memorable science-fiction films of the past 40 years  then the weight of expectation must be especially daunting.

title: Gun Battle Between Ethnic Factions Roils Afghanistans Capital
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Militia forces loyal to the Afghan vice president, the former warlord Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, fought a gun battle with a group of northern Tajik demonstrators in the heart of Kabul on Thursday, leaving at least one person dead and several wounded in a chaotic scene that shook the countrys civil-war fault lines from a generation ago.

title: Review: In Zoom, Everyone Feels Certain Body Parts Are Too Small
description: Zoom, a brainteaser of a film with a breast-and-penis fetish, bets everything on cleverness and a few appealing performances, and it wins. Its conceit nicely fills up its 96 minutes; 97 would have been too long.

title: Review: In Kickboxer: Vengeance, Duty Calls for an Unpracticed Fighter
description: Sure, the new action workout Kickboxer: Vengeance  a reboot of a foot-fighting franchise from the 1980s and 90s  follows a tiresome martial-arts movie formula. But amid the hoary conventions are agreeable inklings of an alternate sensibility.

title: Dismal Days for Brazilian Democracy
description: Rio de Janeiro For an event that marked the end of an era, the final act of the impeachment of Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff was a staid affair, punctuated by procedure and civil speeches.

title: Big Carmakers Merge, Cautiously, Into the Self-Driving Lane
description: When General Motors starts selling a new Cadillac sedan next year, it plans to equip the car with G.M.s answer to Tesla Motors Autopilot.

title: Review: White Girl, a Tale of Cocaine, Sex and Privilege
description: White Girl poses a troubling but unspoken question: To what degree has hard partying with sex and drugs become entrenched as a hazardous rite of passage for bored millennials? Leah (Morgan Saylor), the doll-faced blond protagonist of this movie, written and directed by Elizabeth Wood, is an ebullient New York City college student with an appetite for marijuana, cocaine and casual sex.

title: Cant Get Broadway Tickets? Rock Out to Musicals at the Gym
description: Amid the pounding pop and hip-hop beats that fill area gyms, a small subset of fitness fanatics has, for years, chosen to work out to Les Misrables, Cats and West Side Story.

title: Can You Name These Broadway Theaters?
description: The play may be the thing, but its not the only part of the theater worth your attention. Look up!

title: Review: Jokes, Not Punches, Land With a Thud in Skiptrace
description: Weve signed Jackie Chan and Johnny Knoxville to star; our work is done, said apparently everyone involved in the unintelligible action comedy Skiptrace. The trouble is, pairing two guys who have been amusing individually in the past doesnt guarantee that theyll be amusing together.

title: A Hans Memling Show Is More Than the Sum of Its Divine Parts
description: When it comes to jewels, there are Taylor-Burton rocks and discreet heirloom stones. With museum shows, its the same. Hans Memling: Portraiture, Piety and a Reunited Altarpiece, at the Morgan Library & Museum, is a minute but invaluable gem of some two dozen small paintings, drawings and books set in the Morgans Clare Eddy Thaw gallery, known as the Cube for its intimate size.

title: Why Roz Chast Makes Fun of White Middle-Class New Yorkers
description: A cartoon by the brilliant, widely beloved visual humorist Roz Chast has the title Einsteins on the Beach drawn above a family of three camped out on the shore: Dad, listening to the gurgling coming from his wristwatch, remarks, Guess I shouldnt have worn my Rolex. Mom, sitting in a beach chair and observing a large, transparent bag of food on the blanket at her feet, reflects, Maybe its time to move the sandwiches out of the sun. Their young daughter, emptying a bag of snacks onto the sand, says, I wonder if sea gulls like Cheez Doodles.

title: In Artek and the Aaltos, Caution  Sleek, Modernist Curves Ahead
description: Artek and the Aaltos: Creating a Modern World, a landmark exhibition at the Bard Graduate Center Gallery, is a dizzying, sometimes slightly daunting array of objects, furnishings, drawings, photographs and archival material. Laid out in finely wrought displays, it is one of the most comprehensive exhibitions about the artistry and making of design you are likely to see.

title: Review: The 9th Life of Louis Drax. So, Little Boys Get Nine Lives, Too?
description: Its not clear whether The 9th Life of Louis Drax is deliberately inconsistent or merely an example of confused filmmaking. One thing is certain, however: It sure leaves an unpleasant aftertaste.

title: An Artists Maine Menagerie, as Enduring (and Elusive) as Wildlife
description: CUSHING, Me.  As historians, art restorers and land conservationists transform the artist Bernard Langlaiss property in this coastal hamlet into a museum and sculpture park, they keep finding wooden carvings in the overgrowth.

title: 9 Books for Back-to-School That Times Editors Think You Should Read
description: Even those of us whove left school far behind cant help recognize that pencils-at-the-ready feeling that comes at the end of summer. Fall just feels like the time to get serious, whether you have to go back to class or not. Some of our favorite new back-to-school books tackle difficult issues  voter fraud, ADHD and education. So while the books below dont offer light reading, they do offer plenty to chew on.

title: Theater Listings for Sept. 2-8
description: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

title: No Subway. No Buses. No Uber. No Problem.
description: WE were trapped beneath the heat dome  the air like soup, the sun relentless  with no escape. But as my son, Spencer, and I set off by ferry toward Randalls Island in late July, something like relief swept over us. A faint breeze squeezed through an open window and then stiffened as the boat motored north on the East River. And if I closed my eyes and succumbed to the waters rhythm, I was almost transported out of this urban toaster oven and onto a Caribbean island or maybe a Pacific atoll.

title: Comedy Listings for Sept. 2-8
description: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

title: Leaked Script Shows What Advisers Want Donald Trump to Say at Black Church
description: DETROIT  Donald J. Trumps visit to a black church here on Saturday will be a major moment for a candidate with a history of offending the sensibilities of black Americans.

title: Review: In Kevin Smiths Yoga Hosers, Enlightenment Is Elusive
description: Since the ignominious critical and commercial failure of his 2010 comedy, Cop Out, Kevin Smith has been allowing his filmmaking inspiration to take him in directions that are fanciful even by his own gonzo standards. For reasons best known to himself and perhaps his producers (his explanations in interviews notwithstanding), he is in the middle of a True North trilogy of films combining comedic and horror elements, all set in Canada.

title: The News From Trump Changed. The Main Story Was Slow to Catch Up.
description: It was a fast-paced day for the team covering politics at The New York Times on Wednesday.

title: A Chinese Mystery: Who Owns a Firm on a Global Shopping Spree?
description: Pingyang Countys verdant hills still hint at a long-lost China. Rice paddies and villages surround its bustling towns, and in the fields, farmers wade into the mud to plant seedlings as they have for thousands of years.

title: Behind Chinas Anbang: Empty Offices and Obscure Names
description: In the center of Beijings booming commercial district, with soaring office towers, gleaming shopping malls and luxury apartment complexes, sits a shabby, four-story building with an office that houses stupendous wealth.

title: Review: Max Rose Has Jerry Lewis Tearful Over a Hint of Infidelity
description: Max Rose, a soggy, fragile feature about love, death, marriage and memories, might never have made it to theaters were it not for its star, Jerry Lewis. More than 20 years have passed since he appeared in the delightfully weird Funny Bones, and, whether from curiosity or admiration (most likely, both), moviegoers of a certain age will be unable to resist this unexpected glimpse of a true-blue legend.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Why Did Pea Nieto Invite Trump to Mexico?
description: Mexico City  Mexicos president, Enrique Pea Nieto, had already had a terrible summer. July was the most murderous month in Mexico since he took office in 2012. Second-quarter results showed negative economic growth for the first time in three years. A survey found his approval rating slipping to 23 percent. And a news report even alleged that he plagiarized nearly a third of his law degree thesis. How could he make it any worse? Only by inviting Donald J. Trump, one of the most hated men in Mexico  so hated that piatas with his visage are brisk sellers across the country  to his presidential palace.

Its glass-walled exterior, with Southwestern-like tiles and a somewhat ostentatious sign, feels a little too polished and proper. But once you are inside, Spice exudes a decidedly relaxed atmosphere and has an affordable menu of locally inspired dishes.

title: 1891: Fraud at the Bank of England
description: For some days persistent rumors have been in the air of a colossal fraud said to have been perpetrated on the Bank of England. On Monday the amount alleged to have been stolen was currently given as 250,000, and since then the sum has advanced by leaps and bounds, until today it was confidently asserted in the City that it amounted to half a million. These rumors have obtained a degree of credence in banking circles which calls for authoritative treatment. There is no truth whatever in the report, which, if well founded, would have startled the commercial world, and must have produced results disastrous to the largest interests. The Governor of the Bank of England states that there is absolutely no foundation for the rumors. The story, it appears, arose as follows: It will be remembered that in February last a counter robbery was effected at the Bank of Scotland. Certain of the securities then stolen have been within the last few days presented for payment in Paris, and in one of the Paris papers an announcement appeared confusing the Bank of Scotland with the Bank of England, and stating the amount of the frauds to have been 250,000.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 3, 1891

title: 1966: Sukarno Likens Self to Christ
description: DJAKARTA  Comparing himself to Mohammed and Christ, President Sukarno said today [Sept. 2] that he would go on speaking his mind. The president, who has been stripped of most of his powers, was replying to the criticism which has been leveled at him for his speeches contradicting stated government policy. Mohammed also made speeches all the time, he declared. Challenging those who criticized hero worship and the personality cult in Indonesia, Mr. Sukarno said it was necessary to worship something. He asked what would happen to Islam and Christianity without worship of Mohammed and Christ, then added; I want Indonesia to have a hero the Indonesians can be proud of.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 3, 1966

description: Life With Microbes

title: Reading Toward Recovery
description: Alcoholics Anonymous, commonly referred to as the Big Book, helped to establish the 12-step program. Its been an indispensable guide for millions since it was published in 1939. A new, very different kind of book, Out of the Wreck I Rise: A Literary Companion to Recovery, by Neil Steinberg and Sara Bader, aims to be a complementary comfort.

title: The Latest and Best in Crime Fiction
description: A huge weight of grief bears down like a marble tombstone on A GREAT RECKONING (Minotaur, $28.99), Louise Pennys disquieting mystery featuring Armand Gamache, the retired homicide chief of the Sret du Qubec. Gamache and his wife, Reine-Marie, are wintering among their eccentric neighbors in the remote village of Three Pines when the first snowfall sends everyone scrambling for the warmth of the fireplace at the local bistro. As the village turns into a scene in a snow globe, the friends take to sorting through the desiccated newspapers, magazines and catalogs stuffed behind the bistro walls as insulation a century earlier (as though words could keep winter at bay) and salvaged during a renovation.

title: Rachel Cusk Reviews Two Books About Assisted Reproduction
description: AVALANCHEA Love StoryBy Julia Leigh133 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $23.95.

title: How Growth-Focused Politics Helped Build Vulnerability in Louisianas Flood Zones
description: As coastal communities from the Carolinas through New England track Tropical Storm Hermine, which struck Florida yesterday as that states first hurricane since 2005 before weakening, its worth looking back at the disastrous deluge in Louisiana for wider lessons. A good starting point is two photographs.

title: No Zika Cases Reported During Rio Olympics, W.H.O. Says
description: No Zika infections were reported in Brazil during the Olympics, either among athletes or visitors, the World Health Organization said Friday.

title: Five Things T Editors Are Really Into Right Now
description: I am not, nor have I ever been, a Serum Person. Serums just always seemed to be a thing people liked to say they use in order to appear fancy and well groomed. That was until I tried Dr. Grosss Radiance Booster  housed in a little orange bottle that, I was sure when I purchased it, would not make me more radiant. But as Ive used the serum in my morning routine (either applying it before moisturizer or mixing it into my makeup), it has surprisingly delivered on its promise. Ive been told how radiant I look  even though, no, I didnt just come back from summer vacation. $68, drdennisgross.com.  ISABEL WILKINSON

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: In Brooklyn, Stifling Higher Learning Among Hasidic Women
description: In the mid-1940s, Joel Teitelbaum, an eminent and charismatic rabbi, immigrated to the United States, colonizing a section of Williamsburg in Brooklyn for his Hasidic sect, the Satmar, its name taken from the Hungarian town of Szatmar, where Rabbi Teitelbaum had fought to resist the encroachments of a modernizing society.

title: Big Love for Small Donkeys
description: Members of the group Hudson Valley Donkey Walkers take a herd of miniature donkeys for a summer stroll.

title: Roasted Eggplant and Tomato Pasta
description: Ripe, juicy heirloom tomatoes and roasted eggplant are the stars of this hearty summer dish.

title: Eggplant, Tomatoes and Just a Bit of Pasta
description: Pasta is a generous co-star.

title: Inside the List
description: Saddle Up: As any observer of the best-seller lists can tell you, World War II exerts a deep hold on the popular imagination. Lately, though, readers seem less interested in the Nazis human victims than in the quirky corners of the war. A couple of years ago, Robert M. Edsel (and his co-writer, Bret Witter) spent 21 weeks on the paperback nonfiction list with The Monuments Men, about Allied efforts to retrieve looted art from the Germans; now Elizabeth Lettss The Perfect Horse  No.17 on the extended hardcover nonfiction list  tells a similar story about the mission to save a breed of horses, the noble Lipizzaner stallions, that the Nazis abducted to create a master race of war animals. General Patton himself approved the rescue: Get them. Make it fast, the book quotes him saying. But why divert military resources to protect horses, however mighty? According to an essay Letts wrote for the Amazon blog Omnivoracious, the answer lies with the Armys legacy of training cavalry officers. Turns out, the interwar years are called the cavalrys golden age, she says. Army-bred horses won Olympic medals and Army-trained riders shone in international competitions. To belong to the U.S. Cavalry was to be a skilled rider. It was also to be trained in a code of honor known to cavalries around the world: Always take care of your horse first. In the last days of World War II, the worlds most priceless purebreds were in danger of being slaughtered for food. Their only hope was a group of American soldiers who by chance were camped out nearby. As it happened, these were the soldiers of the Second Cavalry  one of Americas most storied mounted units, and one of the last to be mechanized. ... As Patton liked to remind people, many of the most celebrated leaders in World War II got their start as cavalry officers, and in the last days of the war, when the priceless purebreds were in danger, these men remembered the lesson to put the horses first. Letts is, no surprise, a horse lover herself: Her previous best seller, The Eighty-Dollar Champion, was about the show jumper Snowman, and in her Twitter biography she admits she never got over Black Beauty.

title: I Do, Part Two: Why Couples Decide to Renew Their Vows
description: After a decade or two of marriage, what could possess someone to hire a party planner, caterer, florist and officiant, and then surprise a spouse with a ceremony and reception in which they renew their vows in front of several dozen of their closest friends?

title: Atlantic Silversides Know the Wisdom of Crowds
description: Those who fish the piers and shorelines of New York City probably know the skinny Atlantic silverside by its bait-shop alias: spearing. Dozens of the small fish are frozen and vacuum-packed into blocks of ice, which can be purchased for a few dollars at local bait and tackle shops. Decades ago, my brother and I learned about patience from these impenetrable chunks of frozen fish, waiting for what seemed like hours until the block thawed sufficiently to pry out a full length fish or two, which we immediately impaled whole, on a hook.

title: Hurricane Hermine Thrashes Florida
description: Gov. Rick Scott told Florida residents how to survive Hurricane Hermine.

title: The Faces of Coney Island
description: The photographer Mark Hartman takes portraits of the people he encounters on the beach in Brooklyn. But his work is about far more than just summer leisure.

title: Sunbathed Portraits at Coney Island
description: It began one afternoon in mid-August. The photographer Mark Hartman had recently turned 35, and he found himself going through something like a midlife crisis. He was ready for a change. So he took the train to Coney Island, Brooklyn, and started walking, camera in hand.

title: Curating 9/11 Relics One Page at a Time
description: Summer unofficially ends on a Monday that is meant to glorify organized labor, but in New York, the days festivities focus more on celebrating West Indian heritage. Unionized workers unwilling to interrupt the holiday weekend for a parade will stage their own march five days later, which will be followed by the third of Septembers tributes, the anniversary of 9/11.

title: Taco Trucks on Every Corner: Trump Supporters Anti-Immigration Warning
description: That was Marco Gutierrez, founder of the group Latinos for Trump, issuing a dire warning to the United States in an interview with Joy Reid on MSNBC on Thursday night.

title: A Manhattan Museum Looks at Cubas Exotic Fauna and Flora
description: In a giant production studio on the Upper West Side of Manhattan in July, volunteers were busy making 2,986 tobacco leaves  painting, distressing and scrunching pieces of brown paper by hand. Nearby, an artist built part of a coral reef from towels, to get the texture just right, while a fellow artist sculpted a giant, killer prehistoric owl.

title: Supermans Building Goes Condo
description: Reading the ads for the Standish Arms Hotel in Brooklyn Heights that were in newspapers at the turn of the 20th century, you might be forgiven for thinking they were published recently. Like todays ads for high-end developments in the area, most of them tout the quick commute to Wall Street by ferry and the views of Manhattan.

title: Samsungs Recall: The Problem With Lithium-Ion Batteries
description: Samsung Electronics announced on Friday that it  would recall 2.5 million Galaxy Note 7 smartphones after finding a flaw in the battery cell that resulted in fires. It is the latest problem for the lithium-ion battery, the power source at the heart of most modern devices.

title: A Bridge from Moscow to Paris: 130 Works of Modern Art
description: PARIS  Some cities mark time by natural events  the year of the earthquake, the flood, the tsunami, the hurricane. But Parisians, being Parisian, tend to tell time by landmark exhibitions: Paris-Moscow 1900-1930 at the Pompidou Center in 1979, the Czanne retrospective at the Grand Palais in 1995, Dada at the Pompidou in 2005.

The words adrenaline junkie come to mind.

description: CEDAR KEY, Fla.  Florida may have largely dodged catastrophic damage from Hurricane Hermine, which blew through the state on Friday, but you would not have known it by visiting this artsy village of about 700 people in the northwest, near the Panhandle.

title: The Sunday Routine of Koshin Paley Ellison, Monk and Zen Teacher
description: In 2007, Koshin Paley Ellison and Robert Chodo Campbell founded the New York Zen Center for Contemplative Care, a nonprofit in Chelsea that offers meditation training and study programs for medical professionals and caregivers. Since then, they and their students have worked with over 80,000 people. Dr. Paley Ellison, co-editor of the new book Awake at the Bedside: Contemplative Teachings on Palliative and End-of-Life Care, lives on the Upper West Side with Mr. Campbell, who is also his husband, and two Maine coon cats.

title: Mets Show Some Range With Music Playlists That Mix and Match

The Securities and Exchange Commissions recent decision to throw in the towel in its civil case against Daniel H. Mudd, the chief executive of Fannie Mae in the go-go years immediately preceding the crisis, helps explain why.

description: The days when Brooklyn meant baseball, boredom and bad breath, to quote a dig apocryphally attributed to Barbra Streisand, are long gone. Now, the borough that once had to content itself with bragging about being the fourth largest city in America is getting a speakers series to match its expanding global profile.

And at $22,210,782.50, the new purchase was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

He quit his job as a well-paid sales representative in the printing industry and became his wifes 24-hour caregiver: dressing her, doing laundry and scheduling social visits with friends. Faith, hope and courage became his new mantra.

description: Welcome to Watching, The New York Timess what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

title: The Playlist: Young Thug Turns the Summers Big Meme Into a Standout Track
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing  in the Playlist. This week, we have compiled 10 tracks you may have missed this summer. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this format? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com.

title: Islam Karimov Dies at 78, Ending a Long, Ruthless Rule of Uzbekistan
description: MOSCOW  Islam Karimov, a ruthless autocrat who ruled Uzbekistan for almost three decades, died on Friday in the Uzbek capital, Tashkent. He was 78.

title: Support Wanes for Paul LePage, Maines Brash Governor
description: AUGUSTA, Me.  No visitor to Gov. Paul R. LePages office suite can miss the framed message on the wall, opposite the main door: Dont expect to build up the weak by pulling down the strong.

description: MANILA  President Rodrigo Duterte declared a state of lawlessness on Saturday after a powerful blast ripped through a crowded night market in the city of Davao on Friday, killing at least 14 people and wounding more than 60.

title: Finding Love an Ocean Away

That will cost you $650,000, plus a $500,000 setup fee with an Israeli outfit called the NSO Group. You can spy on more people if you would like  just check out the companys price list.

title: For Unions and New York City Hall, an Open-Door Relationship Turns Complex
description: As what would become one of the most controversial deals of Mayor Bill de Blasios administration  the removal of deed restrictions on a Lower East Side nursing home  hung in the balance, the health care workers union, 1199 S.E.I.U., sought to exert its influence through a series of emails and text messages to the mayors top officials.

title: New Hope for Tasmanian Devils in Fight Against Contagious Cancer
description: There may yet be hope for the Tasmanian devil.

title: A Popular Vacation Stop? This New Hampshire Liquor Store Beckons
description: HAMPTON, N.H.  Over Independence Day weekend, a million vehicles cruised the Maine Turnpike, as Interstate 95 is known north of the Piscataqua River. It is impossible to say exactly how many of those cars first stopped at New Hampshire Liquor & Wine Outlet No. 76, but a bit of regional vernacular  hella wicked many  will suffice for an estimate.

description: To the Editor:

title: My Familys Story in Georgetowns Slave Past
description: New Orleans  One fall day in 1838, Jesuit priests from Georgetown University assembled enslaved people and walked them to a ship at a wharf south of Washington. The boat was not filled with silver or wood or cotton, but with 56 people, some of the 272 enslaved humans kept by the university.

title: Lawyers Burnish Teslas Deal for SolarCity
description: The lawyers have grabbed control of the merger between Tesla Motors and SolarCity. They are blanketing the deal with legal process to try to smooth over the conflict of interest stemming from Elon Musks ownership interest in both companies. But will it be enough?

description: The F.B.I. on Friday released its interview with Hillary Clinton, the Democratic presidential candidate, and a lengthy memorandum summarizing the bureau's investigation into her use of private email server while she was secretary of state.

title: Christiania, a Commune in Denmark, Dismantles Drug Market After Shootings
description: With its open-air marijuana stalls festooned in psychedelic colors and its freewheeling, self-governing structure, the Christiania neighborhood in Copenhagen has been for decades emblematic of Danish liberalism and tolerance.

description: Catch these summer season highlights before they close.

title: More Bad News for Africas Elephants: A Super-Slow Reproduction Rate
description: Africas elephants are widely loved  and widely endangered. Poachers killed off nearly 30 percent of the continents savanna elephants from 2007 to 2014, according to a survey published this week. Their populations are now declining at a rate of nearly 8 percent a year.

title: Coming Back Home to Oscar de la Renta
description: When Oscar de la Renta died, in October 2014, the fashion world was shaken, nowhere more strongly than at Mr. de la Rentas West 42nd Street atelier. His was a family company  his son-in-law, Alex Bolen, is its chief executive  and many long-serving employees felt like family, too.

title: Indonesia Is Pushed to Ban Alcohol for Health of Bodies, if Not Souls
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  I.B. Agung Partha foresees an apocalypse, as he put it, on the Indonesian resort island of Bali.

title: What I Love | Nancy Zeckendorf
description: The widow of the developer William Zeckendorf Jr., lives in Museum Tower in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Life With the Legendary Zeckendorfs
description: As the wife, daughter-in-law and stepmother of New York real estate titans, Nancy Zeckendorf has spent a lifetime studying blueprints and refining her common-sense approach to home design. When she renovated her two-bedroom pied--terre at Museum Tower on West 53rd Street, decorated with contemporary and antique furnishings, she had a dedicated broom closet built in the hall by the living room.

title: A Short History of The Timess Shortest Story
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Daniel Victor, a reporter on the Express Team, discusses his one-word story.

title: F.D.A. Bans Sale of Many Antibacterial Soaps, Saying Risks Outweigh Benefits
description: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration banned the sale of soaps containing certain antibacterial chemicals on Friday, saying industry had failed to prove they were safe to use over the long term or more effective than using ordinary soap and water.

title: Why Facts Dont Unify Us
description: According to the Pew Research Center, the nation is more polarized than at any time in recent history. While some of the issues dividing us boil down to ideology and preference, there is at least one on which hard science should have a strong say  climate change. But do numbers and figures change peoples opinions?

title: Think Like a Doctor: The Sick Traveler Solved!
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to take on the complicated case of a 50-year-old woman who felt feverish and couldnt stop vomiting and who ended up losing a lot of weight. Like the doctors who saw her as she searched for a diagnosis, many of you focused on her recent journey to Kenya as the source of her symptoms. It was a completely reasonable approach, and one that was extensively explored by the doctors who cared for her. But ultimately it was incorrect.

title: After 0-12 Season, Kansas Starts With Romp and Hopes for Best
description: LAWRENCE, Kan.  By the yardstick that matters most, the 2015 Kansas football season was a disaster: The Jayhawks lost all 12 of their games. Look deeper, and the numbers are worse. Eight of the losses were by at least 25 points. Home attendance dipped by 20 percent, to an average of 27,282. Crowds that size make up barely half the capacity at Memorial Stadium.

title: Donald Trump, Changing His Mind
description: Presidential candidates have a long history of reversing their positions, but Mr. Trump takes it to a new level.

title: Yum Brands in China Adds Owners With Skill and Connections
description: Yum Brands has added some spice at a price. The company, which owns KFC and Pizza Hut, is selling part of its China business to Alibabas mobile-payments affiliate and a private-equity firm run by Fred Hu, the former chairman of Goldman Sachs China. They bring valuable technology skill and connections. It is a better deal than usual for so-called cornerstone investors, but may pay off for Yums coming spinoff.

title: Dean Baquet in Conversation With Media Columnist Jim Rutenberg
description: Welcome to Times Insider Events  live programming for Times Insiders and their guests.

title: 6 Things We Learned in the F.B.I. Clinton Email Investigation
description: WASHINGTON  Documents released by the F.B.I. on Friday revealed new details about the Justice Departments yearlong investigation into Hillary Clintons use of a private email server and whether she and her aides mishandled classified information. Among the documents was an 11-page summary of an interview F.B.I. agents conducted with Mrs. Clinton on July 2. Two days later, the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, said the bureau had recommended to the Justice Department that neither Mrs. Clinton nor her aides should be charged with a crime. Here are six highlights from those documents:

title: Princes Old Band Resurrects Him Through His Songs
description: MINNEAPOLIS  On April 21, as news spread that Prince had been found dead at his Paisley Park compound in Chanhassen, Minn., a crowd began to gather 21 miles away at First Avenue, the Minneapolis club where he had filmed the concert scenes for the 1984 film Purple Rain. Thousands of fans flocked to what became a giant all-night block party memorial, and local acts took the stage to play covers of Princes songs.

title: At New Museum, a Pop-Up Support System for Black Lives Matter

But it has also raised another fraught question: Is our national anthem itself racist?

description: The United States Open added a new $150 million retractable roof before this years tournament, so fans inside Arthur Ashe Stadium no longer need umbrellas. They might, however, need earplugs.

description: Jared Fogle, the former Subway pitchman who pleaded guilty last year to sex acts with minors and distribution of child pornography, is blaming the parents of one of his victims, arguing that their divorce and lack of supervision led to the girls emotional distress that they attributed to him.

description: Chihira Junco is one of four such androids that have been created so far. The company that developed the technology plans to make 1,000 more in 2017.

description: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times. In this piece, David Dunlap, a Metro reporter, connects the dots between eBay and an unsung Times defender of freedom of the press.
