description: I encountered this very young band opening for Lucius a year ago. Now they have a record about to come out, and a first single here:

title: Save Gabon From Election Fraud
description: On Saturday, Aug. 27, presidential elections were held in my country, Gabon, in West Africa, and I was the candidate who won by a substantial vote margin. Nearly a week later, I would have expected to be addressing the world as Gabons president-elect, ready and willing to work with the United States and all our international partners to fight terrorism, build our economies and improve the lives of our citizens through increased development and cooperation.

title: Looking Back at Alan Kurdi and Other Faces of Syrian Crisis
description: Friday is the first anniversary of the death of Alan Kurdi, a 2-year-old Syrian refugee whose drowned body was discovered on a beach in Turkey. Photos of the boy shocked the world and put a human face on the refugee crisis.

title: Tensions Deepen Between Donald Trump and R.N.C.
description: The Republican National Committee had high hopes that Donald J. Trump would deliver a compassionate and measured speech about immigration on Wednesday, and prepared to lavish praise on the candidate on the partys Twitter account.

title: Reinhard Selten, Whose Strides in Game Theory Led to a Nobel, Dies at 85
description: Reinhard Selten, who was expelled from school in Germany when he was 14 because he was half Jewish, but returned after World War II to study mathematics and become the countrys first and only Nobel winner for economics, died on Aug. 23 in Poznan, Poland. He was 85.

title: Spain Remains Deadlocked as Vote to Form New Government Fails
description: For the second time this week, Spanish lawmakers on Friday rejected a bid by Mariano Rajoy, the caretaker prime minister, to form a government, increasing the likelihood that Spain will have to hold its third national election in a year to break its political stalemate.

title: The Hidden Scars All Refugees Carry
description: Many people have characterized my novel, The Sympathizer, as an immigrant story, and me as an immigrant. No. My novel is a war story and I am not an immigrant. I am a refugee who, like many others, has never ceased being a refugee in some corner of my mind.

title: Assembling the Front Page: A Time Lapse
description: The front page of The New York Times begins as a pencil drawing (on green paper).

title: Is EpiPen a Brand-Name or a Generic Drug? Mylan Casts It Both Ways
description: The drug company Mylan has profited richly from its exclusive right to sell EpiPen, the severe allergy treatment. Recent price increases on the product have rendered it unaffordable for many, leading to a public outcry.

title: 22 Migrant Women Held in Pennsylvania Start a Hunger Strike to Protest Detention
description: Margarita Alberto cannot forget the tantrum her 6-year-old son threw several months ago. One afternoon he started shouting that he wanted to leave the Pennsylvania immigration detention center for families, where they have been held since Oct. 28, 2015, He said, Its your fault that were here, your fault! Ms. Alberto said.

title: Focused on Singles, Jack Sock Delivers a U.S. Open Upset
description: Jack Sock was not going to be satisfied anymore with just making the third round of a Grand Slam tournament.

title: Microsofts Challenge to Government Secrecy Wins Dozens of Supporters
description: SEATTLE  Dozens of allies threw their weight behind Microsoft on Friday in a case that challenges law enforcements use of secrecy orders to cloak its pursuit of digital communications in investigations.

title: Madison Keys Arises from a Second Set Slumber
description: Inside a sleepy Arthur Ashe Stadium, Madison Keys needed some noise.

title: In Britain, Soul-Searching on Brexit
description: It has been more than two months since the British voted to leave the European Union, yet it often appears from the continuing debate in Britain that the June 23 referendum served only to intensify the questions about Brexit. That is healthy. A move as complex and consequential as this can only benefit from more discussion and soul-searching. After all, this is new territory, with Britain headed where no other E.U. member has gone before.

title: Economic Resilience, Political Paralysis
description: In the more than seven years since the Great Recession ended, the economy has never soared, but it would be fair to say it has been remarkably resilient.

title: Endorsements in New York Primary Races
description: The New York Legislature is still broken, even though its two leading bad actors  Sheldon Silver, the former Assembly speaker, and Dean Skelos, the former Senate majority leader  have been convicted of corruption and sentenced to prison. Besides prosecuting the criminals, changing Albanys culture requires sending in people who will put public interests ahead of their own. Here are recommendations for some races in the Democratic primary on Sept. 13.

title: Yankees Run Down the September Stretch Gets Off on the Wrong Foot
description: BALTIMORE  The month of August provided a dose of optimism for the Yankees. The team found that, even though it had traded away several key parts, its new cast of players was capable of success.

title: New York City Will Change Lead Testing Methods at Its Schools
description: New York City said on Friday that it would adjust its procedure of testing for lead in the water supply of schools, after experts said the citys methods could lower the levels found.

title: For Russell Knox, $4.8 Million in Earnings but a Ryder Cup Snub
description: NORTON, Mass.  Two holes before he finished his opening round Friday at the Deutsche Bank Championship, Russell Knox sought out his wife, Andrea, in the gallery. He told her that he needed to see a doctor. His wife was not surprised.

title: Donald Trump Meets With Black Leaders Ahead of Detroit Church Visit
description: PHILADELPHIA  Amid confusion over whether he would speak at a black church this weekend, Donald J. Trumps halting attempts to win over African-American voters took him to Philadelphia on Friday, where he spoke with a small group of business owners and community leaders and had an emotional meeting with the mother of a young woman who was killed by undocumented immigrants.

title: A Met Whos Become the Met-Killer
description: When the Washington Nationals signed Daniel Murphy last December, for three years and $37.5 million, Max Scherzer thought he knew what they had gotten.

title: Avoiding Foreclosure for Now, Harlem Church Celebrates With Anti-Gay Vitriol
description: The Atlah Worldwide Church in Harlem has grown infamous for the incendiary and often anti-gay views expressed by its pastor, which are trumpeted in bold letters on a large sign outside the church.

title: Buddy From the Block
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  I predict that the response to todays puzzle by Damon Gulczynski will be as divided as his entries, which can be boiled down to Things Most People Over the Age of 40 Are Bound to Know and Things Most People Over the Age of 40 Might Not Know But Are About to Learn.

title: Fred Hellerman, Last of the Weavers Folk Group, Dies at 89
description: Fred Hellerman, a singer, guitarist and songwriter and the last surviving member of the Weavers, the quartet that in the 1950s helped usher in the folk music revival, died on Thursday at his home in Weston, Conn. He was 89.

title: Mets Fall to Nationals; Ailing Jacob deGrom May Miss His Next Start
description: At this point, should Mets fans shake their heads in disbelief or applaud that their team is still in the playoff hunt despite a seemingly endless stream of injuries? Perhaps they should do both, and pray.

title: Jon Polito, a Favorite in Coen Brothers Films, Dies at 65
description: Jon Polito, a character actor who often played law enforcement figures and gangsters and had memorable turns in many films by Joel and Ethan Coen, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 65.

title: CiCi Belliss Charming Run Through the U.S. Open Ends Swiftly
description: CiCi Bellis was the youngest player left in the womens draw when she arrived Friday night for her third-round match at Arthur Ashe Stadium. The lights dimmed when Bellis, a 17-year-old Californian, made her entrance. She got a warm reception. She unpacked her tennis bag and got ready for the biggest stage of her life.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I feel degraded.

title: Alexandra Willkie and Zachary Pasanen: A Romantic, and Risky, Dance Move
description: Alexandra Elizabeth Willkie, a daughter of Carlotta Fendig Willkie and Wendell Lewis Willkie II of Darien, Conn., is to be married Sept. 4 to Zachary Anton Pasanen, the son of Susan Anton Pasanen and Dr. Wayne Edward Pasanen of North Andover, Mass. The Rev. Richard Pike, an Episcopal priest, is to officiate at Blue Hill at Stone Barns in Pocantico Hills, N.Y.

title: Corrections: September 3, 2016
description: FRONT PAGE

title: For Art Dealers, the Place to Be Is Still London
description: These are early days, but the Hieronymus Bosch vision of a socioeconomic apocalypse that many feared would follow Britains June 23 vote to leave the European Union has yet to materialize.

title: Whats on TV Sunday: The Talented Mr. Ripley and Building Star Trek
description: Seeking a thrill? Choose among The Talented Mr. Ripley; its French precursor, Purple Noon; and Carol, all adapted from Patricia Highsmith novels. Ride the roller coaster at Walley World in Vacation. Or venture into deep space with Building Star Trek, a 50th-anniversary special.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: The Intervention and Shame
description: Clea DuVall couples with her bestie, Natasha Lyonne, in The Intervention, about friends who think they know better where marriage is concerned. And Michael Fassbender reveals all  and nothing  in Shame.

title: Want a National Title? Hire a Coach, Wait Three Years
description: If college footballs national championship were awarded purely on the basis of preseason hype, the Washington Huskies would be top contenders. A frequent Pacific-12 also-ran, Washington returns more than a dozen starters from last years team, which was widely acknowledged as better than its 7-6 record. The teams No. 14 ranking in the current Associated Press poll is the teams highest since 2002.

title: Onstage With Putin, Shinzo Abe of Japan Calls for Resolution of Island Dispute
description: TOKYO  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan made an impassioned plea on Saturday to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for their two countries to resolve a dispute over a group of islands that has been a sore point in their relations since the end of World War II.

title: Dont Try to Use It or You Will Be Called Un-American
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

title: Goodbye, Ivory Tower. Hello, Silicon Valley Candy Store.
description: For eight years, Peter Coles had an economists dream job at Harvard Business School.

title: Venture Communism: How China Is Building a Start-Up Boom
description: HANGZHOU, China  In Dream Town, a collection of boxy office buildings on the gritty edge of this historic city, one tiny company is developing a portable 3-D printer. Another takes orders for traditional Chinese massages by smartphone. They are just two of the 710 start-ups being nurtured here.

title: Renovation Restores the Luster to Cartier Flagship
description: Enlightened urbanism is not the first thing that comes to mind when a prestigious jeweler owned by a multinational luxury goods conglomerate throws open its doors. Yet with the reopening this week of the Cartier flagship on Fifth Avenue, after a renovation of more than two years, it is the city itself that reclaims a gem.

title: Serving Stylish Looks at the U.S. Open
description: Tennis devotees brought their fashion game courtside.

title: Chers Latest Road Show? The Campaign Trail
description: Chers first brush with politics was an act of teenage civil disobedience. It was right before the election of 1960. And she came home one day horrified to discover that her mother and stepfather had festooned their house in Hollywood with Richard Nixon paraphernalia.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from Bamian Province in Afghanistan to the Silver Gull Beach Club in Queens.

title: Rare Harmony as China and U.S. Commit to Climate Deal
description: HANGZHOU, China  President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China formally committed the worlds two largest economies to the Paris climate agreement here on Saturday, cementing their partnership on climate change and offering a rare display of harmony in a relationship that has become increasingly discordant.

title: Narcos Season 2, Episode 2: The Legend vs. the Monster
description: The baptism sequence in The Godfather is one of the most celebrated montages in cinema, a breathtaking assertion of power from Michael Corleone as he gains control over the Corleone crime family and puts down threats from the other four New York mob syndicates. Everyone remembers the sequence for its sharp juxtaposition of serene religious ritual and startling violence, as Michael, the once-reluctant successor to his fathers business, handles the job with efficient, cold-blooded aplomb. What tends to be forgotten is the thematic significance of the baptism itself, the sick association between Catholic rites and a childs passage into a family of unrepentant sinners. Divorced from any larger meaning, it can be chalked up as a tribute to gangland ruthlessness.

title: A Little Variety
description: VARIETY PUZZLES  This weeks puzzles include:

title: What Do You Know About Mother Teresa and Other Saints?
description: Mother Teresa, one of the 20th centurys most visible religious figures, was canonized on Sunday. Test your knowledge of Mother Teresa and the lives of other saints.

title: Farhads and Mikes Week in Tech: What? No More iPhone Headphone Jack?
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. This week, they needed extra help and roped in new tech reporter Daisuke Wakabayashi.

title: Discord Over Lobby Remodeling
description: Last year, our co-op board selected a design firm to renovate the two lobbies in our building. Shareholders were shown two conceptual renderings with a cost estimate of $500,000 to $750,000. Ten months later, the managing agent sent shareholders a letter telling us that the project would now cost $1.2 million and we could view the updated renderings on request. Many shareholders think  the process has been autocratic and opaque, and are upset about the skyrocketing costs. What are our rights, and what can we do to find out what happened  and to start a conversation about lowering the costs?

title: A Sharp Increase In Sunny Day Flooding
description: Global warming and rising seas are increasing the amount of tidal flooding on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.

title: Flooding of Coast, Caused by Global Warming, Has Already Begun
description: NORFOLK, Va.  Huge vertical rulers are sprouting beside low spots in the streets here, so people can judge if the tidal floods that increasingly inundate their roads are too deep to drive through.

title: Which Tennis Ball is in Use? It Makes a Difference
description: At the United States Open this year, conversations have tended to focus on the players and the courts (the new roof, the new Grandstand, the new noise). Discussions about equipment are usually about a players new racket or the impact of synthetic strings.

title: Confrontations Flare as Obamas Traveling Party Reaches China
description: HANGZHOU, China  Air Force One had a bumpy landing in Hangzhou on Saturday, but it was nothing compared with what happened after the plane rolled to a stop.

title: The Baseball Hall of Fames New Era: Digital
description: Cal Ripken Jr. has been a Hall of Famer since 2007, when he was 46 years old. At first, when he would visit the exhibits and tour the archives, Ripken was more interested in the equipment, the tools of the trade he had mastered as an ironman infielder for the Baltimore Orioles. That has changed with time.

title: Premier Leagues Wealth Often Subsidizes Clubs Across the Channel
description: Suddenly, Le Havre A.C. has choices. As is the case with most teams in Frances second division, money is usually tight for Arnaud Tanguy, Le Havres chief executive. There are salaries to be paid and bills to be settled. Tanguys job, more often than not, is to make ends meet.

title: A Nightmare Presidential Campaign Ad That Stayed in the Vault
description: Forty years ago next month, the two major-party nominees, President Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter, the former governor of Georgia, were almost tied in the polls. Mr. Fords media team, Doug Bailey and John Deardourff, argued for taking a chance on a television commercial that would infuse the Ford campaign with the vote-getting power of emotion and history.

title: A Warrior Against Junk Mail at Yahoo Looks Out for Mom, Too
description: Elizabeth Zwicky, 51, is an anti-spam architect at Yahoo in Sunnyvale, Calif.

title: Response of Philippines President to Fatal Blast Raises Fears
description: MANILA  President Rodrigo Dutertes declaration of a state of lawlessness in the Philippines after a blast that left at least 14 dead raised fears on Saturday that it could lead to a curtailment of basic freedoms.

title: A Temp Agency That Gives Ex-Inmates a Job, and a Ride to Work
description: In early August, Mark Eason was released from the Charleston Correctional Facility in Maine, where he had served eight months for drug trafficking. Given that it wasnt his first felony incarceration, he knew his employment options would be limited.

title: What Are Sanctuary Cities?
description: Behind the term that Donald J. Trump and others are talking about.

title: Peter Naylor: A Sun-Drenched Cubicle, but Hardly the French Riviera
description: Sunshine and students

title: Oklahoma Orders Shutdown of Wells After Record-Tying Earthquake
description: Oklahoma officials on Saturday ordered oil and gas operators to shut down three dozen wastewater disposal wells following a 5.6-magnitude earthquake that tied a record as the strongest in state history.

title: Libya: Unified Against ISIS, Fragmented After
description: CAIRO  Martin Kobler, the United Nations envoy to Libya, used to regularly joke that the only functioning government in Libya was the Islamic State. Unlike the countrys other three governments, it not only held territory but ran the courts, provided services to the public and ensured security  however harsh its rule.

title: Variety: The Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  This was a tough one for me, but I was able to crack Emily Coxs and Henry Rathvons acrostic with a few gimmes and a lot of persistence.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Tropical Storm Hermine Leaves Trail of Power Failures
description: The remnants of what had been Hurricane Hermine swept up and along the Eastern Seaboard on Saturday, disrupting the holiday weekend in much of the coastal South while preparing to bedevil the Northeast well into the week.

title: Where Has Hillary Clinton Been? Ask the Ultrarich
description: At a private fund-raiser Tuesday night at a waterfront Hamptons estate, Hillary Clinton danced alongside Jimmy Buffett, Jon Bon Jovi and Paul McCartney, and joined in a singalong finale to Hey Jude.

title: Depicting a Country Sitting on the Brink
description: In the first two ads for Donald J. Trump in the general election campaign, his message and style have closely followed his stump speech: a dark, ominous and fearful portrait of the future under Hillary Clinton, and proclamations of all that the country has to gain by supporting him. His first ad focused on immigration, and his new ad, titled Two Americas: Economy, is about jobs.

title: Myanmar Peace Talks End With No Breakthrough but Some Hope
description: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar  A peace conference convened to find a way to end decades of ethnic conflict in Myanmar concluded Saturday without any breakthroughs, but the countrys leader contended that it was a step toward resolving intractable disputes.

title: Israel Seeking Police Recruits: Eager, and Arab
description: KIRYAT ATTA, Israel  The roll call was startling for a class preparing to take Israels police academy exam: Mohammad Hreib, Ghadeer Ghadeer, Munis Huwari and Arafat Hassanein, dressed like a hipster and named after the Palestinian leader, whom most Israeli Jews view as a terrorist.

title: A Bold Attempt to Redefine Dissidence in Cuba
description: Dissident is a loaded word in Cuba, a label used to discredit and punish. Those who have embraced the term can be shut out of public jobs and are often subjected to arbitrary detentions and beatings.

title: Free Speech on Campus
description: Reactions to a deans letter against shielding students from controversial or offensive ideas

title: When Police Unions Impede Justice
description: Across the country, municipal governments have signed contracts with police unions including provisions that shield officers from punishment for brutal behavior as well as from legitimate complaints by the citizens they are supposed to serve.

title: The Czars Return to Crimea
description: YALTA, Crimea  My quest to unearth my Russian roots brings me regularly to Crimea, where my ancestors cultivated a vineyard along the spectacular southern coast for generations until the 1917 Revolution.

title: Youre How Old? Well Be in Touch
description: It might not seem that Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump have much in common. But they share something important with each other and with a whole lot of their fellow citizens. Both are job seekers. And at ages 68 and 70, respectively, theyre part of a large group of Americans who are radically upending the concept of retirement.

title: For a Long Life, Retire to Manhattan
description: In his famous essay about New York, E. B. White distinguished among three cities and three types of New Yorkers. The first two  the city belonging to people born here, and that of commuters who work here by day and leave by night  were, he said, less compelling than the third, the city of final destination for those who come here in hope and nervousness.

title: Taylor Sheridan
description: Taylor Sheridan is an actor turned screenwriter who wrote the screenplay for this summers sleeper hit Hell or High Water.

title: The Candidates Final-Stretch Playbook
description: Labor Day weekend has always had a particular resonance in American politics as the official start of the sprint to Election Day, celebrated by rallies, marches and lakeside picnics.

title: What Religion Would Jesus Belong To?
description: ONE puzzle of the world is that religions often dont resemble their founders.

title: Political Correctness and Its Real Enemies
description: NEW HAVEN  Last November, Scott C. Johnston, a 1982 Yale graduate, was attending a conference organized by the William F. Buckley Jr. Program at his alma mater when student protesters disrupted it. Soon after, he watched an online video of a black Yale student hurling imprecations at a professor who headed her residential college for failing to create a place of comfort and home.

title: How to Tell a Mother Her Child Is Dead
description: Philadelphia  First you get your coat. I dont care if you dont remember where you left it, you find it. If there was a lot of blood you ask someone to go quickly to the basement to get you a new set of scrubs. You put on your coat and you go into the bathroom. You look in the mirror and you say it. You use the mothers name and you use her childs name. You may not adjust this part in any way.

title: Americas Shocking Maternal Deaths
description: The rate at which women die during pregnancy or shortly after childbirth has fallen sharply in many nations as maternal care has improved. The United States  and particularly Texas  is a glaring exception.

title: The Big Gay Sway
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  On a sweltering afternoon in late August, Stephanie Murphy, a Democrat running for Congress against a longtime Republican incumbent, stole a half-hour from a crammed schedule for something that grieving residents of this metropolitan area still routinely do: She visited Pulse nightclub, where a gunman ended 49 lives in June.

title: Take Back the House, Democrats. Please.
description: Ithaca, N.Y.  RECENT polls put Hillary Clinton slightly ahead of Donald Trump in traditionally Republican states like Georgia and close even in South Carolina. Should she make the serious investment necessary to put those states in play for real? Or should she ignore them and invest the same money in traditional battleground states? If the only concern were to minimize Mr. Trumps chances of winning, it would be an easy call: Caution would dictate focusing exclusively on swing states.

title: Deliveryman Sues Ex-Mayor David Dinkins Over Collision
description: A bicycle deliveryman is suing David N. Dinkins, claiming that the former mayor of New York was driving a car in June that struck and injured him, according to court documents.

title: BBC Soap The Archers, Pushing 70, Generates New Buzz With Abuse Thread
description: LONDON  In the rural village of Ambridge on the British radio show The Archers, nothing much changes, and listeners like it that way.

title: Venezuelan President Is Chased by Angry Protesters
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Nicols Maduro was chased at a routine political event by a crowd of angry protesters banging on pots and yelling that they were hungry, just days after thousands of Venezuelans took to the streets to call for his ouster, local news media reported on Saturday.

title: New Afghan Attorney General Seeks Justice in System Rife With Graft
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In a corner office at one of the most corrupt institutions of the Afghan government, the countrys new attorney general has been tasked with actually delivering justice.

title: Short Story, Shorter Response
description: To the Editor:

title: A Ranger, a Field of Wildflowers and the Retelling of Flight 93
description: SHANKSVILLE, Pa.  Just another Thursday, and the morning mix includes leather-vested bikers from New Jersey, Amish visitors from Pennsylvania and a few children adjusting to a park not intended for play. They settle onto benches for the 11 oclock retelling.

title: Seeking Support and Invoking Faith, Donald Trump Visits a Black Church for the First Time
description: DETROIT  Donald J. Trump, who has campaigned for president as a blunt provocateur, dismissing complaints of racial insensitivity as political correctness, took an uncharacteristic step on Saturday: He visited a black church for the first time and tried to blend in.

title: The Future of Wealth
description: To the Editor:

title: Underwater Property
One by One
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Tom McCoy is back with a theme that pays homage to Sam Ezerskys Aug. 14 diagramless crossword. Kind of.

title: Houston Topples No. 3 Oklahoma, Showing Last Years Success Was No Fluke
description: HOUSTON  Nearly midway through the third quarter, it was already a moral victory for No. 15 Houston in its opening game versus No. 3 Oklahoma.

title: Nick Kyrgioss Explosive Forehand
description: Nick Kyrgios of Australia combines athleticism and a distinctive technique to deliver one of the most explosive forehands in the current game.

title: Mother Teresa Is Made a Saint by Pope Francis
description: VATICAN CITY  She was known throughout the world as Mother Teresa, considered a saint by many for her charitable work among the poorest of the worlds poor. On Sunday morning, Pope Francis officially bestowed that title at her canonization ceremony in St. Peters Square.

title: Far-Right Overtakes Angela Merkels Bloc in Her Home State
description: BERLIN  Voters in Chancellor Angela Merkels political home state delivered her a stinging rebuke on Sunday, propelling a far-right party to second place in the state legislature, ahead of her center-right bloc.

title: Beat Novak Djokovic? Kyle Edmund Will Give It His Best Shot
description: The first question for any opponent of Novak Djokovic at this United States Open is obvious enough: Do you actually intend to play a full, best-of-five-set match against the defending champion?

title: On the Trail: Week of Aug. 28
description: In the final week of August, Donald Trump made a surprise visit to Mexico, and Hillary Clinton continued to raise funds.

title: Jordan Spieth Is Chasing a FedEx Cup First: A Repeat Title
description: NORTON, Mass.  Jordan Spieth checked in with his second straight 68 on Saturday to stand five shots off the lead at the Deutsche Bank Championship. He is vying for his third win of the season while also positioning himself to do what no one has done in the nine-year history of the FedEx Cup: Repeat as the Cup champion.

title: Test Reveals That Yankees Chad Green Has a Sprained Elbow Ligament
description: BALTIMORE  The Yankees may need a new addition to their rotation even as they find themselves in the middle of the American League wild-card race.

title: Serena Williams Sails Past Match Record in Grand Slam Tournament
description: Serena Williams had an image in mind when she designed her current tennis outfit. The fluorescent pink sleeves, she said, make her think of the superhero characters Wonder Woman and Superwoman.

title: Letters to the Editor: Criticism of Kaepernicks Anthem Protest Exposes Weakness
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Yankees, Stifled Again, Fail to Gain Ground in Wild-Card Race
description: BALTIMORE  Before Saturdays game, Yankees first baseman Mark Teixeira discussed playing at Camden Yards for what was most likely the last time in his career. Teixeira was born in Annapolis, Md., and went to high school in Baltimore.

title: Looking the Part of a Mets Starter, Robert Gsellman Performs
description: To pitch in the Mets rotation these days, it seems, being at least 6 feet 4 inches and having hair down to the shoulders is a necessity. Jacob deGrom is 6-4 with flowing locks, and Noah Syndergaard is two inches taller and also has long hair. So in that sense, Robert Gsellman, also 6-4, fit right in before he threw his first pitch in the major leagues.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Its as if the country was being attacked along every border, simultaneously. Its a slow, gradual attack, but it threatens the safety and security of the United States.

title: Hip Injury Forces Kyrgios to Withdraw; Journeyman Challenges Murray
description: Nick Kyrgios could not jump and could not move forward, and the hip injury he had struggled with through his first two matches at the United States Open had finally caught up with him.

title: Paul Betz, Benjamin Coleman
description: Paul Jared Betz and Benjamin Gulick Coleman are to be married Sept. 4 at the Metropolitan Building, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. The Rev. Wayne Zschech, a Lutheran minister, is to officiate.

title: Brittany Piehl, Adam Miller
description: Brittany Lynn Piehl and Adam Andrew Miller are to be married Sept. 4 at the Carondelet House, an event space in Los Angeles. Sophie Speth, a friend of the bride who was ordained by American Marriage Ministries for the occasion, is to officiate.

title: Dayo Olopade, Walter Lamberson
description: Temidayo Folasade Olopade and Walter Ramn-Manuel Lamberson are to be married Sept. 4 at the El Dorado Hotel in Santa Fe, N.M. The Rev. Kara Wagner Sherer, an Episcopal priest, is to lead an Anglican ceremony incorporating Nigerian and Mexican elements.

title: Melissa Hoppert, Michael Lucci
description: Melissa Hoppert and Michael Scott Lucci were married Sept. 3 at the National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Bruce Hoppert, who is an uncle of the bride and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Samuel Spector, Glenn Greilsamer
description: Samuel Mathew Spector and Glenn Jason Greilsamer were married Aug. 29 on the rooftop of their building in New York. Amy Komorowski, a friend of the couple who became a minister with American Marriage Ministries for the occasion, officiated.

title: Mitzi Avanzado, Ian Cohen
description: Mitzi Claire Avanzado, the daughter of Violet Bernardino and Michael L. Bernardino of Robbinsville, N.J., is to be married Sept. 4 to Dr. Ian Jeffrey Cohen, a son of Leslie R. Cohen and Barry M. Cohen of Clifton, N.J. Rabbi Lisa Rubin is to officiate at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

title: Allison Bormel, Aaron Ament
description: Allison Fran Bormel, the daughter of Aileen S. Bormel and David B. Bormel of Owings Mills, Md., is to be married Sept. 4 to Aaron Samuel Ament, the son of Sue Ament and Mark S. Ament of Louisville, Ky. Rabbi Jay R. Goldstein is to officiate at the Frederick Douglass-Isaac Myers Maritime Park in Baltimore.

title: Melanie Simonson, Steven Evans
description: Melanie Rose Simonson, a daughter of Jane S. Simonson and Dr. Peter T. Simonson of Suffern, N.Y., is to be married Sept. 4 to Steven Alexander Evans, a son of Dr. Steven Evans of Upper St. Clair, Pa., and the late Dr. Cynthia A. Duarte-Evans. Rabbi Zachary A. Fredman is to officiate at the Estate at Florentine Gardens, an event space in River Vale, N.J., with the Rev. Richard L. Freeman Sr. taking part.

title: Emma Sokoloff-Rubin, Samuel Purdy
description: Emma Rachel Sokoloff-Rubin, a daughter of Dr. Shoshana R. Sokoloff and Jeffrey W. Rubin of Amherst, Mass., is to be married Sept. 4 to Samuel Russakoff Purdy, a son of Dale Russakoff and Matthew Purdy of Montclair, N.J. Rabbi and Cantor Alan H. Sokoloff, an uncle of the bride, is to lead the ceremony at Lighthouse Point Park in New Haven.

title: Marla Diakow, Christian Sanchez
description: Dr. Marla Naomi Diakow, a daughter of Renee F. Laffer and Nicholas T. Diakow of Port Washington, N.Y., is to be married Sept. 4 to Christian Garibaldi Sanchez, a son of the late Rosa A. Rijo and the late Jose G. Sanchez of Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, at the Woodbury Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y. Rabbi Frank Tamburello is to officiate.

title: Missy Mlotek, Zach Schonbrun
description: Marissa Mlotek and Zach Schonbrun are to be married Sept. 4 at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J. Associate Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the United States Supreme Court, who is a cousin of the groom, is to officiate, with Rabbi Avram Mlotek, a cousin of the bride, to take part.

title: Kateri Allard, Arash Salavitabar
description: Kateri Laurel Allard and Dr. Arash Salavitabar were married Sept. 3 in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Pamela Fazzio, a minister ordained by American Marriage Ministries, officiated at the Canfield Casino.

title: Kelly Durels, Terence Sullivan
description: Kelly Martelle Durels, the daughter of Elizabeth P. Durels and Steven M. Durels of New York, was married Sept. 3 to Terence Sean Sullivan Jr., a son of Annette L. Sullivan and Mr. Sullivan of Carmel, Ind. The Rev. Kenneth Brannon, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Trail Creek Cabin, a lodge in Sun Valley, Idaho.

title: Eliav Barr, Paul Koulogeorge
description: Dr. Eliav Barr and Paul Matthew Koulogeorge are to be married Sept. 4 at the Calistoga Ranch in Calistoga, Calif., by Dr. Brian Keith, a friend of the couple who was ordained by the American Marriage Ministries to officiate.

title: Molly Pam, Adam Cohen
description: Molly Stroud Pam and Adam David Cohen are to be married Sept. 4 at a horse ranch in Glen Ellen, Calif. Rabbi Lee T. Bycel, an uncle of the bride, is to officiate.

title: Julie Rapaport, Greg Levine
description: Julie Tripler Rapaport and Greg Levine are to be married Sept. 4 at Kamp Kohut, a summer camp in Oxford, Me., that is owned by the brides parents, Lisa M. Tripler and Daniel Rapaport of Cape Elizabeth, Me. Benjamin Samit, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.

title: Michelle Kobler, Yiwey Shieh
description: Michelle Thaung Kobler and Dr. Yiwey Shieh were married Sept. 1 in Washington. Judge Judith Bartnoff of the District of Columbia Superior Court officiated in her chambers.

title: Tobah Aukland, Adam Peck
description: Tobah Joy Aukland, a daughter of Esther Samra and David R. Aukland of Tarrytown, N.Y., is to be married there Sept. 4 to Adam Bresler Peck, the son of Elizabeth B. Peck and David C. Peck of Weston, Fla. Cantor George Mordecai is to officiate at the Lodge at Hudson Harbor, an event space.

title: Jessica Barr, Joel Albers
description: Jessica Lauren Barr is to be married Sept. 4 to Joel Henry Albers. Rabbi Steven Chester is to officiate at the Detroit Opera House.

title: Mari Armstrong-Hough, Jacob Remes
description: Mari Jean Armstrong-Hough and Jacob Aaron Carliner Remes are to be married Sept. 4 at Edgerton Park in New Haven by A. Mitchell Fraas, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister.

title: Jennifer Holmes, Alexander Tischenko
description: Jennifer Amelia Holmes, the daughter of Marian Smith Holmes of Washington and Steven A. Holmes of Columbia, Md., was married Sept. 2 to Alexander George Tischenko, the son of Mari M. Tischenko and Dr. George J. Tischenko of Orinda, Calif. The ceremony, held in the Bishops Garden at the National Cathedral in Washington, was led by Kwame A. Holmes, a cousin of the bride who received permission from the District of Columbia to officiate.

title: Anna Ross, William Goldman
description: Dr. Anna Louise Ross and William Ira Goldman are to be married Sept. 4 by Rabbi Gary Berenson at the Etz Chaim synagogue in Portland, Me.

title: Courtney Galiano, Jonah Platt
description: Courtney Galiano, the daughter of Toniann Galiano and James V. Galiano of Dix Hills, N.Y., is to be married Sept. 4, to Jonah Platt, a son of Julie Beren Platt and Marc E. Platt of Los Angeles. Rabbi David Wolpe is to officiate with assistance from Rabbi Shlomo Riskin at the Saddlerock Ranch in Malibu, Calif.

title: Susanna Fried, David Cohen
description: Susanna Rachel Fried, a daughter of Gigi Panush Fried and Samuel P. Fried of Columbus, Ohio, is to be married Sept. 4 to David Zachary Cohen, the son of Louise S. Cohen and Robert A. Cohen of Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi Harold Berman is to officiate at the Columbus Museum of Art with Rabbi Jeffrey Segelman taking part.

title: Nadine Chalmers, Erica Colligan
description: Nadine Kauder Chalmers and Dr. Erica Ann Colligan are to be married Sept. 4 at the Buffalo Yacht Club in Buffalo. Rabbi Adam Scheldt is to officiate.

title: Maab Ibrahim, Mahmood El-Gasim
description: Maab Suleiman Ibrahim, a daughter of Mariam Abdelmahmoud Ibrahim and Suleiman O. Ibrahim of Richmond, Va., is to be married Sept. 4 to Dr. Mahmood El-Gasim, the son of Nuha Ali and Dr. Mohamed El-Gasim of Gilbert, Ariz. Imam Abdullah T. Antepli is to officiate at Foxchase Manor, an event space in Manassas, Va.

title: Lauren Phillips, Daniel Fogelman
description: Cantor Lauren Ruth Phillips, the daughter of Rebecca L. Phillips and Dr. Malcolm C. Phillips of Great Neck, N.Y., is to be married Sept. 4 to Daniel Steven Fogelman, a son of Annette Fogelman and Mitchell Fogelman of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi David B. Cohen is to officiate, with Cantor Benjie E. Schiller participating, at Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle.

title: Erica Hicks, Donald Anderson
description: Erica Tennil Hicks and Donald Lyndel Anderson are to be married Sept. 4 at the Cruz Building, an events space in Miami. The Rev. Rudolf Daniels, a Baptist pastor, will officiate.

title: Christine Powell, Alexander Duncan
description: Christine Renee Powell, a daughter of Regina A. Powell and Peter J. Powell of Voorhees, N.J., was married Sept. 3 to Alexander Burns Duncan, the son of Cherie Burns and Richard L. Duncan of Taos, N.M. Clarence H. Gifford III, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the home of the grooms parents.

title: David Wong, Dennis Yu
description: David Franklin Wong and Dennis Che-Wei Yu were married Aug. 30 at the New York Marriage Bureau by Edwina Townes, a staff member in the office of the New York City Clerk. On Sept. 3, the couple held a second ceremony in Copenhagen for family and friends, led by Katherine Taylor Johnson, a friend of Mr. Yu.

title: Corrections: September 4, 2016
description: METROPOLITAN

title: Tennis as Far as the Eye Can See
description: In an age of splintered attention and multi-everything-all-at-once, why should anyone, even a tennis fan, have to limit himself to one distraction at a time? Here was Jake Snorsky, for instance, standing atop his seat far above a cluster of courts at the United States Open the other day, able to watch seven potentially interesting things at once.

title: Homes That Sold for $900,000 or More
description: 233 East 17th Street, Landmark 17, Gramercy Park Area

title: Raghuram Rajan, Indias Departing Central Banker, Has a New Warning
description: MUMBAI, India  Three years before the 2008 global financial crisis, an Indian economist named Raghuram G. Rajan presciently warned a skeptical audience of top economic thinkers that excessive risk threatened the entire global financial system.

title: Narcos Season 2, Episode 3: A Flawed Endgame
description: You and I are like the snake and the cat. If the snake has the chance, it will kill the cat. If the cat has the chance, it will kill the snake. But there are times when they see a big rat and they both want to eat that.

title: U.S. Presses for Truce in Syria, With Its Larger Policy on Pause
description: HANGZHOU, China  The image of a 5-year-old Syrian boy, dazed and bloodied after being rescued from an airstrike on rebel-held Aleppo, reverberated around the world last month, a harrowing reminder that five years after civil war broke out there, Syria remains a charnel house.

title: Stolen, Sold and Savored: Ice Cream Is a Hot Commodity in Manhattan
description: A particular wave of crime has yet to crest, a pattern of theft in Manhattan that has penetrated the safest of neighborhoods.

title: 1941: Submarine Attacks U.S. Destroyer in Atlantic
description: WASHINGTON  An unsuccessful submarine attack on an American destroyer, the U.S.S. Greer, somewhere in the Atlantic en route to Iceland, was reported tonight by the Navy Department. Several torpedoes missed their mark, according to the commander of the destroyer, who immediately ordered the firing of depth charges. The result of the dropping of the TNT-filled ashcans is not known. The Greer was on her way to Iceland, most distant outpost in the United States hemisphere defense zone, with mail for the American forces which are relieving British troops there. Nothing could be learned from the Navy Department as to the nationality of the submarine making the attack.  New York Herald Tribune, Sept. 5, 1941

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Factors That Will Sway Presidential Election
description: The United States presidential campaign seems to have been going on for an eternity. The Labor Day holiday on Monday is the start of the final stretch.

title: Heng on China Hosting the G-20 Meeting
description: Despite a wealth of controversial issues, China seems determined to deliver a non-confrontational, even uneventful summit.

title: Before G-20, Obama Tries to Smooth Things Over With Turkey
description: HANGZHOU, China  President Obama sought on Sunday to heal a rift with Turkey, expressing his wholehearted support for its president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, in the wake of a failed effort to oust him and promising Americas help in bringing the coup plotters to justice.

title: Letter From a Bahraini Jail
description: RIFFA, Bahrain  I write this from a Bahraini jail cell where I have been detained, largely in isolation, since the beginning of summer. This is not new to me: I have been here before, from 2012 to 2014, in 2015, and now again, all because of my work as a human rights defender.

title: Hermine Swirls Off East Coast, but Threat Eases
description: ATLANTA  The powerful post-tropical cyclone Hermine lurked off the Eastern Seaboard on Sunday, and its evolving path made the storm more likely to be a bother than a threat.

title: 1916: Tristan Da Cunha to Receive Mail
description: LONDON  One hundred and three British subjects, self-exiled on a lonely isle in the South Atlantic, are eagerly awaiting their Treasure Ship, which will steam from London in a few days, says the Weekly Dispatch. They are the inhabitants of Tristan da Cunha, and it is so far off the beaten track that they have not heard officially from the Motherland for ten years, but now a ship has been chartered to visit the island and take mails. The Colonial Office and other friends of the islanders are sending them comforts and stores, and at the offices of the Crown Agents for the Colonies (who are packing and dispatching the goods free) there have been busy scenes the past few days. The gifts are chiefly of a practical value, and include soap, which is greatly in demand in Tristan da Cunha, rope, dungaree for making clothes, boots, rice, oars, medical supplies and sails.The women exiles are not forgotten, and a good supply of hairpins and other necessities will bring joy to the belles of Tristan. The only flag the islanders are said to have to prove their allegiance to the Empire is a red ensign, and the Colonial Office is sending out a brand new Union Jack. There are sure to be hearty cheers in the lonely settlement when the new flag arrives and is unfurled.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 1, 1916

title: Tim Kaine Compares Donald Trumps Comments on Russian Hacking to Watergate Scandal
description: Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia on Sunday compared Donald J. Trumps encouragement of Russia to hack Hillary Clintons emails to the Watergate scandal, which led to President Richard M. Nixons resignation.

title: Business as Usual for Alabama Against a Nonconference Power
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  No. 1 Alabama must have been disoriented Saturday night when it struggled at the outset against No. 20 Southern California in the season opener for both teams.

title: Nicolas Sarkozy Mounts What He Hopes Is a Comeback in France
description: PARIS  He was beaten in the last presidential election, his presidential term was considered a failure, and he has been the subject of numerous judicial inquiries. In most other political systems, he would be a has-been. Yet in a France under terrorist threat, Nicolas Sarkozy may be the man of the moment in a presidential race picking up steam.

title: A George Carlin Special Too Raw After Sept. 11 Resurfaces Now
description: On Sept. 10, 2001, George Carlin, the greatest political comic in history if measured only by stand-up specials, recorded a bracing hour of social commentary for his new HBO special. The next day, he shelved it.

title: Jose Reyes Raises the Mets Spirits and Hopes
description: A black sign hangs above the exit of the Mets clubhouse. In white lettering, it reads, Do Your Thing. Mets players wear blue and black T-shirts with the slogan Has Tu Diligencia, which carries a similar message in Spanish.

title: Labour Party Is Poised to Back Jeremy Corbyn Again, Even if Britain Isnt
description: LONDON  A recent semi-scandal over seats on a train illuminates the deep problems of Britains Labour Party. Its left-wing leader, Jeremy Corbyn, made a video sitting on the floor of a train, calling for the renationalization of the railways while claiming that there were no empty seats and that travelers were ram-packed.

title: Vin Scullys Farewell Should Be Heard Far and Wide
description: Vin Scully will conclude his 67-season run as the voice of the Dodgers on Oct. 2 in a game against the Giants at AT&T Park in San Francisco. But it should be more than a local event for Scullys fans in the Los Angeles area. When baseballs greatest announcer retires, it is a national occasion.

title: Rolling Coal at the Fair
description: Spewing black smoke is part of the allure of pulling events at county fairs, where drivers in modified vehicles compete to see how far they can pull a heavy sled.

title: The Trucks That Intentionally Spew Smoke
description: Coal rollers alter their diesel trucks so they put out thick black smoke, sometimes in the direction of joggers, cyclists and hybrid cars.

title: Hollywoods Summer of Extremes: Megahits, Superflops and Little Else
description: LOS ANGELES  Sequel fatigue does not fully explain it. Nor does an overload of mega-budget event movies. A spate of terrible films? Yes, but thats not entirely the explanation, either.

title: Political Intrigue in Israel Leaves Commuters Without Trains for a Day
description: JERUSALEM  In an abrupt resurrection of Israels Sabbath wars, a key train line was disabled for repairs on Sunday, snarling tens of thousands of Israeli commuters and soldiers returning to base in traffic jams at the start of the workweek  all because of a political spat involving Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, his transportation minister and their ultra-Orthodox coalition partners.

title: Review: Viktor Is Vintage Pina Bausch, Complete With Gravedigger
description: PARIS  Death is omnipresent. The stage is an enormous grave, with 20-foot-high mud walls forming cliffs around its perimeters. At the top of the walls, a man slowly and steadily shovels earth into the huge chasm below. The gravedigger shovels for all three hours of Pina Bauschs Viktor, a rarely seen 1986 work, which the Tanztheater Wuppertal is performing at the Thtre du Chtelet here through Sept. 12.

title: Review: Twelfth Night, Anything Goes in Love and Shakespeare
description: Everybodys pretty much crazy in love in Shakespeares Twelfth Night, so it seems natural to include a shout-out to the Beyonc song of that name in the contemporary musical adaptation of the play that finishes a brief Labor Day weekend run on Monday night at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

title: Razor Girl, a Tale of Kidnappers, Reality TV Stars and Dodgy Seafood
description: Carl Hiaasens irresistible Razor Girl meets his usual sky-high standards for elegance, craziness and mike-drop humor. But this election-year novel is exceptionally timely, too. It illustrates the dog-whistle effects of bigotry that take the form of entertainment, with a plot that revolves around a Duck Dynasty-type reality show, the sermons delivered by one of its stars and a crazed fan who decides to follow what he thinks are the stars teachings. Mr. Hiaasen  and probably only Mr. Hiaasen  could weave this into a book thats still so funny.

title: Review: In 800 Words, a Widowed Father of Teenagers Uproots the Family
description: The Australian drama series 800 Words will remind you in one way of Sex and the City. Its hero, George Turner (Erik Thomson), writes a column for a Sydney newspaper  its exactly 800 words long  and like Carrie Bradshaw, he reads snippets of it aloud as narration. Unlike her, he actually reads them onscreen, sitting at his laptop and occasionally looking into the camera, as if to make sure were listening.

title: How the Fight for a National African-American Museum Was Won
description: Eleven years ago, Lonnie G. Bunch III was a museum director with no museum.

title: Muslim Gathering Laments a Normalization of Bigotry
description: ROSEMONT, Ill.  An imam of a mosque in New York City and his associate shot dead while strolling following afternoon prayers. A presidential candidate calling for Muslims to be barred from entering the United States. Muslim women harassed and physically attacked in Chicago while walking to their car.

title: Site on a Rose
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  This statement will fall unreservedly into the category of first-world problems, but there are few shopping trips that I dread more than trying to buy a pair of JEANS.

title: The Playwright Lindsey Ferrentino Wins the Kesselring Prize
description: Lindsey Ferrentino has won the National Arts Clubs 2016 Kesselring Prize for her play Ugly Lies the Bone. Since 1980, the prize has been awarded to a playwright on the verge of recognition, and now comes with a $25,000 award.

title: Yankees Avoid a Sweep and Sustain Their Playoff Hopes
description: BALTIMORE  After a second straight shutout loss at Camden Yards against the Baltimore Orioles on Saturday, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said that Sundays game would be perhaps the teams most important of the year.

title: Rolling Coal in Diesel Trucks, to Rebel and Provoke
description: MONTROSE, Colo.  There is a new menace on Americas roads: diesel truck drivers who soup up their engines and remove their emissions controls to roll coal, or belch black smoke, at pedestrians, cyclists and unsuspecting Prius drivers.

title: Clash of Titans? Opponents of Pier 55 Have Secret Backer, Media Mogul Says
description: In their quest to build a huge new cultural pier on the West Side of Manhattan, the Hudson River Park Trust and Barry Diller, the media mogul who is paying for it, have faced one seemingly intractable opponent: the City Club of New York, a little-known civic group founded in 1892 that was all but dead a few years ago. But it has gone back to court repeatedly in the last year to stop the project.

title: Gun Control Groups Divide Their Loyalties in Senate Races
description: GLENOLDEN, Pa.  Senator Patrick J. Toomey hears a lot of things he would rather not these days, like the taunts of protesters outside a body shop here about his (actually nonexistent) relationship with Donald J. Trump.

title: Lucrative Book Deals Might Finance the Obamas Post-White House Life
description: WASHINGTON  After he is out of the White House, President Obama has said that he wants to become a venture capitalist, own part of an N.B.A. franchise and avoid taking off his shoes during security screenings at commercial airports.

title: Rafael Nadal Upset by Lucas Pouille in Fourth Round of U.S. Open
description: After four grueling hours spent fending off a relentless adversary who refused to submit, Rafael Nadal saw the ball exactly where he wanted it, practically on a platter and ready to be plucked.

title: Egypts Christians Say They Are at a Breaking Point
description: MINYA, Egypt  The Egyptian government has appointed Imam Mahmoud Gomaa, a Muslim cleric, to keep the peace between Christians and Muslims in this corner of upper Egypt. Everything is good, he insisted in an interview, citing Christian participation in his official peace-building initiative.

title: This Street Is the Whole World
description: Dear Diary:

title: Team Canada Offers Lessons for the Future, From 1972
description: The members of Team Canada 1972 are among the few hockey squads in the history of the country to have both a deep, emotional connection to their citizens and a legacy that stretches beyond their borders. But until recently, the surviving players had lacked a platform to share their story.

title: Libertarian Gary Johnson Polls at 10 Percent. Who Are His Supporters?
description: Gary Johnson, the Libertarian candidate for president, may be on track to win more votes than any third-party candidate in 20 years, if current polling holds up.

title: Jerry Heller, Music Manager Who Promoted N.W.A and Gangsta Rap, Dies at 75
description: Jerry Heller, a veteran music manager who helped introduce N.W.A to the masses and promoted gangsta rap to a mainstream audience, died on Friday in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 75.

title: PGA Tour Rookie Smylie Kaufman Strives to Aid Louisiana Flood Victims
description: NORTON, Mass.  The elite of the PGA Tour, the 30 fortunate players who qualify for the season-ending Tour Championship, will have a week of rest to prepare for the Sept. 22-25 tournament.

title: Results of Obama Voter Focus Groups on Hillary Clinton
description: Hillary Clintons difficulties with young African-Americans were laid bare in four damning focus groups conducted for a handful of progressive organizations. The results were outlined in a presentation by a Democratic pollster, and shared with The Times by another party strategist who wanted to draw attention to Mrs. Clintons difficulties in hopes that the campaign would move more aggressively to address the matter.

title: Young Blacks Voice Skepticism on Hillary Clinton, Worrying Democrats
description: WASHINGTON  When a handful of liberal advocacy organizations convened a series of focus groups with young black voters last month, the assessments of Donald J. Trump were predictably unsparing.

title: Jack Sock, the Last American Man at the U.S. Open, Heads Home
description: After one final, wildly wayward forehand return by Jack Sock, the American male population in the United States Open singles bracket was reduced to an all-too-familiar zero. Zilch, once again.

title: F.B.I. Arrests Florida Man Accused of Threatening to Kill Gays
description: A Florida man who posted a Facebook rant threatening to kill gay people on Labor Day in a style he compared to the massacre at an Orlando nightclub and the killing of African-Americans by police officers has been arrested and charged with a federal crime, the F.B.I. said in a statement.

title: Look Up: In the Digital Age, Billboards Are Far From Dead
description: When Axl Rose ended a 23-year feud with his former Guns N Roses bandmates, Duff McKagan and Slash, and agreed to reunite with them onstage in 2016, the band unveiled its North American tour in an unusual way. There were no news conferences, talk-show chats or photo ops. Instead, flashy electronic billboards featuring the bands logo and famous song titles began popping up in major cities across the country.

title: Caroline Wozniacki Advances to Quarterfinals With Win Over Madison Keys
description: After a season of struggles, Caroline Wozniacki said it was crazy to be back in the United States Open quarterfinals, given that she had reached that stage only twice this year, at much smaller tournaments.

title: White House Pushes for Export-Import Bank Deal as Apple Readies iPhone Update
description: Heres what to expect in the week ahead:

title: Yes, the News Can Survive the Newspaper
description: One day many decades hence, when your grandchildren ask you, Grandma, what was a newspaper? you can direct them back to Wednesday, Sept. 7, 2016. Because it may well go down as the day the American newspaper as weve known it moved out of intensive care and into the palliative wing on its way to the Great Beyond.

title: He Denied Blacks Citizenship. Now a City Is Deciding His Statues Fate.
description: FREDERICK, Md.  In 1801, Roger Brooke Taney, the politically minded son of a Maryland tobacco planter, settled here to practice law. He married the sister of Francis Scott Key, won election to the State Senate and worked his way to Washington, where he landed a dream job: Chief Justice of the Supreme Court.

title: An Art Exhibit Based on a Migrant Tragedy in Austria Stirs Unease
description: NICKELSDORF, Austria  When darkness descends on this farming village on the border with Hungary, the only lights left shining are often at the Jazzgalerie Nickelsdorf.

title: No Sailors Needed: Robot Sailboats Scour the Oceans for Data
description: ALAMEDA, Calif.  Two robotic sailboats trace lawn-mower-style paths across the violent surface of the Bering Sea, off the coast of Alaska. The boats are counting fish  pollock, to be specific  with a fancy version of the fish finder sonar youd find on a bass fishing boat.

title: Kolkata Testifies to the Grace of Mother Teresa, Its New Saint
description: KOLKATA, India  When Mother Teresas canonization took place on Sunday, a battered-looking audience gathered in front of a screen some 4,500 miles east of St. Peters Square: men with caved-in chests, weeping sores wrapped in gauze, extremities missing entirely, legs so thin you could encircle them with a finger and thumb.

title: How Uber Drivers Decide How Long to Work
description: The ride-hailing company Uber is best known for upending the taxi industry. Now it may be making waves in the economics profession as well.

title: A Publisher Joins an Industry It Covers, Blurring Lines
description: When Judy Balint, the chief marketing officer at SmartBiz Loans, read a freelance article that her companys president contributed to Entrepreneur.com last month, she was startled to see that  a promotion for a rival lender had been added to the beginning  a lender with a partnership with Entrepreneur.

title: Ivo Karlovics Net Game is Rising to Match His Serve, and His Wit
description: Few things in tennis move faster and land harder than Ivo Karlovics serves. The veteran Karlovic, who stands 6 feet 11 inches, has fired off at least one at 156 miles per hour, and no one has recorded more aces. He has delivered more than 11,200 of them and counting.

title: Oysters Are Nearly Extinct in New York Waters. This Team Is Trying to Coax Them Back.
description: Torrential rain poured down on the team of scientists and conservationists on Jamaica Bay as their small boat slowly towed about 85 cages packed with 36,000 oysters, a species that once blanketed New York Harbor but is now nearly extinct there.

title: Heavy Metal Magazine, Long a Provocateur, Returns to Its Roots
description: Heavy Metal magazine, which will celebrate its 40th anniversary next year, is harking back to its past.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 5
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes regular weekly auctions of new three- and six-month bills, rescheduled to Tuesday this week because of the Labor Day holiday, and an auction of four-week bills, also on Tuesday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I think, perhaps, we may have some difficulty in calling her St. Teresa: Her holiness is so near to us, so tender and so fruitful, that we continue to spontaneously call her Mother Teresa.

title: SpaceXs Explosion Reverberates Across Space, Satellite and Telecom Industries
description: The explosion of a SpaceX rocket last Thursday will have an impact across the space industry, far beyond the losses on the launchpad at Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: Roger Y. Tsien, Nobel Winner for Use of Glowing Proteins, Dies at 64
description: Roger Y. Tsien, who won a Nobel Prize in Chemistry for creating a rainbow of fluorescent proteins that could light up the dance of molecules within cells, died on Aug. 24 in Eugene, Ore. He was 64.

title: Michel Butor, French Novelist Who Shattered Conventions, Dies at 89
description: Michel Butor, a French novelist whose experiments with narrative and structure in the late 1950s and early 60s put him at the forefront of the literary trend known as le nouveau roman (the new novel), died on Aug. 24 in Contamine-sur-Arve, in the Rhne-Alpes region of southeastern France. He was 89.

title: Adriano Espaillat Tests the Role of Kingmaker After His Historic Primary Win
description: Adriano Espaillats victory in a Democratic primary for a New York congressional seat was a watershed for Dominican immigrants hoping to send one of their own to Washington for the first time.

title: Fear the Walking Dead Season 2, Episode 10: Weve Done Worse
description: What if you took the zombies out of the Dead universe?

title: Labor Unions, Waning Nationwide, Stay Robust in New York
description: Despite all the attention that has been paid to the union-backed campaign for a $15 minimum wage, the national decline in organized labor has persisted. Still, for three straight years, New York City, the birthplace of the Fight for $15 movement, has bucked that trend, according to a report that was to be released on Monday.

title: In Hong Kong, Young Protest Leaders Win Seats in Local Elections
description: HONG KONG  A group of young people committed to rewriting the rules that govern Hong Kongs relationship with China were swept into office on Sunday in elections for the citys legislature, lifted by record voter turnout, according to a government vote tally.

title: Nicholas Monroe Takes a Bad Tumble at U.S. Open
description: Nicholas Monroe toppled over a low wall during his third-round doubles match at the United States Open on Sunday, and he spent several minutes on the ground receiving treatment in the seating area of the Grandstand.

title: New Yorker Festival to Feature David Letterman, Louis C.K.
description: David Letterman, the basketball player Jeremy Lin and Sarah Silverman are among the guest stars to be interviewed at the 17th annual New Yorker Festival. The festival will consist of talks, panels, performances and screenings with writers for The New Yorker and prominent cultural figures, and will run Oct. 7-9 in Manhattan.

title: Mets Get a Solid Start After Dispiriting News on Jacob deGrom
description: When Mets pitching coach Dan Warthen met Seth Lugo earlier this summer, they had a conversation that might also have secretly served as an interrogation.

title: Obama Plays Down Confrontation With China Over His Planes Stairs
description: HANGZHOU, China  When Air Force One taxied to a stop in eastern China on Saturday afternoon, American and Chinese officials had already engaged in a lengthy, heated dispute over the most mundane of issues: How would the president depart his plane?

title: No Corrections: September 5, 2016
description: No corrections appeared in print.

title: Whats on TV Monday: Comedy Central Roast of Rob Lowe and High Maintenance
description: Rob Lowe is raked over the coals in a Comedy Central Roast. A widowed Australian newspaper columnist moves his teenagers to the end of the earth  New Zealand  in 800 Words. And inhale High Maintenance, the web series, before the HBO version arrives next week.

title: New Chinese Vessels Seen Near Disputed Reef in South China Sea
description: HANGZHOU, China  An unusually large number of Chinese vessels have been positioned close to a disputed reef in the South China Sea near the coast of the Philippines for the last week, despite warnings by the United States that China should stay away.

title: Venus Williams Seeks Perfection, in Lieu of the Spotlight
description: In career twilight and in the competitive shadow of her younger sister, Venus Williams nonetheless stepped into the sunlight of a practice court Sunday morning, 12 hours removed from her previous match.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: The TPP Deals Effect on U.S. and China
description: To the Editor:
