description: To the Editor:

title: Hillary Clinton Gets Gored
description: Americans of a certain age who follow politics and policy closely still have vivid memories of the 2000 election  bad memories, and not just because the man who lost the popular vote somehow ended up in office. For the campaign leading up to that end game was nightmarish too.

title: A Life of Meaning (Reason Not Required)
description: Few would disagree with two age-old truisms: We should strive to shape our lives with reason, and a central prerequisite for the good life is a personal sense of meaning. Ideally, the two should go hand in hand. We study the lessons of history, read philosophy, and seek out wise men with the hope of learning what matters. But this acquired knowledge is not the same as the felt sense that ones life is meaningful.

title: Looking Down on Black America
description: Donald J. Trump officially lost me early on the morning of Aug. 25.

title: Prisons Arent the Answer on Immigration
description: The Department of Homeland Security announced late last month that it is considering ending its use of private prisons, as the Justice Department has decided to do. The Homeland Security secretary, Jeh Johnson, told his departments advisory council to study the issue and report back to him by the end of November.

title: Donald Trump Does Detroit
description: So, after weeks of preaching his sinister sermon of black pathology to mostly white audiences as part of his utterly fake black outreach  which is in fact the effort of a bigot to disguise his bigotry  Donald Trump finally brought his message before a few mostly black audiences.

title: The Injustice of Making Kids Pay
description: It takes a lot these days to surprise anyone with the irrationalities of the American criminal justice system, rife as it is with harsh and counterproductive practices that do little or nothing to improve lives or keep the public safe.

title: Hope for Americans With Mental Illness
description: More than 40 million American adults  almost 20 percent of the adult American population  will deal with mental illness this year. Yet mental health (of the citizens, not the candidates) has not been an issue in the presidential campaign. Hillary Clinton tried to change that last week, announcing a plan that offers hope for improving mental health research, diagnosis and treatment.

title: Keep Bikes Off Our Wilderness Trails
description: Palm Springs, Calif.  Some new threat is always trying to nose its way into Americas wilderness areas. Fierce battles have been fought over logging, mining and damming these last vestiges of our wild heritage. Now proposed legislation in Congress would allow bikes in wilderness.

title: Shanghai Violin Competition Celebrates Isaac Sterns Legacy in China
description: More than 35 years after the violinist Isaac Stern made a groundbreaking visit to China, his legacy there lives on.

title: Australian Teenager Sentenced to 10 Years in Jail for Anzac Day Terror Plot
description: SYDNEY, Australia  A teenager who plotted to run over and behead a police officer during a holiday parade in Melbourne last year was sentenced on Monday to 10 years in jail.

title: North Korea Test-Fires 3 Missiles Toward Japan, Seoul Says
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea fired three ballistic missiles from the western town of Hwangju toward Japan shortly after noon on Monday, according to South Koreas Joint Chiefs of Staff. The launches came on the final day of the Group of 20 summit meeting, where the president of South Korea urged the Norths traditional allies, China and Russia, to help persuade it to end such provocations.

title: A Shopping Mall at Ground Zero, Uninformed by Its Sacred Land
description: The advice that I would give to people today, if theyre home from work, is to  is to go about a normal day, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said on Sept. 12, 2001. Take the day as an opportunity to go shopping, be with your children. Do things. Get out. Dont feel  dont feel locked in.

title: Will the New Apple iPhone Have a Headphone Jack? Rumormongers Say It Wont
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If Apple had its way, this week would play out like Christmas for 5-year-olds. First, unbelievable anticipation. Then, great surprise. At the end, immense satisfaction.

title: Sonia Sotomayor and Elena Kagan Muse Over a Cookie-Cutter Supreme Court
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  As the Supreme Court prepares to return to the bench next month, its two newest members have been reflecting on the absence of Justice Antonin Scalia, who died in February, and on the striking lack of diversity among the remaining justices.

title: Drug Linked to Ohio Overdoses Can Kill in Doses Smaller than a Snowflake
description: CINCINNATI  On the day he almost died, John Hatmaker bought a packet of Oreos and some ruby-red Swedish Fish at the corner store for his 5-year-old son. He was walking home when he spotted a man who used to sell him heroin.

title: Mark Thompsons New Book on the Use and Misuse of Rhetoric
description: ENOUGH SAIDWhats Gone Wrong With the Language of Politics?By Mark Thompson342 pp. St. Martins Press. $27.99.

title: 5 New Novels Make Fiction Out of Eco-Disaster
description: MARROW ISLANDBy Alexis M. Smith244 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $23.

title: Perfect Strangers | Dick Cavett & Seth Meyers
description: The TV legend and late-night comedian talk fashion, Snapchat and Pokmon Go.

title: When Dick Cavett Met Seth Meyers
description: One generations smartest talk show host meets anothers to discuss the rules of comedy, and how to break them.

title: ScienceTake: Bees Buzz for Their Supper
description: Researchers from the University of Arizona experimented to find out whether a bees technique to cull pollen from flowers was learned, or instinctual.

title: Bees Buzz for Their Supper
description: The familiar buzz of a bumble bee is one of those summer sounds that is easy to take for granted. But for the bees, buzzing has a purpose. They may buzz during courtship, or out of alarm if they are caught or trapped.

title: London Burns, for the Sake of Art
description: LONDON  The skyline of the British capital burst into flames Sunday night. Unlike when London burned in 1666, this was only an art project.

title: Politics Are Tricky but Science Is Clear: Needle Exchanges Work
description: For decades, public health experts have known that syringe exchange programs reduce the spread of certain viral infections  like H.I.V., hepatitis B and hepatitis C  by removing contaminated syringes from circulation.

title: South Sudan to Allow More U.N. Peacekeepers, but Force Will Be No Panacea
description: UKUNDA, Kenya  Under intense pressure, South Sudans beleaguered government has relented and will allow more United Nations peacekeepers into the country.

title: Gentler Chicken Slaughter? Chinese Province Thinks Its Worth a Try
description: BEIJING  In its final hours before being butchered, a chicken deserves to be reasonably comfortable and relatively stress-free. This is the message from Chinas first official recommendations to the poultry industry, recently issued by Shandong Province, on how to slaughter the animals.

title: 1966: Philippine Sect Battles Police
description: MANILA  A band of religious fanatics led by a white-robed man who calls himself God battled on today [Sept. 5] against pursuing armed police after a weekend clash in which 1,000 of his followers surrendered. Victorino Siagan, the 27-year old leader, and about 40 armed followers escaped after a skirmish with troopers on Mindanao island in which six followers and one policeman were killed.

title: Vote in Hong Kong Deepens a Thorn in Chinas Side
description: HONG KONG  In Canada, it is the Qubcois. In Spain, the Catalans. In Britain, the Scots.

title: On Labor Day, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Begin a Final Sprint
description: CLEVELAND  Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump ran virtually parallel campaigns on Monday as they geared up for the final stretch of the presidential race. She made nice with the news media by opening up her campaign plane and chatting with reporters. He followed suit, inviting a smaller group of reporters onto his plane and answering questions during the 30-minute flight.

title: 2 Killed at Jouvert Celebration in Brooklyn Despite Security Steps
description: This year, Jouvert was supposed to be different.

title: Gaps of Trust With Russia Bar a Syrian Truce, Obama Says
description: VIENTIANE, Laos  The Obama administrations latest effort to broker a cease-fire in Syrias civil war fell short on Monday, after a 90-minute meeting between President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia failed to resolve problems between them.

title: Barclays Hires JPMorgan Executive to Head Investment Bank
description: LONDON  James E. Staley, the Barclays chief executive, has turned to another executive from his former employer, JPMorgan Chase, to fill out his new banks executive ranks.

title: At World Scrabble Championship, Braconid Carries the Day
description: In the end, victory came down to a parasitic wasp.

title: I Was a Hotline Psychic for Miss Cleo
description: The summer I became a phone psychic, you could still wear shoes through airport security, Britney Spears had not yet shaved her head and no one knew I was flunking out of college.

title: A Budding Beauty Baron Gets an Assist From Nas
description: For nearly four years, hip-hop fans have been waiting for Nas to release his long-gestating 12th studio album. Over the summer the Queens-born rapper offered more than a hint that it was ready to go when he appeared as the featured rapper on a track from DJ Khaleds latest album, Nas Album Done.

title: How New York Times Stories Are Like Footballs
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this article, Steven Rocker, a news assistant, explains how Times stories move through the editing process, not unlike a football through a play.

title: The Mystery of Sweating Buckets
description: Q. A 90-degree day means I sweat buckets just walking the dog and lose every bit of energy. Why do some people tolerate the heat less well than others?

title: U.S. Open Today: Breakthrough Wins for Karolina Pliskova and Ana Konjuh
description: In the past year, Karolina Pliskova, 24, has been in the top 10 and became the highest-ranked player from the Czech Republic.

title: Merkel Vows to Stay on Course Despite Party Setback
description: BERLIN  A day after voters in Chancellor Angela Merkels political home state delivered what amounted to a strong rejection of her refugee policy, the German leader acknowledged on Monday that she was very dissatisfied with the result but insisted that she would stick with her chosen course.

title: 1891: Wusueh Outrages in China
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A Wuchang correspondent, writing on August 3 to the North China News, which has just been received here by mail, says the patience of the foreign population is well nigh exhausted by the tardiness of the Chinese officials in punishing the perpetrators of the Wusueh outrages. On the second batch of offenders, eight in number, who were convicted of murder, assault and pillage, sentences of penal servitude for life, banishment for life, or branding on the face or back were imposed.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 6, 1891

title: Coordinated Bombs in Kabul Kill Senior Afghan Officials at Defense Ministry
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A pair of coordinated Taliban bombings targeted the Afghan Defense Ministry in a crowded neighborhood of Kabul on Monday, officials said, killing at least 24 people and wounding dozens, among them senior security officials.

title: Where Is Safe? Travelers Seek Havens in Wake of Europe Attacks
description: In the months since the November terrorist attack in Paris and the March bombing of the Brussels airport, Americans did something that may seem counterintuitive. They went to Europe more, with travelers up 5 percent in April, according to the Department of Commerces National Travel & Tourism Office.

title: A Monster Watch Mashup
description: This year the Swiss watchmaker HYT is saluting the 200th birthday of another well-known creation of Swiss provenance: Frankensteins famous monster, which Mary Shelley dreamed up while visiting Lord Byron at Lake Geneva.

title: Happy Labor Day!
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: A Mechanical Bestiary, With Time
description: PARIS  Who is ticking? Alexis Kugel playfully asked a group of ornate animal figures in his palatial antiques gallery at the historic Htel Collot.

title: A.N.C.s Combative Response to Election Losses Startles South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG  When South African voters last month handed the African National Congress its worst-ever losses, seemingly chastened party leaders said they would engage in introspection.

title: Ive Become a Racist: Migrant Wave Unleashes Danish Tensions Over Identity
description: TAARNBY, Denmark  Johnny Christensen, a stout and silver-whiskered retired bank employee, always thought of himself as sympathetic to people fleeing war and welcoming to immigrants. But after more than 36,000 mostly Muslim asylum seekers poured into Denmark over the past two years, Mr. Christensen, 65, said, Ive become a racist.

title: A Land Eager to Look Rich: Luxury Brands Edge Into Myanmar
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Every man has a crazy hobby, said U Thiri Thein Than, an automotive engineer from Yangon who also has a home in Tokyo. For me, its cars and watches.

title: Obama Says Colin Kaepernick Is Exercising His Constitutional Right
description: President Obama said Monday that Colin Kaepernick, the San Francisco 49ers quarterback, was exercising his constitutional right by refusing to stand during the national anthem, a decision that has fostered considerable controversy since he first took the action on Aug. 26.

title: Crossing the Pool
description: This weeks puzzle was suggested by Steve Humble (@drmaths), an author and mathematics educator from Newcastle University. Steve was relaxing by the pool in Murcia, Spain recently and thought of this athletic challenge. Heres Steve with

title: What You Should Watch: Queen Sugar and Atlanta
description: Welcome to Watching, The New York Timess what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

title: Female Scientists Turn to Data to Fight Lack of Representation on Panels
description: One day in August 2015, the Princeton University neuroscientist Yael Niv saw an email notice of a conference on deep brain stimulation, a hot topic in treatment for depression and other mental disorders. Dr. Niv noticed that none of the 21 scientists scheduled to speak were women.

title: Q. and A.: Andy Murray Puts On His Politicians Hat
description: For a fifth year, The New York Times is speaking to Andy Murray after his matches at the United States Open, where he broke through for his first Grand Slam title in 2012. Murray, who plays Grigor Dimitrov in the fourth round Monday night, was recently elected to his first term on the ATP Player Council (Novak Djokovic was elected president). After a strenuous first meeting, Murray discussed the issues most important to the tour and to him, as well as his inclination toward politics.

title: Doctors on Lookout for Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever in Spain
description: Doctors are closely watching about 200 people in Spain after a patient at a hospital in Madrid died of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever, the first time the disease has been found in Western Europe in someone who had not traveled to an endemic area.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 11 Books Worth Reading About the World Trade Centers Redevelopment
description: Lynne B. Sagalyns Power at Ground Zero: Politics, Money and the Remaking of Lower Manhattan and Judith Duprs One World Trade Center: Biography of the Building are two of the most consequential new books about the redevelopment of the World Trade Center.

title: Does the Messaging Service Telegram Take Privacy Too Far?
description: PARIS  The encryption of digital information is considered the best protection against hackers, snoops or potential enemies looking to poke around into private exchanges of all sorts.

title: No Longer Missing: Rosettas Philae Spacecraft Located on Comet
description: With its legs poking out of a dark crevice on a speeding comet many millions of miles away, the Philae spacecraft, missing since 2014 after a 10-year trip, has finally been found.

title: On Being a Black Female Math Whiz During the Space Race
description: HAMPTON, Va.  Growing up here in the 1970s, in the shadow of Langley Research Center, where workers helped revolutionize air flight and put Americans on the moon, Margot Lee Shetterly had a pretty fixed idea of what scientists looked like: They were middle class, African-American and worked at NASA, like her dad.

title: In Philippine Drug War, Little Help for Those Who Surrender
description: MANILA  Rayzabell Bongol, an 18-year-old mother and methamphetamine user, was afraid to die in President Rodrigo Dutertes war on drugs in the Philippines. So she turned herself in to the police. They made her sign a pledge that she would never take illegal drugs again, then sent her home.

title: Kabul Bombing Witnesses Describe Attack
description: An attack by Taliban suicide bombers in a busy area near the defense ministry in Kabul killed at least 20 people, the deadliest toll in the Afghan capital in weeks.

title: Researchers Confront an Epidemic of Loneliness
description: BLACKPOOL, England  The woman on the other end of the phone spoke lightheartedly of spring and of her 81st birthday the previous week.

title: Narcos Season 2 Episode 4: No One Escapes
description: The character of Colonel Horacio Carrillo in Narcos was thought to be based loosely on Col. Hugo Martnez, the leader of the Search Bloc police unit tasked by President Gaviria with hunting Pablo Escobar. In a Daily Beast column from last year titled The Man Who Brought Down Pablo Escobar, the then-74-year-old Martnez told the author Kim MacQuarrie about Escobars many attempts to bribe, intimidate and murder him before Search Bloc finally captured him on Dec. 2, 1993. MacQuarrie also noted the Narcos inspiration, writing:

title: Sorry About That: Wells Fargo to End Ads Suggesting Science Over Arts
description: Wells Fargo, the financial services giant immortalized in lyrics to The Music Man, has apologized for advertisements that seemed to suggest that teenagers should set aside their artistic dreams and choose careers in science.

title: Overlooked Influences on Donald Trump: A Famous Minister and His Church
description: Just before a Sunday morning service in the early 1990s, two women walked into one of Manhattans most venerable sanctuaries, Marble Collegiate Church, on Fifth Avenue. The usher who seated them, sizing them up as first-time worshipers, asked what had brought them to Marble, as the church is known.

title: The California Voter Ordeal: 17 Decisions on the Ballot
description: LOS ANGELES  Pity the California voter.

title: Keeping Your Old Phone Alive and Working
description: Q. Some of us like our older phones and want to keep them. I know for many just getting a new battery will be enough, so what resources are available for those of us who want to keep our older iPhones, Android phones and other gear going for as long as possible?

title: Air Force, Running Low on Drone Pilots, Turns to Contractors in Terror Fight
description: WASHINGTON  The American militarys extensive use of drones against the Islamic State and other terrorist groups has resulted in a shortage of Air Force pilots and other personnel to operate the aircraft, leading the Pentagon to rely more on private contractors for reconnaissance missions in Afghanistan and Iraq.

title: Syrian Forces Make Gains Near Aleppo With Russian Help
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Russian airstrikes helped the Syrian government and allied forces seize critical territory on the outskirts of the divided northern city of Aleppo on Monday, tightening a siege of rebel-held territory there as Russian and American officials joined meetings said to be aimed at hashing out access for humanitarian aid to the city.

title: With Occupancy High, Hotels Seek to Avoid Online Booking Services
description: Hotels and online travel booking companies tend to have a marriage of convenience  one that savvy travelers can exploit.

title: Director of the Victoria and Albert Museum to Step Down
description: London  Martin Roth, the director of the Victoria and Albert Museum, will step down from his position in the fall, the museum announced on Monday. The announcement came after the British media had published rumors of his imminent resignation over the weekend, based on an interview that Mr. Roth gave in late June to the German broadcaster DW. In that interview, the German-born Mr. Roth voiced his unhappiness at Britains Brexit vote, describing it as horrible.

title: Brazils Better Than Goldman Bank Slowly Rebounds From Scandal
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  BTG Pactual, a once highflying Brazilian investment bank that stumbled badly during a brush with scandal last year, is reinventing itself with more modest aspirations.

title: After Obama Cancels Talk, Rodrigo Duterte of Philippines Says He Regrets Slur
description: President Obama canceled a meeting with President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines scheduled for Tuesday in Laos, after the Philippine president directed an expletive at Mr. Obama on Monday.

title: Streisands Encore Tops the Billboard Album Chart
description: Show business rule No. 1: Never doubt Barbra Streisand, as this weeks music charts affirm once again. (Rule No. 2 might be: Never doubt Beyonc.)

title: Tyler Austin Aids in a Yankees Victory, and Makes a Statement
description: With Mark Teixeira set to retire after this season, there will be a rare vacancy at first base at Yankee Stadium next year.

title: Review: In FXs Atlanta, a Princeton Dropout Works the Angles Back Home
description: In Atlanta, Donald Glover plays a character whose name  Earn  is also his aspiration. Hes not earning much right now. A Princeton dropout, hes technically homeless, crashing with the mother of his baby daughter and pushing credit-card sign-ups at the airport for $5.15 an hour.

title: Review: Queen Sugar, on OWN, Yields Family Drama
description: More than five years after it went on the air, OWN, Oprah Winfreys cable channel, still seems as if its trying to define itself. So perhaps its no surprise that its latest series, Queen Sugar, feels that way too. The show, which begins on Tuesday, is definitely a drama, but it sure is a hodgepodge of tones and topics.

title: Review: Nutshell, a Tale Told by a Baby-to-Be (or Not-to-Be)
description: With Nutshell, Ian McEwan has performed an incongruous magic trick, mashing up the premises of Shakespeares Hamlet and Amy Heckerlings 1989 movie, Look Whos Talking, to create a smart, funny and utterly captivating novel.

title: Theresa May Rules Out Immigration Plan That Brexit Backers Espoused
description: LONDON  Outlining the first, tentative details of how she intends to leave the European Union without damaging Britains economy, Prime Minister Theresa May on Monday ruled out the type of immigration curbs championed by prominent supporters of withdrawal before Junes referendum on quitting the bloc.

title: Review: Inventing a Better Bitcoin in StartUp, New on Crackle
description: Jerry Seinfeld is going to run out of cars someday. StartUp is the latest manifestation of that inevitability.

title: Cinema Is Dead? Telluride Says Not Yet
description: TELLURIDE, Colo.  Can we please kill the talk about the death of movies?

title: Review: In The Jamb, 2 Gay Middle-Age Friends Face a Reckoning
description: At 40, Roderick is fit and muscular, and leads a healthy life. He is also angry at just about everything, especially gay men who waste their lives getting wasted  chief among them his best friend, Tuffer, a trust-fund wastrel with a weakness for crystal meth and go-go boys. What makes things worse for Roderick is that before adopting the monastic precepts of straightedge hardcore music  no drugs, no booze, no fun  he used to be just like Tuffer. Now, hes the one on call when his buddy cries for help at 4 a.m.

title: Lacking Sleep and Several Starters, the Mets Power Through
description: CINCINNATI  The Mets arrived here just before 3 a.m. Monday, and many players did not get to sleep until an hour later, all because of a late game Sunday night at Citi Field. Mets Manager Terry Collins swore at his alarm clock when it sounded, yet he was still at Great American Ball Park at 8 a.m.

title: Hugh OBrian Dies; Dashing TV Star of Wyatt Earp Was 91
description: Hugh OBrian, who rose to fame on television as the quick-drawing lawman Wyatt Earp in the 1950s and who later devoted extensive time to a foundation he created that trains young people to be leaders, died on Monday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 91.

title: Osiris-Rex: Chasing Asteroid Bennu
description: NASAs Osiris-Rex spacecraft will hunt down an asteroid and return a sample to Earth.

title: NASA Aims at an Asteroid Holding Clues to the Solar Systems Roots
description: For the next two years, NASAs latest robotic spacecraft will be chasing down an asteroid near Earth in the hopes of scooping up some of the most primordial bits of the solar system.

title: BuzzFeed Regroups as Media Turns Video-Centric
description: Staff meetings at BuzzFeed are not uncommon. Jonah H. Peretti, the sites founder and chief executive, who is based in Los Angeles, travels to the New York offices regularly and often meets with employees to answer questions or outline strategy.

title: Namon Hoggle, 81, Accused in a Civil Rights Killing, Is Dead
description: Namon ONeal Hoggle, the last surviving defendant accused of bludgeoning a minister to death in Selma, Ala., in 1965  a killing that galvanized the civil rights movement in the South and helped embolden Congress to ban racial discrimination in voting  died on Aug. 30 in Selma. He was 81.

title: Q. and A.: Eric Korita Shares the Keys to a Power Serve
description: In the 1980s, the most powerful serve in tennis belonged to Eric Korita. He never achieved the overall success of his big-serving predecessor Roscoe Tanner or successors like Mark Philippoussis or Ivo Karlovic. Koritas highest world ranking was 30th in doubles and 46th in singles, but he regularly served faster than 140 miles per hour in an era when that was unheard of. Korita will be at the United States Open, giving a clinic on serving, for The New York Times on Facebook Live on Tuesday at 1 p.m. First, he shared some thoughts on his biggest weapon.

title: The Bridge Scandal: You Ask, We Answer
description: New York Times reporters answered readers questions about the George Washington Bridge scandal in a live online discussion on Wednesday, Sept. 7, 2016.

title: Rory McIlroy Wins a Windy Deutsche Bank Championship
description: NORTON, Mass.  For most of the field  even golfs elite  a relentless, swirling wind turned the final round of the Deutsche Bank Championship into a survival test.

title: Why Airgas Was Finally Sold, for $10 Billion Instead of $5 Billion
description: Big shareholders do not always play nice.

title: No For Sale Sign? Silicon Valley Buyers Arent Deterred
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif.  Swell-looking home youve got here. Ever think about selling it? How about to me, right now?

title: Donald Trumps Alt-Right Brain
description: Donald Trump has devoted most of the past two weeks to discussing immigration, even though only 8 percent of Americans rank it as the most important problem facing this country today, according to a recent Gallup poll.

title: Despite Bernie Sanderss Urging, Die-Hards Still Resist Hillary Clinton
description: LEBANON, N.H.  Outside Senator Bernie Sanderss first general-election rally for Hillary Clinton on Monday, a small group of Clinton supporters and former Sanders backers glared at one another.

title: Roger Ailes Hints at Suit Against New York Magazine
description: A lawyer for Roger Ailes, the former chairman of Fox News, has sent a letter to New York magazine suggesting he might take legal action over its reporting about Mr. Ailes.

title: Phyllis Schlafly, First Lady of a Political March to the Right, Dies at 92
description: Phyllis Schlafly, whose grass-roots campaigns against Communism, abortion and the Equal Rights Amendment galvanized conservatives for almost two generations and helped reshape American politics, died on Monday. She was 92.

title: Russian Polling Center Is Declared a Foreign Agent Before Elections
description: MOSCOW  Russian officials declared the Levada Center, the countrys only major independent pollster, a foreign agent on Monday, two weeks before nationwide parliamentary elections and days after a poll showed sliding support for the governing party, United Russia.

title: Whom to Vote For? Employees Tend to Follow Their Leader
description: Late last month, Tim Cook, Apples chief executive, hosted a private fund-raiser for Hillary Clinton in Los Altos, Calif., along with his colleague Lisa Jackson, vice president of Apples environmental, policy and social initiatives. The private, off-the-record event required a donation of $2,700 to $50,000.

title: Eating Lobster Tails at Gage & Tollner
description: Dear Diary:

title: Pondering Miracles, Medical and Religious
description: Kingston, Ontario  THERE was no mistaking the diagnostic significance of that little red stick inside a deep blue cell: The Auer rod meant the mystery patient had acute myelogenous leukemia. As slide after slide went by, her bone marrow told a story: treatment, remission, relapse, treatment, remission, remission, remission.

title: French Prime Minister Faults Times Article Giving Voice to Muslim Women
description: Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France sharply criticized on Monday a New York Times article in which French Muslim women described being ostracized by non-Muslims, discriminated against when they sought jobs and made to feel persecuted.

title: Hillary Clinton Unveils New Plane, and Lets Journalists On Board
description: CLEVELAND  The general election began in earnest on Monday, not with the first presidential debate or the start of early voting, but with the arrival of a squat Boeing 737 strewn with a shiny new coat of white paint and an H on its sky-blue tail.

title: Jersey Shore Shopkeepers Are Hit by a Storm That Never Arrived
description: WILDWOOD, N.J.  At the Dolphin Gift Shop on the boardwalk, sales of T-shirts, beach balls, hats and sunglasses plunged over Labor Day weekend as customers fled from a storm that never arrived.

title: Juan Martn del Potro, Ranked No. 142, Reaches Quarterfinals in a Jimmy Connors Flashback
description: In the 25th-anniversary year of his memorable run to the United States Open semifinals at age 39, Jimmy Connors came up a lot Monday.

title: With Food Hub, Premium Produce May Reach More New Yorkers Plates
description: Lunches at a senior center on the Upper East Side of Manhattan come with organic kale, vine-ripened tomatoes and freshly plucked summer squash  all grown not that far away in the Hudson Valley.

title: Obama Unlikely to Vow No First Use of Nuclear Weapons
description: President Obama, who has weighed ruling out a first use of a nuclear weapon in a conflict, appears likely to abandon the proposal after top national security advisers argued that it could undermine allies and embolden Russia and China, according to several senior administration officials.

title: Venus Williams Loses in Third-Set Tiebreaker and Serena Williams Moves On
description: It was a meandering match that spanned 2 hours 24 minutes and encapsulated the three primary stages of Venus Williamss two-decade career.

title: U.N. Human Rights Chief Blasts Demagogues of Western Nations
description: GENEVA  Discarding diplomatic niceties, the United Nations top human rights official on Monday denounced Western politicians who he said used racist language and peddled fear in a way similar to the jihadist propaganda of Islamist extremists.

title: Hopes Rise That Staten Islands Young Eagle Is a Native New Yorker
description: Three years ago, as Lawrence Pugliares searched for bugs and butterflies to photograph within the Mount Loretto Unique Area, a 200-acre grassland along the south shore of Staten Island, something not so tiny soared over his head. Mr. Pugliares scrambled as an adult male bald eagle canvassed what would become its new home.

title: S.E.C. Whistle-Blower Programs First Chief Joins Law Firm
description: Sean X. McKessy, the founding director of the whistle-blower program at the Securities and Exchange Commission, is joining a law firm in Washington, where he will be an advocate for individuals coming forward with information about fraud or improprieties in their workplaces.

title: Three Frenchmen in U.S. Open Quarterfinals Are All Eager to Topple Novak Djokovic
description: It will be Novak Djokovic versus the French for a place in the mens singles final at the United States Open.

title: Its the Chicago Cubs Year, in the Milwaukee Brewers Park
description: MILWAUKEE  It has been a while since Casey Jagielnik of West Chicago, Ill., could walk up to Wrigley Field the day of a game, hand over 75 cents or a dollar for a bleacher seat and watch his beloved Chicago Cubs lose in varied and maddening ways.

title: Phrase of Resignation
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  There comes a time in everyones life when a person needs to turn to friends for support. And that day is today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Just kick them out.

title: Hillary Clinton Says She Wont Visit Mexico Before Election
description: MEXICO CITY  Hillary Clinton said Monday that she would not visit Mexico before the November election, delivering another setback to President Enrique Pea Nieto a week after he faced furious criticism at home for receiving Donald J. Trump.

title: Hillary Clinton Accuses Russia of Interfering With U.S. Election
description: MOLINE, Ill.  Hillary Clinton accused Russian intelligence of interfering with the American election, implying that President Vladimir V. Putin viewed a victory by Donald J. Trump as a destabilizing event that would weaken the United States and buttress Russian interests.

title: No Corrections: September 6, 2016
description: No corrections appeared in print.

title: How One of the Deadliest Hajj Accidents Unfolded
description: A survivors story of how he was almost crushed to death at the 2015 hajj.

title: Ubaldo Jimenez Tosses Two-Hitter for the Baltimore Orioles
description: Ubaldo Jimenez threw a two-hitter for his first complete game since 2011, Chris Davis homered and drove in three runs, and the Baltimore Orioles beat the host Tampa Bay Rays, 7-3, on Monday.

title: Ana Konjuh Stuns Agnieszka Radwanska to Reach Quarterfinals of U.S. Open
description: Months after an unlucky bounce tripped up her hopes of a career-making win at Wimbledon, Ana Konjuh, ranked No. 92 in the world, seized a second chance, beating fourth-seeded Agnieszka Radwanska by 6-4, 6-4 on Monday night in the fourth round of the United States Open.

title: The Geography of U.S. Inequality
description: How have the contours of incomes changed, state by state, over the last two decades?

title: Branded Berries
description: Driscolls has been producing berries for more than a century. Now it is embarking on a campaign to tell consumers why its berries are worth seeking out by name.

title: British Airways Computer Problems Cause Widespread Delays
description: British Airways said its flights were gradually returning to normal on Tuesday after a still-unexplained computer problem disabled the airlines self-service check-in kiosks for several hours at a number of international airports, causing significant delays.

title: Stevie Nicks on Her Fleetwood Mac Team, Solo Joys and the 2016 Election
description: Stevie Nicks says that one of her favorite things to do is light a candle, sit at the desk in her Los Angeles home and write poetry. Ms. Nicks, the rock n roll mystic who constitutes one-fifth of Fleetwood Macs classic lineup and wrote several of its most beloved hits (including Dreams and Rhiannon), is so prolific that six years after joining that multiplatinum California band in 1975, she embarked on a solo career with Bella Donna, which featured the memorable centerpiece Edge of Seventeen.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday: Atlanta and Queen Sugar
description: The new television season begins by heading South: Atlanta, a new comedy from Donald Glover, charts the citys rap scene; Queen Sugar, from Oprah Winfrey and Ava DuVernay, settles into a Louisiana sugar-cane farm; and StartUp follows the scent of money in Miami.

title: Vitamin B12 as Protection for the Aging Brain
description: As a woman of a certain age who consumes a well-balanced diet of all the usual food groups, including reasonable amounts of animal protein, I tend to dismiss advice to take a multivitamin supplement. Ive been told repeatedly by nutrition experts that the overuse of dietary supplements for nutritional insurance has given Americans the most expensive urine in the world.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | implode
description: implode  \im-plod\  verb

title: Capturing Complexity and Color in Mexico
description: A book and exhibition feature the lush, multilayered photographs of Alex Webb  works that represent over 40 trips throughout Mexico.

title: How Laos Tries to Balance Its Powerful Neighbors
description: HONG KONG  A rare spotlight is being cast on Laos as world leaders, including President Obama, prepare to gather in its capital, Vientiane, for meetings of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, and other countries beginning on Tuesday.

title: Capturing Complexity and Color in Mexico
description: When Alex Webb first walked across the bridge from El Paso to Ciudad Jurez, Mexico, in 1975, he was a 23-year-old hotshot photographer. He had just become a nominee to the esteemed Magnum photo collective and was already noted for his alienated black-and-white images capturing the American social landscape.

title: An Ugly Presidential Race Shows the World What Its Missing
description: The Timess Cairo bureau chief, Declan Walsh, has come to the United States to cover the 2016 presidential election from the perspective of a foreign correspondent.

title: What We Can Do to Reduce Opioid Overuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Filling In the Retirement Gap, From Coast to Coast
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cost of Keeping Companies in the United States
description: How should we stop corporations from leaving the United States, as both presidential candidates have vowed to do? After Pfizer announced this year that it wanted to merge with the Ireland-based Allergan in a maneuver known as a corporate inversion, the Obama administration put in new tax rules that effectively scuttled the deal.

title: Political History Fades From View
description: To the Editor:

title: Save the Republican Party: Vote for Clinton
description: Every day, I run into Republican friends who cant stomach a vote for Donald J. Trump but dont know what to do. Vote for Hillary Clinton, who has trouble with the truth, wants to raise taxes and opposes free trade with Asia? Vote for the Libertarian candidate, Gary Johnson, an outlier who once ran a marijuana business and embraces isolationism? Or not vote at all, maintaining a certain purity but allowing others to decide the next president?

title: False Hope and a Needless Death Behind Bars
description: On July 26, John MacKenzie went before the parole board at the Fishkill Correctional Facility in Beacon, N.Y., and made the case, once again, for his freedom. He had been locked up since 1975 for shooting and killing a Long Island police officer, Matthew Giglio, during a bungled robbery attempt. His sentence was 25 years to life  the maximum under state law.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Obamacare
description: During the debate over Obamacare, both supporters and opponents assumed the giant law would transform the American health care system. The supporters argued that the system would help Americans purchase health insurance through carefully regulated state exchanges. President Obama envisioned a day when consumers could shop for health coverage the same way youd shop for a plane ticket on Kayak or a TV on Amazon.

title: Surfing in Nixonland
description: I first moved to San Clemente, Calif., in 2007, my last year of graduate school, renting a house in town about a mile up the coast from the so-called Western White House, the beachfront estate Richard Nixon bought in 1969 shortly after winning the presidency. The Nixons called it La Casa Pacifica and lived there through most of the 1970s. I surfed in front of it a lot that first summer, at a spot the locals called Cottons, after the original owner of the property, Hamilton H. Cotton, an F.D.R. man as it happened.

title: Why This Election Feels Never-Ending
description: Im not positive, but at least somewhat sure, that this presidential election has been going on since Hannibals elephants crossed the Alps. It has been going on since Assyria fell to Alexander the Great. It has been going on since before rocks were invented.

title: A Non-Contest at the World Bank
description: The deadline for submitting nominations for the job of president of the World Bank is Sept. 14, about a week away, and so far the only candidate, and the likely winner, is the person who is already running the place: Jim Yong Kim.

title: Picture Prompt | An Act of Kindness
description: Last week, this photo was shared thousands of times on social media.

title: In Watches: Minutes of Steel
description: As global exports of Swiss watches continue to tumble, some houses are turning to lower-priced watches, and in particular, to steel, to stir the market.

title: A Day of Bloodshed in Kabul: Attacks at Defense Ministry and Aid Compound
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Col. Ahmad Salangi, 47, had flourished in the new Afghan national police force, rising to become the deputy commander of one of the most important security districts in the capital.

title: Shariah With Chinese Characteristics: A Scholar Looks at the Muslim Hui
description: Matthew S. Erie, a trained lawyer and ethnographer who teaches at Oxford University, lived for two years in Linxia, a small city in the northwestern Chinese province of Gansu. Known as Chinas Mecca, it is a center of religious life for the Hui, an ethnic minority numbering 10 million who practice Islam. Along with the Turkic Uighurs, they are one of 10 officially recognized ethnic groups that practice Islam, making the total population of Muslims in China around 23 million, according to the 2010 government census.

title: Key to Winning at the U.S. Open Is in the First Four Shots
description: There can be a pronounced disconnect between what happens on a practice court in preparation to win a tennis match, and what actually happens once the match begins.

title: How Much Disclosure Do We Really Expect From Candidates?
description: Its a safe bet that advisers to Hillary Clinton spend more time than they would like batting away the suggestion that their candidate must be hiding something. This is what Joel Benenson, Clintons chief campaign strategist, had to do on CNN one morning in late August, when the anchor Chris Cuomo confronted him with questions about Clintons meetings with donors to the Clinton Foundation, in the years when she was secretary of state. The subtext was whether Clinton had been forthcoming enough about the influence of her private connections on her exercise of official power. Benenson, like any good surrogate, tried to change the subject. Lets talk about Donald Trump, he said. The man who said, I will release my tax returns if I run for president. Who knows what well find if he releases those tax returns? I think if you want to be hammering somebody in this race day in and day out about disclosure, he added, it should be Trump.

title: Subprime Lender, Busy at State Level, Avoids Federal Scrutiny
description: The payday lending industry is bracing for a regulatory crackdown. One of its rivals is not.

title: How Much Do We Really Know About Global Trades Impacts?
description: Donald Trumps campaign has at times resembled a whistle-stop tour of broken-down manufacturing towns. Places like Monessen, Pa., and Hickory, N.C., have come to be seen as central to his rise  and that of Bernie Sanders, before he bowed out  as well as symbols of a national preoccupation during this election season: the downsides of globalization. Earlier this year, research that led to an academic paper from several economists titled The China Shock found that between 1999 and 2011, the growth in imports from China killed about 2.4 million American jobs, one million or so of them in manufacturing. Thats a much greater impact than most economists had been assuming, and the 2.4 million figure has come up again and again in debates over global trade.

title: Donald Trumps Feud With John Kasich May Haunt Him in Ohio
description: Elections in Ohio are trench warfare, fought by waves of volunteers swarming across hundreds of thousands of front porches to rap on doors.

description: Article: Kolkata Testifies to the Grace of Mother Teresa, Its New Saint

description: Clowns: some people love them as much as other people fear them. In light of the strong reactions people seem to have especially the negative ones  do you think its acceptable to dress up as a clown and appear in public in places that arent costume parties, circuses, carnivals and the like? Why or why not?

description: VIENTIANE, Laos  President Obama, declaring that it was time to pull Americas secret war in Laos from the shadows, told an audience here on Tuesday that he stood with them in acknowledging the suffering and sacrifices on all sides of that conflict.

description: LONDON  General Electric said on Tuesday that it had offered to buy two European suppliers of additive manufacturing equipment for a combined $1.4 billion as it looks to push further into 3-D printing.

description: About 90 retired generals and military officials endorsed Donald J. Trump's presidential candidacy in an open letter, urging a long overdue course correction in our national security posture.

description: Donald J. Trumps campaign released an open letter on Tuesday from about 90 retired generals and military officials endorsing his presidential campaign, urging a long overdue course correction in our national security posture.

description: How much influence does your boss have over how you vote? Youd probably like to think youre fairly independent, but that may not be the case.

description: Updated, 8:44 a.m.

description: After a seven-week break, Congress returns on Tuesday for a pre-election session that is likely to produce substantial political positioning without much substantive accomplishment.

description: Our Seventh Annual Summer Reading Contest garnered a record 7,795 submissions from teenagers around the world, and today we honor our final group of winners.

title: A Heros Burial for a Long-Dead Dictator
description: MANILA  Mornings in the Philippines reveal bodies dumped outside slums. Averaging 13 a day, nearly 2,000 in the last two months, the bodies are hung with cardboard labels: purse snatcher, drug pusher, addict. The authorities decline to investigate. These are the casualties of a controversial crusade against crime that was the subject of the recent spat between the countrys new president, Rodrigo Duterte, and Barack Obama, which devolved into crude insults (by Mr. Duterte) and canceled meetings (by Mr. Obama).

title: Nicolas Sarkozy Is Back, but France Has Changed
description: PARIS  One of the most popular items on the social networks as Nicolas Sarkozy opened his new presidential bid last month was a video of an interview he gave to the French news channel BFM-TV on March 8, 2012. Still president then, Mr. Sarkozy was seeking a second five-year term, with Franois Hollande running against him. Asked whether he would quit politics if he lost, he firmly answered, Yes. The journalist was taken aback. Will you quit politics? he asked again, incredulous. You can ask me a third time, the president shot back. Im telling you: yes.

title: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Head Into Crucial Last 2 Months
description: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump, with Labor Day behind them, enter the final stretch of the grueling 2016 presidential campaign on Tuesday as they emerge from Ohio and fan out across the country.

title: Rene Zellweger Is Back and Standing Up for Herself
description: It has been six years since Rene Zellweger appeared on a big screen, and twice as long since she has channeled Bridget Jones, the British heroine who made charming sport of cataloging her romantic foibles. The gap was by design: Ms. Zellweger, 47, an Oscar nominee for the first Bridget movie and a winner in 2004 for Cold Mountain, stepped away from the Hollywood cycle, as she called it, to take stock of her life. I had a lot of promises that I made to myself, years ago, about things that I wanted to learn and try, she said.

title: Is the World Becoming Safer?
On the Menu When Congress Returns From Recess
description: Members of Congress returned from a seven-week recess on Tuesday in a rush to get out the door yet again to campaign for re-election. Still, they have a few items they must address and some optional items. Think of it as a dinner menu at a party voters were not invited to attend:

title: Chappatte on Mother Teresas Canonization
description: Younger generations assess Mother Teresas sainthood 19 years after her death.

title: Release the Records on Dag Hammarskjolds Death
description: LONDON  Last month, the outgoing secretary general of the United Nations, Ban Ki-moon, published a memo following up the inquiry he instigated last year into the death, nearly 55 years ago, of one of his predecessors in the role, the Swedish diplomat Dag Hammarskjold. Hammarskjold perished, along with his entourage, just after midnight on Sept. 18, 1961, when his chartered airliner crashed near Ndola, in what was then Northern Rhodesia, now Zambia.

title: Chinese Companys Payment to Lawmaker Sets Off Furor in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia  An Australian senator who accepted a donation from a Chinese company and used it to cover travel expenses has provoked charges in the country that foreign donors are buying political influence.

title: Announcing Our 2016-17 Student Contest Calendar
description: Update: We have created a new version of this post on our new site. You can find all our updates there.

title: Welcome to School Year 2016-17
description: The Learning Network, which began as a New York Times subsite in September 1998 and became a blog in 2009, marks its 18th birthday this month.

title: Madrid for Kids? Try D.I.Y. Spanish Immersion
description: Like many first-generation Americans my age, I learned Spanish on the fly. My Panamanian mother spoke to my brother and me in Spanish. We answered in English. Back then, in New York City in the late 1970s and 80s, being able to speak flawless English was a prize. When people complimented me on how well I spoke, my family members beamed.

title: In Europe, Three Cities, Three Fashion Weeks
description: Even the cocktails will be stylish. Following New York Fashion Week: the shows, being held from Sept. 8 to 15, London, Milan and Paris celebrate spring 2017 fashion with their own events. The runway aside, theres plenty going on in hotels in each city where travelers and locals alike can get a taste of the scene without attending an actual, invitation-only show. Its a nice way to feel, well, fashionable.

title: Neon Makes a Point at the U.S. Open
description: Blame it on its proximity to New York Fashion Week, which officially starts on Thursday (unofficially, it starts on Wednesday), but the United States Open (which started last week) has always attracted a disproportionate amount of style scrutiny. It tends to focus on ways in which tennis imitates fashion, with players calling center court their runway, discussing their evening dress and acknowledging their awareness of trends. But for anyone who spent the holiday weekend watching the tournament at Arthur Ashe Stadium, theres been a lesson in fashion to take away from the tennis  especially when it comes to the athleisure end.

title: Cassia
description: Balanced flavors at the chef Bryant Ngs latest restaurant in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Our Restaurant Critic Goes National. First Stop: California.
description: Editors Note: The Times has published starred reviews of restaurants in the New York metropolitan area since 1963. Starting today, we will occasionally offer such reviews of restaurants in other cities as well, applying the same standards that govern our reviews in New York: a minimum of three anonymous visits to the restaurant.

title: California Today: Your Voices
description: Good morning.

title: 2 Pipeline Companies, Enbridge and Spectra Energy, to Merge
description: Two pipeline companies agreed on Tuesday to merge in a deal that could create the largest energy-infrastructure company in North America.

title: Keith Vaz, British Lawmaker, Quits Senior Post Amid Sex and Drug Scandal
description: LONDON  Caught in what appeared to be a classic British newspaper expos, an opposition lawmaker on Tuesday relinquished leadership of an influential parliamentary committee over allegations that he paid for the services of prostitutes and offered to buy drugs for them.

title: The Giant Panda Is No Longer Endangered. Its Vulnerable.
description: The giant panda has long languished on the endangered species list, but an international monitoring group finally had some good news for it over the weekend.

title: Volkswagen Takes Minority Stake in Truck Maker Navistar
description: LONDON  Volkswagen said on Tuesday that its truck and bus business had agreed to acquire a 16.6 percent stake in the Navistar International Corporation, an American commercial truck maker, giving it a greater access to the North American commercial vehicle market.

title: New National Poll Shows Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Essentially Tied
description: A national poll released Tuesday shows that Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton are entering the final stretch of the presidential race essentially tied, and the survey revealed a country deeply divided on a racial and gender lines ahead of the November election.

title: Dan Kluger Steps Out on His Own
description: On a muggy summer afternoon at his home in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., Dan Kluger stood watch as stalks of broccoli soaked up smoke on a backyard grill. Stout of frame and sweaty of brow, he looked more like a workaday suburban dad, which he is, than a celebrity chef, which he has never exactly pretended to be.

title: Geologist Sees Clues, and Further Dangers, in Puzzle of Oklahomas Earthquakes
description: Scientists and regulators agree that earthquakes like the 5.6-magnitude tremor that struck Oklahoma on Saturday, and thousands of smaller ones in recent years, have been spurred by the disposal of millions of tons of wastewater that is pumped to the surface, and then injected back into the ground, during oil and gas production. The  shock last week tied a record set in 2011 in Prague, Okla., for the strongest such tremor in the states history.

title: 1966: Verwoerd Assassinated
description: The funeral in 1966 of Prime Minister Hendrik Verwoerd of South Africa. British Path.

title: Guerrilla Art Exhibit Unmasks the Face of Terrorism
description: TEL AVIV  Eight months after the attack, the killers face hovered over Dizengoff Street again, full of menace and malevolence.

title: In the Land of the Robot, Androids Are on the March
description: Meet Chihira Junco, a tourist greeter at a shopping mall in Tokyo. In her crisp blue button-down shirt, white blazer and pinstripe skirt, she stands in sensible pumps behind a counter in Aqua City Odaiba on Tokyo Bay, dispensing directions to local sites and shops in Japanese, Chinese and English.

title: Freddie Mercury Now Races Around the Sun
description: Freddie Mercury, the lead singer of the 1970s rock group Queen, already shared his name with one celestial body, but another has been added to the list.

title: Fox Settles With Gretchen Carlson Over Roger Ailes Sex Harassment Claims
description: Fox Newss parent company spent $20 million on Tuesday to settle a lawsuit brought by a former anchor, Gretchen Carlson, whose allegations of sexual harassment toppled the networks powerful chairman, Roger Ailes, and engulfed the company in crisis.

title: La Newyorkina to Open Its First Shop for Mexican Sweets
description: Fany Gerson is waiting on a delivery of garrafas from Mexico. Once they arrive, shell use the wooden barrels lined with metal cylinders to make the ice cream called nieve de garrafa.

title: Valls critique un article du New York Times donnant la parole aux musulmanes
description: Le premier ministre franais, Manuel Valls, a vivement critiqu ce lundi un article du New York Times dans lequel des femmes musulmanes franaises dcrivent tre ostracises par des non-musulmans, victimes de discrimination  lemploi et se sentir perscutes.

title: Police Officer Is Fired a Year After Fatal Shooting of South Carolina Teenager
description: A South Carolina police lieutenant who fatally shot a 19-year-old man during an attempted drug arrest in a Hardees parking lot last year has been fired from his job, the police chief said. The officer contended that he was acting in self-defense when the suspect drove a car toward him.

title: U.N. Chief Presses to Unlock Mystery of Dag Hammarskjolds Death
description: LONDON  A few days from now, the anniversary of one of the most enduring international mysteries will slide by, hardly likely to be marked by those in Britain and the United States accused of withholding the secret clues to its resolution.

title: Narcos Season 2, Episode 5: No Turning Back
description: Theres an absurd sequence in The Enemies of My Enemy that can at least be salvaged as metaphor. With Col. Horacio Carrillo, the leader of Search Bloc, out of the picture, the official operation to capture or kill Pablo Escobar has not only lost the tip of its spear, but it also barely has a stick left for poking. The D.E.A. agents continue to gather information and surveillance, but protocol keeps them chained to their desks, compiling folders of classified information without anyone to act on the intelligence. And yet, remarkably, theres a shot of Pea entering Carrillos office and delivering the documents anyway, like an old habit he hasnt thought to break. Enter Murphys voice-over narration, lamenting that the hunt for Escobar had been reduced to a growing stack of unread files on a dead mans desk.

title: The New Union Square Cafe
description: The restaurateur Danny Meyer rebuilds his signature restaurant in a new location on Park Avenue South.

title: The Same, Only Different: Designing a New Union Square Cafe
description: On a clear February morning, executives from Union Square Hospitality Group and several architects sipped hot coffee and milled around a table in the partly demolished remains of a shuttered restaurant, waiting for Danny Meyer.

title: New Karachi Mayor Gets Daytrip From Prison to Be Sworn In
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  The yellow-walled, colonial-era central prison in Karachi houses some of the citys hardened criminals, but one of its inmates, Waseem Akhtar, still has a day job: Hes the mayor of Pakistans biggest and most tumultuous city.

title: 1941: Frenchmen Are Executed
description: VICHY  Three French men were shot at dawn today [Sept. 6] by the German military authorities of Paris in reprisal for the shooting and slight wounding of a German sergeant near the East railroad station in Paris Wednesday night. Notice of this grim deed was communicated to the Paris population by a two-column announcement appearing on the front pages of all the Paris newspapers this morning [Sept. 6]. The act was said to be the fulfillment of the threat, made by the Germans after the killing of a Nazi ensign in a Paris subway, that they would regard all French civilians held in detention by them as hostages liable to be shot without notice if any further attempts were made on the lives of German soldiers.  New York Herald Tribune, Sept. 7, 1941

title: Living in Two Time Zones With Google Calendar
description: Q. Is it possible to show more than one time zone in Google Calendar to help find workable meeting times with two distant offices?

title: Sullivan & Cromwell Hires Online Security Specialist
description: Sullivan & Cromwell, a big law firm known for advising major financial institutions, is taking steps to bolster its work in an area of particular concern to large banks: online security.

title: Daily Report: IPhone Season Is Here, but These Days, Surprises Are Rare
description: Its September, which means (drumroll) its iPhone time.

title: Driscolls Aims to Hook the Berry-Buying Shopper
description: WATSONVILLE, Calif.  On 40 acres at a farm near the central coast of California, new varieties of strawberries, raspberries, blackberries and blueberries are being tested, each of them proprietary. No other company in the world grows berries exactly like these.

title: Whistle-Blowing Insiders: Game Changer for the S.E.C.
description: Although there have been many complaints about the Dodd-Frank Act, one area generally hailed as a success is the whistle-blowing program at the Securities and Exchange Commission. Since the programs creation in 2011, the S.E.C. has received more than 14,000 tips, including almost 4,000 last year.

description: Beyoncs big voice needs a break.

description: With a 6-4, 6-3, 6-3 victory over his French countryman Lucas Pouille on Tuesday, Gal Monfils rolled into his first United States Open semifinal, having not lost a set in the tournament.
