title: Art and Science Meld as NASA Announces a New Artist Collaboration
description: Were not used to computing the scale of a 100,000-year-old piece of ice the size of California thats going to break off from an ice sheet, said the artist and photojournalist Justin Guariglia. Last year, he talked his way on board a NASA mission in Greenland and shot pictures of melting glaciers and sea ices through the drop window of the military transport plane flying very low in the troposphere.

title: Wells Fargo Scandal May Be Sign of a Poisonous Culture
description: Let me get this straight: Some 5,300 employees and managers at Wells Fargos retail banking division knowingly opened millions of unauthorized accounts in the names of their customers, are rightly fired as a result, but the senior executives at the bank responsible for them and their reprehensible behavior are not? What year is this? 1928? 2007? Or is this 2016, eight years after the crucible moments leading up to one of the worst financial crises in our collective lifetimes?

title: In the Studio With Katie Roberts-Wood
description: A visit to the workspace of the young designer, who presents her first official collection during London Fashion Week this weekend.

title: A Romantic British Designer, Inspired by Science
description: Katie Roberts-Woods studio is furrowed away in an industrial building in Regents Canal in London. As the evening is settling and commuters are cycling home along the water, the designers helpers sit outside painting paillettes of leather for her sculptural designs. It is a week before her London Fashion Week debut, and she has already finished her collection and shot the lookbook  not bad, considering all of these pieces are produced by hand here in her atelier.

title: Hillary Clintons Backers Thought She Couldnt Lose. Now, I Cant Go There.
description: Beside the olive display at Zabars, that iconic hub of lox and neurosis on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, Linda Donohue was trying to talk herself down.

title: What San Francisco Says About America
description: San Francisco  AFTER more than 27 years abroad, mostly as a foreign correspondent in Asia covering civil unrest and poverty, I wander the streets of this city, my new home, like an enchanted tourist.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from Argentina to New Jersey, for the Senior Olympics.

title: Popcast: Fall Preview
description: The pop music team discusses some of their favorite upcoming fall releases.

title: Popcast: What Will We Be Listening to This Fall?
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

title: Despite His Doubters, Canelo lvarez Humbly Fights for Mexico
description: GRAPEVINE, Tex.  The mariachi band played with unmistakable pride. Fans screamed, desperately scrambling to get a glimpse of their hero.

title: Brooklyn Bridge Parks Long Path to Development
description: The redevelopment of the World Trade Center site since 2001 has produced a number of tomes. Lynne B. Sagalyns Power at Ground Zero is already being hailed as a definitive history and a classic in urban studies. Two new books explore a somewhat less visible site across the East River, focusing on the tortured incubation of Brooklyn Bridge Park, which took even longer to develop but produced a 1.3-mile waterfront gem.

title: The Florists Fashion Designers Love in New York, London, Milan and Paris
description: They send giant bouquets to special clients, keep fresh-cut stems on hand and have been known to create larger-than-life flower installations for shows and presentations: Fashion designers have long relied heavily on florists. T polled houses in the four fashion capitals to find out which florists they order from  and why.

title: Life in the Shadows of War
description: People go about their day in Waer, the last rebel-held enclave in the central city of Homs, Syria, during the cease-fire between the government and its opposition.

title: How Dan White, a Magician, Spends His Sundays
description: How in the world did Dan White manage to levitate his assistant, dressed in a long white gown and surrounded on three sides by spectators, almost three feet in the air? Audiences may never know, but people continue to flock to The Magician, Mr. Whites old-school magic show featuring mind reading, far-from-ordinary card tricks, and other acts, Thursdays through Saturdays at the NoMad Hotel in the Flatiron district. On Sundays, Mr. White, 35, practices parts of his routine, but also uses the time to relax with his fiance, Susie Bray. They live in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, with their toy poodle, Gracie.

title: Less Than Transparent: Journalists Fault Obama
description: To the Editor:

title: Donald Trumps Rise in the Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Gallery Will Open at the Museum at Eldridge Street
description: A new gallery space within the Museum at Eldridge Street will open on Sunday with Kaddish for Dabrowa Bialostocka, 18 works by the artist Mark Podwal.

title: Three Young Photography Stars, Tapped by Gursky
description: Andreas Gursky has long been the subject of exhibitions; since the German photographer and Kunstakademie Dsseldorf professors first solo outing in the late 1980s, his large-format images have been mounted in the Museum of Modern Art, Pariss Centre Pompidou, the Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofa in Madrid and the United Arab Emirates Sharjah Art Museum, to list a few. But this weekend, Gursky picks up the mantle of curator, with the opening of Louisa Clement, Anna Vogel, Moritz Wegwerth, featuring three of his former students, at Sprth Magers Berlin. While he has organized the end-of-semester presentations (Akademierundgnge) at the academy, he has never coordinated a museum or gallery show until now. He says he gladly accepted the special task, explaining, I am not curating artworks of students, but individual artistic personalities who pursue their artistic path with strong commitment. Here, Clement, Vogel and Wegwerth discuss their practices  and their former teacher.

title: How I Spent My New York Fashion Week
description: Observations and scribbles from the margins of a fashion reporters notebook.

title: U.S. Special Operations Forces Arrive in Syria to Advise Turks in ISIS Fight
description: WASHINGTON  American Special Operations forces have arrived in northern Syria to work alongside Turkish troops fighting the Islamic State, the Pentagon said on Friday, stressing that the approximately three dozen Americans would serve in an advise and assist capacity.

title: Transformation on Brooklyns Southern Shore
description: When Hurricane Sandy lashed the New York coastline and drowned neighborhoods like Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, there was some chatter about retreating from the waterfront.

title: Almost as Much to Watch as to Hear: Mighty Organ Pieces
description: With all the wonderful and distinctive organs New York has to offer, you might have wished that Paul Jacobs had played his recital on Wednesday evening on something other than the modest Holtkamp instrument in Paul Hall at the Juilliard School. The program, after all, included what Mr. Jacobs, in preliminary remarks, called two of the mightiest organ works of the 19th century: Franz Liszts Fantasy and Fugue on Ad nos, ad salutarem undam and Julius Reubkes Sonata in C minor.

title: After 30 Years, Pete Hamill Returns to Brooklyn
description: As a native Brooklynite, Pete Hamill figures he is entitled to disagree about the borough with his fellow novelist Thomas Wolfe, who lived there for less than a decade during the 1930s.

title: Why Is Penn State Celebrating Joe Paterno?
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  Before Lauren Davis finished writing her editorial about Joe Paterno for The Daily Collegian, Penn States student-run newspaper, she braced for the response.

title: 5 Highlights From the London Design Festival
description: T's picks among more than 400 design events happening throughout the city.

title: Sewage Overflow Again Fouls Tampa Bay After Storm
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  When Hurricane Hermine bowled onto Floridas Gulf Coast this month, officials in this city were confronted with a familiar problem: The hurricane and days of rain before it had overloaded St. Petersburgs water pipes and treatment tanks so there was no room for the citys waste.

title: Preparing Your Home for Sale
description: When youve decided to sell your home, the last thing you want to do is spend money to spruce the place up. After all, whoever buys it is going to replace those outdated kitchen cabinets and grungy bathroom tiles anyway, right?

title: Gary Johnson and Jill Stein Fail to Make Cut for First Debate
description: The first presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump this month will exclude two leading third-party nominees  Gary Johnson of the Libertarian Party and the Green Partys Jill Stein  the Commission on Presidential Debates announced on Friday.

title: Jean Paul Gaultiers Fantastical Imagination
description: BERLIN  Who is in charge of the feathers? the designer Jean Paul Gaultier shouted on a July day as about 20 people scurried around him in the costume workshop at the Friedrichstadt-Palast theater.

title: The Difference Between Rationality and Intelligence
description: ARE you intelligent  or rational? The question may sound redundant, but in recent years researchers have demonstrated just how distinct those two cognitive attributes actually are.

title: Inspired by the U.S., West Africans Wield Smartphones to Fight Police Abuse
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The YouTube video shows a grim scene from Ivory Coast: An unarmed man lies on a street with his arms up. A police officer fires a shot that appears to strike him.

title: The Playlist: Kim Gordon Vents and the White Stripes Unleash an Outtake
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing  in the Playlist. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this format? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com.

title: F.B.I. Impersonation of Journalist Did Not Violate Undercover Policies, Federal Watchdog Says
description: An F.B.I. agent did not violate the agencys undercover policy by posing as a journalist nearly a decade ago during an investigation, a federal watchdog has concluded, despite criticism by journalists that the practice is harmful to the news-gathering process.

title: Trendspotting Floral Looks
description: Floral looks spring 2017 collections.

title: Designers Toss Petals Into the Style Mix
description: On the runways of New York Fashion Week, flowers clashed incongruously with spots and stripes. They wound in and out of latticework grids and collided irreverently with animal prints.

title: Attacks in a British Town Highlight a Debate Over Ethnic Tensions
description: HARLOW, England  Perceptions of what happened that night, when a Polish immigrant was killed in a fight with a gang of British teenagers, depend on who is talking, and what they saw.

title: Disney Hires Rosenblum to Reinforce Television Division
description: LOS ANGELES  The Disney ABC Television Group, grappling with industrywide upheaval in viewing and delivery, on Friday moved to reinforce its senior management team.

title: Some Republicans Acknowledge Leveraging Voter ID Laws for Political Gain
description: As one prominent and much beloved Republican once said  actually, repeatedly said  There you go again.

title: Watch a 101-Year-Old Painter Argue Against Talking About Art
description: Last year, T ran a very popular story rounding up a number of female artists who have continued to create  and in some cases, have only just begun to receive critical attention  late in life, well into their 70s, 80s and 90s. The oldest among them, the Cuban-American minimalist painter Carmen Herrera, turned 101 in May, and if anything, her star has only risen since our story was published. She had a show in May inaugurating the new New York outpost of Lisson Gallery; and today, the Whitney opens a solo show focusing on her work from 1948 to 1978. Its auspicious timing for the release, on Netflix, of a new documentary about the artist by the award-winning filmmaker Alison Klayman (known most recently for Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry), an exclusive clip from which premieres above. In it, Herrera makes the case for artists not talking too much about their work: You cannot talk about art; you have to art about art, she says, smiling (and lightly pounding a desk for emphasis).

title: Review: Crackskull Row, an Irish Gothic With Masher, Basher and Rasher
description: You might expect the 2016 edition of Origins 1st Irish Festival to kick off with an upbeat paean to Ireland. Instead we have Honor Molloys grotesque but richly satisfying drama Crackskull Row, at the Theater Workshop.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Marshall Project

title: Review: One Birthday Tribute (of Many) for Steve Reich
description: The Queen of England has two birthdays each year: one actual, one official. The composer Steve Reich  American new-music royalty, if such a thing were constitutional  turns 80 next month, but celebrations have been so ubiquitous that they sometimes seem to blur into one big parade.

title: With Ceremony, William Bratton Ends 2nd Stint as New Yorks Police Leader
description: William J. Bratton marked his final day as New York City police commissioner on Friday by strolling through a receiving line of hundreds of officers, a joyful smile on his face as he exited Police Headquarters to applause and the wail of bagpipes, which all but drowned out a small number of protesters.

title: Subway Singer Gets Her Big Break
description: Alice Tan Ridley, the mother of the Oscar-nominated actress Gabourey Sidibe, has been singing in the subway system for 30 years. She will soon perform at the Highline Ballroom in Chelsea, in connection with the release of her debut album.

title: After Years Underground, a Subway Singer Gets the Spotlight
description: Alice Tan Ridley sat before the mirror in her Harlem apartment. She brushed on gold eye shadow, took an auburn wig off a mannequins head and put it on. I really, really dont know what Im doing, she said, laughing. I never used to wear makeup at all. And I never wore wigs. I just braided my hair in teeny braids that would hang when Id get wet.

title: The Best Street Style at New York Fashion Week
description: Our favorite looks from the people at this seasons shows.

title: Prince Memorial Concert to Feature Stevie Wonder and Others
description: In late July, three months after Prince died of an accidental overdose of the opioid painkiller fentanyl, the musicians sister, Tyka Nelson, announced that a public memorial concert would be held at the U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis on Oct. 13. Less than a month before that date, the performers for the show have finally been announced, but the place has shifted  to the considerably smaller Xcel Energy Center in St. Paul.

title: European Leaders Debate Proposals for Closer Military Ties
description: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia  At a moment when many voters across the Continent want national governments to reclaim power from Brussels, the leaders of 27 European Union countries debated proposals Friday that would move in the other direction by creating a joint European military headquarters and increase cooperation among their armed forces.

title: Cameron Crowes Show Roadies Has Been Canceled
description: Roadies, Showtimes behind-the-scenes music drama from Cameron Crowe, has been canceled after one season. Mr. Crowe announced the news on his website.

title: The Best Street Style at New York Fashion Week
description: New York Fashion Week is over, but the street style lives on. Here are some of our favorite moments from outside the shows.

title: How the Marc Jacobs Fashion Show Came Together
description: T trailed the Marc Jacobs show adviser Katie Grand during the 48 hours leading up to the runway in New York.

title: 48 Hours Before the Marc Jacobs Show, With Katie Grand
description: We are really late, said Katie Grand, the stylist and adviser behind Marc Jacobss biannual womens wear shows. Everyone says that every season, but this is especially, especially late. To underline the point, it was a little more than 48 hours before Jacobss spring/summer 2017 runway, yet very little of the collection was hanging on the rails of Jacobss Spring Street studio. Jacobs himself was on his knees on the floor, chopping into a printed chiffon dress. A few boxes held towering platform boots in a fistful of gummy bear colors. There wasnt much else around.

title: Canada Today: Searchers Find a Shipwreck, and Conservatives Seek a Leader
description: Were trying something new: Canada Today, a weekly roundup for Canadian readers and anyone else interested in the True North. Tell us what you think and what youd like to see, at CanadaToday@nytimes.com. And please subscribe to the email newsletter version, which is coming soon.

title: Arctic Summer Sea Ice  Going Down, Down, Down
description: The vast, scrabbly sheath of sea ice drifting on the Arctic Ocean ended its annual summer retreat this week, and the result was sobering. This year tied with 2007 as having the second smallest ice extent ever recorded, the National Snow and Ice Data Center announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Presidential Race, Syria, William Bratton: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Donald Trump Scorns TV Networks. For Once, They Return the Favor.
description: Simmering tension between Donald J. Trump and the television networks that cover him entered an extraordinary new phase on Friday, as a consortium of news executives refused to participate in a media session with Mr. Trump after his aides barred a producer from attending.

title: How Do I Get Out of Here?
description: Dear Diary:

title: Bill to Shield International Art Loans Gains in Senate
description: Legislation to safeguard international art loans will be taken up by the full Senate after years of criticism and complaints that the bill amounts to protection for plundered works.

title: Whos Too Young for an App? Musical.ly Tests the Limits
description: In the folklore of the start-up world, few figures loom larger than the teenager. Teenagers see the future, set trends and spend money, or compel parents to spend it for them. Their behavior has become an obsession for entrepreneurs.

title: Time Traveling at the Toronto Film Festival
description: TORONTO  In his terrific new documentary, Into the Inferno, Werner Herzog leads you to the edge of the red-hot abyss, using airborne cameras, philosophical asides and his boundless interest in the depths of human mystery. Written, directed and narrated by Mr. Herzog, the movie takes you to volcanoes across the globe  from Iceland to Ethiopia and North Korea  in a voyage into wonders and terrors. During this expedition, you discover that North Korean lore asserts that the nations founder, Kim Il Sung, led the fight for independence at the foot of Mt. Paektu, using a log cabin with the optics of an Abraham Lincoln shrine and the sacredness of a Bethlehem manger.

title: Rags, Tea and Advice as Syrians Fret Over Cease-Fire
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The weeklong vacation for the Muslim holiday of Eid al-Adha is nearing an end, and the partial cease-fire that began on Monday night is showing signs of fraying.

title: Poll Finds Most Voters Embrace Milestone for Women, if Not Hillary Clinton
description: On Nov. 8, American voters for the first time in history will see a womans name on the ballot as a major partys nominee for president. A broad majority of voters  men and women  say they are happy this milestone has been reached, but fully half of them say they would have preferred that that first woman not be Hillary Clinton, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: How the New York Times/CBS News Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Sept. 9 through 13 with 1,770 adults throughout the United States. Of those, 865 were women and 905 were men.

title: Donald Trumps Cynical Play for Womens Votes
description: Donald Trump has spent the last week attempting to erase his huge deficits among female voters.

title: A New York Times/CBS News Poll on a Woman for President
description: The poll looked closely at womens political views and broader outlook on American life, as well as how the wider society views the role of women.

title: Actually, Income in Rural America Is Growing, Too
description: On Tuesday, when the Census Bureau released one of the countrys most important reports on income and poverty, dozens of facts were revealed. We found out that real middle-class incomes in America grew a phenomenal 5.2 percent, and that the poverty rate fell by the largest percentage in nearly 50 years.

title: The Top 10 Moments From New York Fashion Week
description: Kanye West's three-hour show, direct-to-consumer fashion  and so much more.

title: Judge Clears 7 Chimps for Departure. Theyre Off to England.
description: For almost two years, the Yerkes National Primate Research Center at Emory University has been working to send seven chimpanzees to a zoo in England, prompting the outrage of several animal welfare and conservation groups because the zoo is unaccredited and there are American sanctuaries ready to accept the chimps.

title: I Wrote That? Playwrights Look Back at Their Teenage Work
description: Neil LaBute, Lynn Nottage and other stage notables take a peek at their early plays (often written in their teens). They werent all brilliant.

title: A Two-Mile Beer Pipeline Carries Belgiums Lifeblood to Be Bottled
description: Beneath the gilded spires and medieval cobblestone streets of Bruges, the lifeblood of Belgium now flows at more than 1,000 gallons an hour.

title: Jason Pierre-Paul May Miss Giants Home Opener
description: Although Giants defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul said earlier in the week that his sore shoulder would not keep him out of the teams home opener Sunday against the New Orleans Saints, Coach Ben McAdoo sounded less confident on Friday about Pierre-Pauls availability.

title: Donald Trump Says Hillary Clintons Bodyguards Should Disarm to See What Happens to Her
description: MIAMI  Donald J. Trump once again raised the specter of violence against Hillary Clinton, suggesting Friday that the Secret Service agents who guard her voluntarily disarm to see what happens to her without their protection.

title: Who Is Evil, and Who Is the Victim?
description: This is the eighth in a series of dialogues with philosophers and critical theorists on the question of violence. This conversation is with Simona Forti, a professor of political philosophy at the University of Eastern Piedmont in Italy, and a visiting professor at the New School for Social Research in New York. Her most recent book is New Demons: Rethinking Power and Evil Today.

title: Nigeria Describes 3 Failed Negotiations With Boko Haram on Kidnapped Girls
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Two and a half years after more than 200 girls were kidnapped from a school in northeastern Nigeria, the government on Friday described for the first time the failed efforts to negotiate for their release.

title: Federal Charges for Chicago Officer in Shooting Caught on Video
description: A Chicago police officer is facing federal criminal charges for shooting two black teenagers in 2013, when he fired into a stolen car that was moving away from him in an incident that was recorded on video.

title: Edward Albee, Trenchant Playwright Who Laid Bare Modern Life, Dies at 88
description: Edward Albee, widely considered the foremost American playwright of his generation, whose psychologically astute and piercing dramas explored the contentiousness of intimacy, the gap between self-delusion and truth and the roiling desperation beneath the facade of contemporary life, died on Friday at his home in Montauk, N.Y. He was 88.

title: Governors Views Dont Help as Maines Population Dwindles
description: PORTLAND, Me.  Leopold Ndayisabye, a Rwandan immigrant who works as a caseworker, has watched refugees, asylum seekers and other immigrants move to this city, fill health care jobs, send their children to school and line up to buy goods in the local stores.

title: On a Friday Out, Chelsea Gets the Check and Liverpool Gets the Points
description: LONDON  As early as April  a few days, at most, after Antonio Conte had agreed to take over as Chelseas manager this summer  word was starting to echo around Europe that Conte believed he would urgently require a central defender upon his arrival in England.

title: The Shady History of Big Sugar
description: Charlottesville, Va.  On Monday, an article in JAMA Internal Medicine reported that in the 1960s, the sugar industry paid Harvard scientists to publish a study blaming fat and cholesterol for coronary heart disease while largely exculpating sugar. This study, published in the prestigious New England Journal of Medicine in 1967, helped set the agenda for decades of public health policy designed to steer Americans into low-fat foods, which increased carbohydrate consumption and exacerbated our obesity epidemic.

title: U.N. Meeting a Farewell for Obama, and a Dress Rehearsal for Clinton
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will use his final appearance at the United Nations General Assembly next week to extol the benefits of his brand of multilateral diplomacy, even as the gathering will lay bare places where that diplomacy has fallen short.

title: Michelle Obama Makes Ardent Case for Hillary Clinton
description: FAIRFAX, Va.  Michelle Obama on Friday issued a cutting critique of Donald J. Trump as an unserious and dangerously unprepared candidate for president, making a rare appearance on the campaign trail to plead with young voters to support Hillary Clinton and extend her husbands legacy.

title: As Shelter Population Surges, Housing for Disabled Comes Up Short
description: Alison Phillipss feet dragged beneath her as she used forearm crutches to make her way down a ramp, leaving the Brooklyn homeless shelter where she and her 3-year-old daughter live.

title: Judge Rejects Justice Department Ruling on Music Licensing
description: A federal judge on Friday rejected a recent Justice Department ruling on music licensing in a move that was immediately hailed by the music industry as a major victory.

title: Donald Trumps Latest Birther Lie
description: The midday bulletin arrived as another bizarre moment in the absurdist presidential campaign of Donald Trump: News Alert: Trump admits Obama was born in the United States.

title: Trump Makes His Birther Lie Worse
description: Wow. Donald Trump says President Obama was born here. What a concession. No wonder hes trending up in the polls.

title: Violence Flares With 4 Attacks on Israelis in Jerusalem and West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  A wave of violence that had subsided in recent months flared up again on Friday as four attacks in Jerusalem and the West Bank within 24 hours underscored the edgy mood between Israelis and Palestinians.

title: South Sudan Rejects Report on Leaders Wealth
description: The government of South Sudan on Friday denounced what it called a groundless report that accuses the president and other figures engaged in the countrys civil war of fomenting violence in order to amass illegal wealth.

title: A Russian-Iranian Axis
description: WASHINGTON  THE partial cease-fire in Syrias civil war is welcome news. But it must not be allowed to obscure a dangerous new development  the emergence from the war of a Russian-Iranian military axis that could upset hopes for stability in the Middle East, and for containing Russias global ambitions, into the future.

title: For the Ages
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  So does everyone agree that puzzles keep the mind young? Accepting that an old mind goes brittle and slow, develops holes in ones memory, settles into its ruts of ruminative repetition... and so on. I ask this (rhetorically, I hope) because I fell off the game wagon this summer for various reasons and Im finding it a challenge to get my focus back, like exercising out-of-shape muscles.

title: The Last Word: Edward Albee
description: Edward Albee was one of America's most important and influential playwrights. In this never-before-seen Last Word interview, he discusses his life and work.

title: The Contest Over Israel Aid
description: Even before the ink was dry on the new 10-year, $38 billion defense agreement between Israel and the United States, Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina threw down the gauntlet and promised to fight the Obama administration over key elements of the deal, including its size. Mr. Graham wants Congress to approve billions more.

title: Viral Sex Tapes and a Suicide Prompt Outrage in Italy
description: ROME  The suicide of an Italian woman who fought a long court battle to get videos of her having sex removed from the web has rekindled a national debate on the perils of social media and the internet.

title: Red Sox David Ortiz, Thorn in Yankees Side for a Bit Longer, Digs Into Them Again
description: BOSTON  David Ortiz stood outside the Red Sox clubhouse before Friday nights game wearing a pair of red, white and blue shorts adorned with stars and stripes and a T-shirt depicting the Citgo sign outside Fenway Park with the word Strong written underneath.

title: Mets and Colon Prevail in a Shutout Win Over the Twins
description: Mets Manager Terry Collins told his players after the conclusion of their previous series against the Washington Nationals that there was no time to relax despite the cushy schedule awaiting them over the final two weeks of the season.

title: A Formula to Make Bail More Fair
description: Judges in San Franciscos courts long used a fixed schedule based on the criminal charge as a starting point for setting bail. Too often, this system left defendants who posed little risk to the community sitting in jail because they couldnt afford bail.

title: From Women, Skepticism About Marriage and a Hunger for Workplace Equality
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll took a reading on the attitudes of American women on a range of topics, from politics to opportunities in the workplace to their overall level of satisfaction in life. We called back a number of them to talk further and also consulted some experts about the challenges facing women today. Here are some of their voices.

title: A Staten Island Mosque Mixes Prayer and Patriotism
description: The man stood at the podium in the cramped Masjid Un-Noor mosque on Staten Island as hundreds of Muslims sat barefoot on the carpet before him, facing east, just before the start of Friday prayers. In his outstretched right hand, he held up a tiny American flag and a pocket-size copy of the Constitution.

title: Joseph B. Keller, Mathematician With Whimsical Curiosity, Dies at 93
description: Joseph B. Keller, an honored mathematician who figured out what makes a joggers ponytail swing from side to side, why teapots dribble, how earthworms (but not snakes) can wriggle even on glass and, in his spare time, whether underwater nuclear tests could set off tsunamis, died on Sept. 7 at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 93.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: We got the idea from looking at other life provisions that run through pipes. Water pipes, electricity pipes, cable distribution, etc. So why wouldnt that be possible for beer?

title: Del Potro Beats Murray in Davis Cup Match
description: Argentina took a 2-0 lead over Britain, the defending champion, in a Davis Cup semifinal in Glasgow on Friday as Juan Martn del Potro defeated Andy Murray in five sets (and more than five hours) and Guido Pella beat Kyle Edmund in four. At 5 hours 7 minutes, the Murray match was the longest of both players careers.

title: Corrections: September 17, 2016
description: NATIONAL

title: Whats on TV Saturday: The Revenant and The Beatles: Eight Days a Week
description: The Revenant, starring Leonardo DiCaprio in his Oscar-winning role, comes to cable. Ron Howard tries to seduce millennials into loving the Beatles. And revisit The Ranch before the second half of Season 1 arrives.

title: A Lie Too Far?
description: I suspect Donald Trump is feeling a bit sandbagged right now, or will be when he wakes up. All along he has treated the news media with contempt, and been rewarded with obsequious deference  his lies sugar-coated, described as disputed or stretching the truth, while every aspect of his opponents life is described as raising questions and casting shadows, despite lack of evidence that she did anything wrong.

title: Her Condescending Dismissal .... Is What Is Deplorable
description: Here are top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

title: A Sour Surprise for Public Pensions: Two Sets of Books
description: When one of the tiniest pension funds imaginable  for Citrus Pest Control District No. 2, serving just six people in California  decided last year to convert itself to a 401(k) plan, it seemed like a no-brainer.

title: For Fall, Seven Notable New Hotels
description: Its a new season with new hotel openings. Although fall usually sees a glut of splashy properties making their debut, thats not the story line this year, according to the hotel specialist Bobby Zur, who owns Travel Artistry, a consultancy in Franklin Lakes, N.J. Its not uncommon for hotels to delay their openings, but the holdups are especially pronounced this fall for a number of reasons including the U.S. elections, European volatility and concerns over Zika, he said.

title: The Eternal Struggle of the Empty Nester
description: The etiquette of the empty nest can bedevil even the most sophisticated parent. Take, for instance, the actress Alfre Woodard. Ms. Woodard said that when her younger child (her son, Duncan) went to college in 2012, her depression caught her in a bind.

title: Cynthia Erivo Takes on a New Role: Fashion Diva
description: Cynthia Erivo took a long, level look at her reflection in the V.I.P. room at the Tory Burch shop on Madison Avenue last week. She was trying on, and casting off, a succession of frocks before eventually settling on the ensemble she would wear to Ms. Burchs spring show on Tuesday.

title: Want to Find Fulfillment at Last? Think Like a Designer
description: STANFORD, CALIF.  Take out your flow journals. Were going to talk about flow moments.

title: Elizabeth Warren and Tracee Ellis Ross on the Road to Activism
description: Tracee Ellis Ross may be working 14 hours a day in Los Angeles on her hit TV show, black-ish. But when Elizabeth Warren says shell have dinner with you, Ms. Ross said, walking into a suite at the Hay-Adams Hotel in Washington, you get on a plane. I have a million questions for her.

title: Abu Sayyaf Militants Release Norwegian Hostage in Philippines
description: MANILA  The Abu Sayyaf militant group freed a Norwegian hostage in the southern Philippines on Saturday, the police said, almost a year after he was seized along with two Canadians who were later beheaded.

title: A Little Variety
description: VARIETY PUZZLES  This weeks puzzles include:

title: JZ Holden and Jules Feiffer: Humor and Truth Spark Outrage, Then a Union
description: J Z Holden and Jules Feiffer are to be married on Sept. 18 at the home of Judith Hudson, a friend of the couple in Amagansett, N.Y. Mary Faith Westervelt, a town justice for Shelter Island, N.Y., is to officiate at a ceremony that will combine Jewish and Buddhist traditions and will be led by Monte Farber, a friend of the bride who is also a Universal Life minister.

title: Vanessa Dube and Gary Le: Surviving a First Date at a Burlesque Show
description: Vanessa Jeanne Dube, a daughter of Jeanne Marie Forte Dube of New York and Gregory R. Dube of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., was married Sept. 17 to Gary Dat Le, a son of Tammy D. Le and Scott C. Le of Seattle. Frances Kissling, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at 620 Loft and Garden, an event space at Rockefeller Center in New York.

title: His Grip Still Secure, Bashar al-Assad Smiles as Syria Burns
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  On the day after his 51st birthday, Bashar al-Assad, the president of Syria, took a victory lap through the dusty streets of a destroyed and empty rebel town that his forces had starved into submission.

title: Farhads and Pauls Week in Tech: Apples China Conundrum and Samsungs Recall Conundrum
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mike is off this week, so Paul Mozur, the Timess Asia technology correspondent, stepped in.

title: Readers Stories About Race and Education
description: Our Race/Related reporting project asked for your stories about race and education. Here are excerpts of what a handful of parents, teachers and students of pre-k  12 had to say about how race and diversity are being discussed in schools and at home.

title: Shared Driveway Parking Problems
description: Q. We have a rent-to-own agreement with our landlord on an attached house in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, with two parking spots and a shared driveway. But our neighbors use the driveway for parking and not as a means of egress. (Their garage is packed with stuff.) And their three adult children block the driveway so we cant access our parking spots  and sometimes cannot even walk along the driveway. The time for friendly reconciliation has passed, as this has festered since 2009. What are our options? Should the landlord step in?

title: Egypt Freezes Assets of Several Human Rights Advocates
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian court dealt a heavy blow to the countrys human rights activists on Saturday by freezing the assets of five prominent human rights defenders and three nongovernmental organizations.

title: Anya Hindmarchs Curated Works for Sothebys
description: The fashion designer talks T through the upcoming auction, which will take place just two days after her London Fashion Week show.

title: For One Designer, an Art Auction to Chase a Fashion Show
description: Art has always been a big part of my life. Its something that Ive constantly engaged with and loved  starting with Fiorucci graphics, says Anya Hindmarch, the sparkly, one-woman powerhouse behind her eponymous British clothing and accessories line. Ahead of her runway bonanza in London this Sunday, the designer has collaborated with the art auction house Sothebys to curate a one-off sale of contemporary works, each handpicked by Hindmarch, and spanning from the postwar period to the present day. I could easily lose myself to the art world, admits the Royal Academy Trustee, who applies her trademark playfulness to the role of curator, even decorating the exhibition space of the historic auction house with speech-bubble emojis. Working on this project has been like a little bit of me-time in the run-up to the show. On view now at Sothebys on New Bond Street, there are sculptural Wolfgang Tillmans, tiny textural Gerhard Richters  and one rare and riotous hot pink Keith Haring thats currently the top lot. The refreshing common denominator? Fun! For an insight into Hindmarchs selection, click through the slideshow below.

title: Trump, Grand Wizard of Birtherism
description: So, on Friday the Grand Wizard of Birtherism against President Obama admitted that birtherism was bunk, not by apologizing for his prominent role in the racist campaign  no, that would have been too right  but by suggesting that he deserved credit for dousing the flames hed fanned.

title: A Chicago Shooting Survivor, but in Need of a Miracle
description: CHICAGO  In a spacious room on the fourth floor of a rehabilitation hospital, Stacey Turner talked to her only daughter, Precious Land, as if she could understand every word. She styled Ms. Lands hair, massaged her hands and set out to paint her fingernails. The only sound was the whirring of a ventilator.

title: Gunman Kills One and Wounds Five, Including 2 Officers, in Philadelphia
description: A gunman killed one person and wounded five others in a rampage on Friday night in Philadelphia that began when he ambushed a police sergeant in her squad car.

title: Spin Class Full? Feel the Burn From Your Living Room
description: On a recent weekday morning, Alex Toussaint, a cycling instructor at Peloton, welcomed people to his 90s hip-hop spin class  50 who were right in front of him, and more than 200 riders who had tuned in from around the country. Pelotons sleek space may look like one of many boutique cycling studios around Manhattan, but it also functions as a film studio, broadcasting to thousands of riders who watch classes from tablets mounted to their Peloton bikes.

title: Variety: The Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Leslie Savans The Sponsored Life: Ads, T.V. and American Culture is a 90s look at the pervasive influence of advertising. I had never heard of this author or book, but fortunately I was able to fill in just enough clues to slowly cobble together the grid. One of my first certain solves, incidentally, was LUFTHANSA based on the advertising line Nonstop you; so I guess Im among the crowd in thrall of the catchy hook.

title: Fashion Week Photo Diary: Ryan Lo and Ashley Williams
description: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented in London on Friday.

title: Padres A. J. Preller Gets a Slap on the Wrist for His Deception
description: The deception of A. J. Preller, the San Diego Padres general manager, who hid medical records from other teams in trade talks, is almost as disturbing as baseballs response to it. Preller was suspended 30 days without pay on Thursday, an inadequate response to a serious ethical breach.

title: Disarming the Food Pushers to Help People Lose Weight
description: Angela Dunn, 33, is a personal coach and receptionist for Weight Watchers International in College Station, Tex.

title: At New York Fashion Week, a Reflection on American Style
description: What is American fashion? I dont mean fashion made in America  that much is obvious (though considering most high fashion in America is manufactured in Italy, thats an interesting point for discussion too). But ideologically, what does it constitute? What makes a collection, or a designer, especially American? To a set of jet-lagged eyes, that seemed to be the question that occupied New York designers in their spring/summer 2017 collections.

title: The Standoff Between Big Oil and Big Corn
description: A decade ago, lawmakers in Washington tried to address a trifecta of thorny challenges with one simple fix that has turned out to be anything but easy to assess.

title: Englands Forgotten Muslim History
description: London  Britain is divided as never before. The country has turned its back on Europe, and its female ruler has her sights set on trade with the East. As much as this sounds like Britain today, it also describes the country in the 16th century, during the golden age of its most famous monarch, Queen Elizabeth I.

title: For Independent League Team, a New Stadium, Indictments and a Title Run
description: RAMAPO, N.Y.  Before the Rockland Boulders season began, their home field was at the center of federal indictments for securities fraud brought by Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York.

title: Swamps, Marijuana, Moonshine: 2 Prison Escapees 3 Weeks on the Run in New York
description: When the two men plunged into the unforgiving wilderness of the Adirondacks, they had scant experience and supplies better suited to boys running away from home than to convicted killers fleeing a maximum-security prison: pepperoni sticks, toilet paper, a cache of black pepper, an electric shaver and 40 granola bars, all packed in a cloth guitar case.

title: Paralympic Athletes Least Favorite Word: Inspiration
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  They hear the word on commercials advertising the Paralympic Games. They see it on promotional material. It surfaces in encounters on the street, in the grocery store, and during interviews.

title: J.W.Anderson: Spring 2017
description: The designer, who is also the creative director of Loewe, presents his latest collection.

title: Baseballs Stirrups: Always in Season, if Not in Fashion
description: Cleveland Indians shortstop Francisco Lindor absorbed a wealth of baseball knowledge from his father, Miguel. In Puerto Rico, the elder Lindor would hit balls down a hill to refine his sons fielding instincts, the theory being he would not miss many if he knew he would then have to chase after them.

title: Device Explodes Near Route of Charity Race in Jersey Shore
description: An improvised device exploded in a garbage receptacle near the course of a charity race that was about to begin in a small town on the Jersey Shore on Saturday, law enforcement officials said.

title: Safety First, Even if Will Power Finishes Second
description: A concussion, or perhaps the absence of one, may help decide the IndyCar title this weekend at Sonoma Raceway in California.

title: A Trump Empire Built on Inside Connections and $885 Million in Tax Breaks
description: The way Donald J. Trump tells it, his first solo project as a real estate developer, the conversion of a faded railroad hotel on 42nd Street into the sleek, 30-story Grand Hyatt, was a triumph from the very beginning.

title: In Missouri Senate Race, Challenger Makes His Point With a Blindfold and Rifle
description: One of the most striking campaign ads for the general election has nothing to do with the presidential race and is aimed at only one state. It is from Jason Kander, a Democratic candidate for Senate in Missouri, a veteran who explains his support for firearms background checks using a blindfold and an assault rifle.

title: In Evolving N.F.L., Giants Show How Getting Younger Is Looking Wiser
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Rookies come into the N.F.L. swelling with pride and promise, but many have ended up neither seen nor heard.

title: Tim Kaine
description: TIM KAINE is a United States senator from Virginia and the Democratic nominee for vice president.

title: Hillary Clinton Struggles to Gain Traction in Florida, Despite Spending
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Hillary Clinton has vastly outspent Donald J. Trump on TV ads in Florida. Her 57 campaign offices dwarf Mr. Trumps afterthought of a ground game. And Mr. Trump is deeply unpopular among Hispanics, who account for nearly one in five Florida voters.

title: Mike Pence
description: MIKE PENCE is the governor of Indiana and the Republican nominee for vice president.

title: Would You Hide a Jew From the Nazis?
description: WHEN representatives from the United States and other countries gathered in Evian, France, in 1938 to discuss the Jewish refugee crisis caused by the Nazis, they exuded sympathy for Jews  and excuses about why they couldnt admit them. Unto the breach stepped a 33-year-old woman from Massachusetts named Martha Sharp.

title: Emilia Wickstead: Spring 2017
description: The designer shows her spring 2017 looks, sure to be noticed by her repeat customer, the Duchess of Cambridge.

title: Hate Crime in the United States
description: A 20-state study by the Center for the Study of Hate & Extremism, California State University, San Bernardino.

title: He Changed the World: Artists Mourn Edward Albee
description: Edward Albee, the playwright whose Broadway debut  Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf?  remains one of the best-known American plays, was mourned by the people who knew him best: those in the world of theater.

title: Rich School, Poor School
description: Readers discuss a Connecticut judges sweeping indictment of the inequities in education.

title: Americas Wildlife Body Count
description: Until recently, I had never had any dealings with Wildlife Services, a century-old agency of the United States Department of Agriculture with a reputation for strong-arm tactics and secrecy. It is beloved by many farmers and ranchers and hated in equal measure by conservationists, for the same basic reason: It routinely kills predators and an astounding assortment of other animals  3.2 million of them last year  because ranchers and farmers regard them as pests.

title: Because Punk Still Rocks
description: BOSTON  Forty years after its noisy arrival, punk rock has hit middle age. CBGB, the seminal New York punk club on the Bowery, has been closed for a decade, but there is a CBGB-themed restaurant at the Newark airport. In my hometown, Boston, the 148-room Hotel Commonwealth, which occupies the former site of the storied punk venue the Rathskeller (always known as The Rat), offers a punk-themed luxury suite  for about $500 a night.

title: Californias Nifty Idea on Immigrant Health Care
description: The Affordable Care Act has helped 20 million people gain health insurance, but it explicitly excludes one group: undocumented immigrants. Now, lawmakers in California want to help change that by letting all immigrants purchase policies on the states insurance marketplace without federal subsidies. This is a good idea that the Obama administration should support.

title: Dilution of Doctrine
description: LAST weekend Tim Kaine, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee and a churchgoing Catholic, briefly escaped obscurity by telling an audience of L.G.B.T. activists that he expects his church to eventually bless and celebrate same-sex marriages.

title: Why Do Anything? A Meditation on Procrastination
description: Have you heard the story of the architect from Shiraz who designed the worlds most beautiful mosque? No one had ever conjured up such a design. It was breathtakingly daring yet well-proportioned, divinely sophisticated, yet radiating a distinctly human warmth. Those who saw the plans were awe-struck.

title: Put Globalization to Work for Democracies
description: A Chinese student once described his countrys globalization strategy to me. China, he said, opened a window to the world economy, but placed a screen on it. The country got the fresh air it needed  nearly 700 million people have been lifted from extreme poverty since the early 1980s  but kept mosquitoes out.

title: Will This Be a Four-Party Election?
description: Third parties dont fit cleanly into the simple political narrative most of us have in our heads of red versus blue, and two parties battling it out, Super Bowl-style. Yet for much of our history, outsiders have pushed their way onto the playing field, disrupting the narrative of the Big Game.

title: Bashing the Hero in the Wells Fargo Case
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has rightly emerged as the hero in the story this month about fraudulent practices at Wells Fargo. The bureau was the lead agency in the investigation of the bank, where some 5,300 employees (now fired) illegally opened millions of unauthorized bank and credit card accounts in customers names in order to meet aggressive sales targets.

title: The Fight Working Moms Won
description: Working mothers, take note: You have won the culture war. Now you are making advances in the policy battle. This presidential race has become, at least in part, a debate over how best to help you balance work and home, not whether you should be working at all.

title: The Afghan War Quagmire
description: Eight years ago, President Obama pledged to wind down the war in Iraq and redouble efforts to defeat the Taliban in Afghanistan. As president, I will make the fight against Al Qaeda and the Taliban the top priority that it should be, he said during a campaign speech. This is a war that we have to win.

title: Why College Rankings Are a Joke
description: Shortly before the newest U.S. News & World Report college rankings came out last week, I got a fresh glimpse of how ridiculous they can be  and of why panicked high school seniors and their status-conscious parents should not spend the next months obsessing over them.

title: An Al Qaeda Martyrs Enduring Pitch
description: Hiding out from American drones in Yemens badlands in March 2010, Al Qaedas most persuasive English-language recruiter donned a camo jacket and addressed American and European Muslims.

title: My Teenage Obsession With How Things Work
description: Tampa, Fla.  My mother, a paranoid schizophrenic, was kind, shy and very strange, darting from our house to the car, carrying her purse in a cardboard box, always. Any activity that required interacting with fellow humans was, for her, anathema. As an adolescent I knew one thing for certain: I didnt want to turn out like my mother.

title: Its a Wrap: Covering the Toronto Film Festival
description: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. In this piece, Mekado Murphy, a Times culture editor, says he still often feels like the shabby, backpack-toting guest at glitzy events like the Toronto International Film Festival: I might be scarfing down a granola bar on the way to a hotel-room interview and find myself sharing an elevator with Michael Fassbender.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Germans and Austrians Protest E.U. Trade Talks With U.S. and Canada
description: BERLIN  Hundreds of thousands of people rallied across Germany and Austria on Saturday to urge their governments not to sign new agreements being negotiated for European Union trade deals with the United States and Canada.

title: Hate Crimes Against American Muslims Most Since Post-9/11 Era
description: WASHINGTON  Hate crimes against American Muslims have soared to their highest levels since the aftermath of the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks, according to data compiled by researchers, an increase apparently fueled by terrorist attacks in the United States and abroad and by divisive language on the campaign trail.

title: Caliphate in Peril, More ISIS Fighters May Take Mayhem to Europe
description: WASHINGTON  As the Islamic State loses territory in Iraq and Syria, American and other Western officials say they are bracing for large numbers of battle-tested terrorist fighters to flee the conflict in desperation or by design and prepare attacks after returning home.

title: A Mosquito Killer, Unwelcome to Many
description: A controversial pesticide, naled, was sprayed over Miami this month in an effort to eradicate Aedes aegypti, the mosquitoes spreading the Zika virus in southern Florida. The spraying has prompted protests from environmentalists and residents worried about naleds toxicity. Here are some facts about the pesticide.

title: Outcry Erupts Over Miami Beachs Pesticide Spraying to Curb Zika
description: MIAMI BEACH  As Miami Beach works to blunt the spread of Zika  a virus that is taking a toll on tourism here  the city is wrestling with a separate predicament: a fast-growing outcry over the aerial spraying of naled, the pesticide used to kill adult mosquitoes.

title: Occupy Wall Street: Where Are They Now?
description: Though some protesters have returned to their former lives, all say they have been transformed.

title: Southeast Asia Replaces Africa as the Worlds Hotbed of Piracy
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Sembara Oktafian was in the engine room of a tugboat chugging toward the Philippines when something didnt sound right.

title: Simone Rocha: Spring 2017
description: Ms. Rocha, who debuted at London Fashion Week in 2010, shows the latest in her subversive, romantic style.

title: The Insomnia Machine
description: In 1914, The Lancet reported on a clergyman who was found dead in a pool; he had left behind this suicide note: Another sleepless night, no real sleep for weeks. Oh, my poor brain, I cannot bear the lengthy, dark hours of the night.

title: At Simone Rocha, Youthful and Careless Plaited Ponytails
description: The work of the Boston-born photographer Jackie Nickerson, whose powerful portraits document agricultural workers across southern Africa, was the cerebral starting point for the look both front and backstage at Simone Rocha for spring 2017. Its really important to Simone to have a complete look where everything works together, explained the hairstylist (and longtime friend of the designer) James Pecis, backstage. This hair has a practical and utilitarian feel. Its a little more pulled back than what weve done in the past  because theres so much going on in the collection. To create a look that would work out-of-doors, Pecis pulled the models hair back into two plaited ponytails, using Maximista Thickening Spray to give it the sweaty feel that Rocha requested.

title: Edward Albee, a Playwright Intent on Naming, and Goading, the Beast Within
description: Edward Albee never expected or even wanted you to like his plays. Like is too pale and friendly a word for the red-blooded emotions he hoped to elicit. Rage and bewilderment, fear and loathing and that grand old Aristotelian couple, pity and terror: These were all welcome and entirely appropriate responses to have in the theater of Mr. Albee, one of the genuinely great dramatists of the last century, who died on Friday at 88.

title: Gareth Pugh: Spring 2017
description: The designer, known for his provocative looks, shows his latest collection.

title: Don Buchla, Inventor, Composer and Electronic Music Maverick, Dies at 79
description: Don Buchla, a pioneer and maverick of electronic music who had a lifelong fascination with the ways that humans, technology and sounds interact, died on Wednesday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 79.

title: Mets Win Offsets Bad News on Jacob deGrom, Expected to Miss Rest of Season
description: The Mets season, a tale that has included as many strange turns as a Stanley Kubrick film, revealed another twist Saturday.

title: Turkeys Islamic Fashion Revolution
description: ISTANBUL  The models, tall and lithe and strutting down the runway to the beat of Moroccan-themed house music, are from Russia and Eastern Europe. They could be displaying the latest designer styles in Paris or New York, but instead they are here, in Istanbul, wearing high heels, flowing tunics and colorful head scarves.

title: Another Painful Loss for Yankees, With Castro and Ellsbury Injured
description: BOSTON  No player who has been with the Yankees since the start of the season has played in fewer games than Austin Romine, their third-string catcher since early August.

title: Kremlin Says It Wants a Spotless Election, but Locally It Is Marred
description: TOGLIATTI, Russia  The retiree out walking her Scottie in the rain last week in Togliatti, home of the infamous Lada automobile, was delighted to encounter an opposition candidate distributing pamphlets that called on President Vladimir V. Putin to step down.

title: Howard E. Butt Jr., Grocery Empire Heir Who Spread a Gospel, Dies at 89
description: Howard E. Butt Jr., a billionaire heir apparent to his familys Texas supermarket empire, who gave up the business to spread a Christian message about the dignity of work and its nexus with faith and built a nationwide following, died on Sept. 11 at his home in San Antonio. He was 89.

title: Film Shines Light on South Korean Spy Agencys Fabrication of Enemies
description: SEOUL, South Korea  They were beaten and forced to make false confessions. Many spent years in prison. Some were executed. Most were forgotten for decades.

title: Make a Dash for It
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  I thought this Sunday puzzle provided a good balance of no-brainers and headscratchers, and a theme that was smart and inventive without being too abstruse.

title: U.S. Admits Airstrike in Syria, Meant to Hit ISIS, Killed Syrian Troops
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The United States acknowledged on Saturday that its warplanes had carried out an airstrike in Syria that resulted in the deaths of Syrian government troops. American military officials said the pilots in the attack, in the eastern province of Deir al-Zour, believed they were targeting the Islamic State.

title: Versus: Spring 2017
description: Versaces diffusion line is shown sans the design guidance of Anthony Vaccarello, who was handed the reigns at Saint Laurent in April.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Your Weekend Briefing

title: Donald Trumps Anything-Goes Campaign Sets an Alarming Political Precedent
description: WASHINGTON  When Donald J. Trump descended on the capital Friday, he was expected to finally concede that the racially tinged falsehood he had gleefully propagated, that President Obama was born outside of the United States, had in fact been a lie.

title: Duane Graveline, Doctor Who Was Forced Out as an Astronaut, Dies at 85
description: In 1965, Duane E. Graveline, a doctor who did pioneering research in space medicine, was awarded one of the most coveted jobs the government can bestow: astronaut. But he resigned less than two months later without ever being fitted for a spacesuit, let alone riding a rocket into space.

title: Iranian Cyclist Dies After Crashing at the Paralympics
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  An Iranian cyclist died Saturday after an accident in a mens road race at the Paralympics in Rio de Janeiro. The cyclist, Bahman Golbarnezhad, crashed on a mountainous section of the course known as the Grumari loop, the International Paralympic Committee said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Hes a different kind of bloodthirsty dictator, the kind who shops online on his iPad. Hes sort of Arab dictator 2.0.

title: Scuba, Parrots, Yoga: Veterans Embrace Alternative Therapies for PTSD
description: ATLANTA  Thomas Harris slid into the cool, salty water of a 6.3-million-gallon tank at the Georgia Aquarium here and let himself float limp as kelp.

title: Powerful Blast Injures at Least 29 in Manhattan; Second Device Found
description: A powerful explosion caused by what the authorities believe was a homemade bomb injured at least 29 people on a crowded sidewalk in the bustling Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan on Saturday night.

title: On Syria's Border With Turkey
description: Fattah Issa, 38, lives in Kobani, a city in northern Syria far from the front lines and controlled by Kurdish militias. An ethnic Kurd, he left a government job in Damascus as the country's crisis began.

title: Syrias Unraveling Truce: My Children Woke Up, Again, to Explosions
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In Aleppo, there are again reports of dead children. In Damascus, clashes reverberate close to downtown.

title: W.P. Kinsella, Author of Shoeless Joe, Dies at 81
description: W.P. Kinsella, who wrote Shoeless Joe, the novel that became the basis for the 1989 movie Field of Dreams, and the author of numerous baseball short stories, poetry collections and several works of nonfiction, died on Friday in Hope, British Columbia. He was 81.

title: At Least 29 Injured in Explosion in Manhattan
description: A blast was reported around 8:30 p.m. in the Chelsea neighborhood on Saturday.

title: Louisvilles Lamar Jackson Strikes an Early Pose in the Heisman Chase
description: It is difficult to conceive of how Lamar Jackson will not win the Heisman Trophy  even if, in college football terms, that eventuality is eons away.

title: On the Trail: Week of Sept. 11
description: Hillary Clinton took a break from campaigning early in the week to recover from pneumonia, and Donald J. Trump closed out the week by suggesting Mrs. Clintons bodyguards disarm.

title: Krista Schult, Elliott Jones
description: Krista Marie Schult, a daughter of Deborah C. Leible of Naples, Fla., and Peter E. Schult of Southampton, N.Y., was married Sept. 17 to Elliott Stanton Jones, a son of Christina C. Evans and Peter D. Jones, both of New York. The Rev. Charles W. Froehlich, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at Union Chapel in the Grove in Shelter Island Heights, N.Y.

title: Kara Feigeles, Andrew Braithwaite
description: Kara Blake Feigeles and Andrew Robert Braithwaite were married Sept. 17 in Brooklyn. Rabbi Robert N. Levine officiated at Weylin B. Seymours, an event space.

title: Annie Atkinson, Henry Bodmer
description: Annie Chilton Atkinson, a daughter of Joan B. Atkinson and Thomas M. Atkinson of Tulsa, Okla., was married there Sept. 17 to Henry Christopher Bodmer, the son of Annina C. Mueller-Bodmer and George H. Mueller of Zollikerberg, Switzerland. The Rev. James D. Miller, a Presbyterian pastor, officiated at the Philbrook Museum of Art in Tulsa.

title: Julia Rueckert, Brett Shannon
description: Julia Rueckert, a daughter of Fleur Marks Rueckert and William D. Rueckert of Southport, Conn., was married there Sept. 17 to Brett Danielson Shannon, the son of Lori Danielson Shannon and Glenn A. Shannon of Tiberon, Calif. The Rev. Paul D. Whitmore, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Southport Congregational Church.

title: Casey Hedden, Drew Jennings
description: Casey Alexandra Hedden, a daughter of Vicki C. Hedden and Barry K. Hedden of Raleigh, N.C., was married Sept. 17 to Drew Kingston Jennings, a son of Deborah Jennings and Dana Jennings of Upper Montclair, N.J. Ben Locke, an ordained pastor of the International Church of the Foursquare Gospel, officiated at Regan Beach in Lake Tahoe, Calif.

title: Katharine Sargent, James Hogan
description: Katharine Porter Sargent, the daughter of Allison D. Ijams and Thomas A. Sargent of Wellesley, Mass., was married Sept. 17 to James Andrew Hogan, a son of Leslie M. Hannafey and Stephen Hogan of Brooklyn. Margaret ONeil, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the brides family farm in Norwich, Vt.

title: Jordan Rowley, Shane Sandridge
description: Jordan Thorpe Rowley, a daughter of Toni Capps Rowley and Edward W. Rowley of St. Simons Island, Ga., was married Sept. 17 to Shane Andrew Sandridge, the son of Karen R. Sandridge of Sugar Hill, Ga., and the late Alfred D. Sandridge. The Rev. Thomas C. Purdy performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church, Frederica, in St. Simons Island, where he is the rector.

title: Elizabeth Sebesky, Brandon Jonas
description: Elizabeth Jane Sebesky, a daughter of Janina Serden Sebesky of Monmouth Beach, N.J., and Don Sebesky of Chatham, N.J., is to be married Sept. 18 to Brandon Asher Jonas, a son of Geri Jonas and Frederick Jonas of Santa Clarita, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Sheila Gay Gross, an interfaith minister ordained by the All Faiths Seminary, is to officiate at the Channel Club, an event space in Monmouth Beach.

title: Debra Halpert, David Greenberg
description: Debra Ellen Halpert and David Mark Greenberg are to be married Sept. 18 at the home of Jewel and Robert Morris, friends of the bride, in Water Mill, N.Y. Rabbi Jennifer E. Krause is to officiate.

title: Yael Rapport, David Moser
description: Rabbi Yael Rooks Rapport, the daughter of Rabbi Gaylia R. Rooks and Rabbi Joe R. Rapport of Louisville, Ky., is to be married Sept. 18 to David Russell Moser, a son of Beth R. Moser and William J. Moser of Great Barrington, Mass. Rabbi Jodie Gordon will officiate at Gedney Farm, a dairy farm in New Marlborough, Mass.

title: Katherine Alberti, Brian Price
description: Katherine Elizabeth Alberti and Brian Anthony Price were married Sept. 17 at East Hampton Point, a restaurant in East Hampton, N.Y. Rabbi Jon Adland officiated.

title: Christina Bucci, William Vanderveer
description: Christina Genduso Bucci, a daughter of Carol A. Genduso and Judge James M. Bucci of Bernville, Pa., was married Sept. 17 to William Russell Vanderveer, a son of Deborah I. Vanderveer of Ambler, Pa., and Richard B. Vanderveer of Hilton Head, S.C. Arthur Dobrin, the former leader of the Ethical Humanist Society of Long Island, officiated at the Lieb Estate in Cutchogue, N.Y.

title: Ariane Reinhart, Laurence Hobgood
description: Ariane Malia Reinhart, the daughter of Charles L. Reinhart of New York and the late Stephanie Reinhart, was married Sept. 16 to Laurence Bishop Hobgood, a son of Jane Bishop Hobgood of Urbana, Ill., and the late Burnet M. Hobgood. Carlos Cuevas, the former city clerk of New York, officiated at the brides fathers home.

title: Alexandra Cutler, Joel Dommel
description: Alexandra Danielle Cutler, a daughter of Aimee S. Cutler of Bethel, N.Y., is to be married Sept. 18 to Joel Ryan Dommel, a son of Bonnie L. Dommel and the Rev. Albert J. Dommel of Whitehall, Pa. The grooms father, a minister ordained though Bible Fellowship Church, is to officiate at Mohonk Mountain House, a resort hotel in New Paltz, N.Y.

title: Nicole Landesman, Benjamin Leitman
