Ms. Shanley, the subject of Dead Shot Mary, was one of the first women to become a New York City police detective. Her story lives on in Depression-era newspaper headlines like Policewoman Seizes Two Men Without Aid (1936) and Woman Detective Draws Pistol in Fifth Avenue (1938). And now in this one-hour one-act, by Robert K. Benson, at Shetler Studios.

title: Ts New Design & Luxury Issue: Editors Letter
description: Design is so pervasive, argues Michael Rock in his Sign of the Times essay, that it often appears as fact rather than the result of subjective decision-making. After a period of time, an idea that originally evolved from mores, habits or customs becomes so codified and ingrained that it takes on the air of inevitability. For this issue, we decided to take a closer look at the meaning of design and why we make certain choices, from the wild natural beauty of Isabel and Julian Bannermans garden to the fine attention to detail in the rising designer Billy Cottons interiors. We considered the psychological effects of design, from the standpoint of a mad collector, the young fashion designer Jonathan Anderson, to what happens when it all goes terribly wrong. Of course, we also celebrate the vast range of the designed world: teapots, interesting hairdos, clever companies, artists communities, fabric, paint and rugs, jewels, clothing, even plumbing. Added up, these stories are a call to see design more clearly, to appreciate what is all around us, but also to realize the delicacy of ingenuity  that none of it had to be quite this way, and yet it is. And, to recognize that if something isnt working, we can try to design its change.

title: Clinton Plays It Frosty Between the Ferns
description: Yesterday, Hillary Clinton arguably had one of her most effective public appearances in months, and it happened on the website Funny or Die. Clinton appeared as a guest on Between Two Ferns with Zach Galifianakis, a semi-aggressive, extremely rumpled comedian and sort-of talk show host who makes David Letterman look painfully earnest by comparison. The show has a glaringly low-rent aesthetic, like something made in an office park, circa 1981, by a bunch of interns with time on their hands. That sensibility  self-mocking, on-the-fly and D.I.Y.  is very 2016.

description: YUMINGZUI VILLAGE, China  On a moonless night, when there was nothing in the air except the smell of rotting seaweed and the songs of drunken fishermen, Wang Xinfeng sneaked onto a boat by the dock and sailed into the darkness.

title: Caliber Said to Be Asked for Data on Handling Distressed Mortgages
description: New Yorks financial regulator wants information from Caliber Home Loans, one of the nations fastest-growing mortgage firms, about its handling of distressed mortgages and origination of mortgages to borrowers with checkered credit histories.

title: 6 Sites Recognized by Britain for Significance to Gay History
description: LONDON  The former homes of the writer Oscar Wilde and the composer Benjamin Britten are among six sites that were recognized on Friday by an arm of the British government for their significance in lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender history.

title: This Movie Was Nearly Lost. Now Theyre Fighting to Save It.
description: When it debuted in 1982, Cane River was already a rarity: a drama by an independent black filmmaker, financed by wealthy black patrons and dealing with race issues untouched by mainstream cinema. Richard Pryor had even tried to take it to Hollywood.

title: South Koreas President Has No Easy Options in Dealing with an Aggressive North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  After North Korea conducted its fifth and most powerful nuclear test this month, South Koreas president, Park Geun-hye, met with her countrys opposition leaders to discuss how to react. The outcome was not surprising.

title: Wages for Home Care Aides Lag as Demand Grows
description: The analysts at P.H.I., a nonprofit research and consulting group, sift through federal data each year to see how the nations swelling corps of home care workers is faring.

title: At Home in Times Square
description: When Jan Staller set about photographing 42nd Street in the early 1980s, the people who called Times Square home were drawn to his camera. Together, over one summer, they captured a moment in time.

title: Egypt Recovers Over 160 Bodies From Sunken Migrant Boat
description: CAIRO  The Egyptian authorities said Friday that they had recovered 162 bodies after the sinking of a ship full of mostly Egyptian migrants in the Mediterranean this week.

title: He Thought Times Square Was Dead, Before It Showed Him Life
description: Jan Staller has an eye for urban ruin, and one summer in the early 1980s, it brought him to Times Square. Mr. Staller, 64, is best known for his images of New Yorks desolate landscapes. In Times Square, he was drawn to what he thought were dead zones: a subterranean shoe-repair shop squeezed into a subway station and a coin-operated fortune teller perched by the subway stairs. They were so grimy and old, so redolent of another time, the first 50 years of the 20th century, he said.

title: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
description: A guide to cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there's much more where these came from.

title: Times Editor Dean Baquet on Calling Out Donald Trumps Lies.
description: The Timess executive editor, Dean Baquet, talks about his decision to be more direct about calling out a presidential candidates lies.

title: Making Manhood in The Hairy Ape
description: If the play is called The Hairy Ape, why is this guy so smooth? And whats in the bottle?

title: Hundreds of Thousands of Syrians Are Trapped, Unable to Get Food or Aid
description: Civilians in these areas have limited or no access to food, medicine and basic necessities.

title: How to Get Versaces Fresh, Sporty Beauty Look
description: This season, rather than show an overtly sexy collection akin to the Versace designs of yore, Donatella Versace said that her mission was to elevate sportswear to luxury levels  so women could look good while feeling comfortable and powerful. To that end, she asked the makeup artist Pat McGrath to create a look that emphasized a natural glow. Which she did, with just a bit of cream blush and mascara, and her namesake lines Skin Fetish highlighter. McGrath also groomed the models eyebrows and, finally, added a touch of silver pigment to the inside corner of the eyes  a little futuristic but at the same time pretty, she said. The look is sporty, but not sporty as in sweaty and undone and disheveled  its more of a refined sport look.

title: Times Editor Dean Baquet on Calling Out Donald Trumps Lies
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this podcast, the Timess executive editor Dean Baquet talks about the decision to call out Donald J. Trumps lies.

title: Doors of Manhattan
description: Even though they stand between us and the chaos of the city, the boroughs distinctive doors are easy to overlook.

title: If the 18th Hole Isnt Made for TV, Make It the 9th
description: ATLANTA  Imagine if, just this year, the horses at the Kentucky Derby made right turns instead of lefts around the track at Churchill Downs. Or if the New York City Marathon ended at the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge instead of starting there. Or, for the baseball playoffs, the Boston Red Sox moved Fenway Parks iconic Green Monster outfield wall from left field to right.

title: Ted Cruz Announces Support for Donald Trump
description: Senator Ted Cruz said on Friday that he would vote for Donald J. Trump for president, two months after Mr. Cruz pointedly declined to endorse his former rival in a speech at the Republican National Convention.

title: Diego Della Valle of Tods on Design, Politics  and Tattoos
description: Diego Della Valle is the 62-year-old billionaire who not only manages but is instantly identifiable with the brands he owns. Unlike his closest peers, Franois-Henri Pinault of Kering, or Bernard Arnault of LVMH, Della Valle has an unexpected, dandyish flair: He habitually sports upturned shirt collars and a wide-spread scarf in place of a tie, and employs not one but two tailors (Lattini for his sport jackets, Caraceni for his suits) though Ive most often seen him combine his Caraceni jackets with Levis. His gray hair is swept back from his high forehead, his horn-rimmed spectacles seem well-considered. He is a man who likes fashion, wears it, buys some  and sells lots.

title: Harvard Needs a Steady Endowment Manager
description: Harvard University is struggling with postgraduate life. Its giant endowment lost 2 percent in the year to June, falling short of its own yardsticks and the 3.4 percent gain generated by David Swensen at its rival, Yale. More than a decade after the departure of its architect, Jack Meyer, the Harvard Management Company is finding it hard to get past being the sort-of hedge fund it once was.

title: Coffee Grounds May Filter Out Heavy Metals in Water
description: Inside an old gas tank, pink and white mold grows atop crispy cakes of spent espresso.

title: In Toronto, Looking to the Future in an Abandoned Park
description: TORONTO  For the first time in five summers, Torontos waterfront amusement park is open, overgrown though it may be.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Simon Schamas The Face of Britain
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: Canada Today: Taking the International Stage
description: Were trying something new: Canada Today, a weekly roundup for Canadian readers and anyone else interested in the True North. Tell us what you think and what youd like to see, at CanadaToday@nytimes.com. And, using the link below, please subscribe to the email newsletter version.

title: What I Love | Amor Towles
description: The author of the novels Rules of Civility and the new A Gentleman in Moscow, lives in a townhouse near Gramercy Park in Manhattan.

title: Ed Temple, Track Coach Who Produced Olympians and National Titles, Dies at 89
description: Ed Temple, who coached Wilma Rudolph, Wyomia Tyus and 38 other Olympians in his 43 seasons as the most celebrated womens track and field coach in the United States, died on Thursday. He was 89.

title: Amor Towles, a Gentleman in Gramercy Park
description: Amor Towles lives with his family in an elegant Victorian townhouse near Gramercy Park, a circumstance his fans would, no doubt, find eminently fitting. After all, Mr. Towless 2011 debut novel, Rules of Civility, takes place amid the haunts of cafe and Nescaf society in 1930s Manhattan. With its beautifully restored staircase and moldings, its marble fireplaces and French doors, its adroit mix of antique and Art Deco furniture, Mr. Towless home could have been one of the soigne settings for his best-selling book.

title: Obama Vetoes 9/11 Bill, but Congressional Override Is Expected
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama vetoed legislation on Friday that would allow families of victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks to sue the government of Saudi Arabia for any role in the plot, setting up an extraordinary confrontation with a Congress that unanimously backed the bill and has vowed to uphold it.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Chelsea Manning Sentenced to Solitary Over Suicide Attempt
description: WASHINGTON  An Army board has decided to discipline Chelsea Manning, the former Army analyst, with two weeks of solitary confinement in connection with her suicide attempt in early July at the prison barracks at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., her lawyer said Friday.

title: Childrens Books That Tackle Race and Ethnicity
description: A reading list for kids of all ages.

title: Franklins Lament, Revisited
description: New verses update a ballad about Sir John Franklin, lost in the Arctic with 128 men 170 years ago.

title: A Guide to the Smithsonians African-American Museum
description: The idea of a national African-American museum was conceived by black Civil War veterans more than a century ago.

title: What the Hacking at Yahoo Means for Verizon
description: It was the kind of phone call no chief executive wants to make  or receive  in the middle of a multibillion-dollar deal.

title: Why Is Sarah Jessica Parker Following Me?
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Susan Dominus, a staff writer for The Times Magazine whose profile of Sarah Jessica Parker is on the cover of Sundays Arts & Leisure section, muses on some eerie similarities between the trappings of her own life and those of the leading TV characters Ms. Parker has played over the last two decades.

title: Hillary Clintons Angry Face
description: When Hillary Clinton participated in a televised forum on national security and military issues this month, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, Reince Priebus, tweeted that she was angry and defensive the entire time  no smile and uncomfortable. Mrs. Clinton, evidently undaunted by Mr. Priebuss opinion on when she should and shouldnt smile, tweeted back, Actually, thats just what taking the office of president seriously looks like.

title: Tesla Upgrades Autopilot in Cars on the Road
description: Tesla Motors, always ahead of the automotive curve, is conducting a remarkable technological feat.

title: Yale Endowment Earned 3.4% in a Year When Many Peers Lost
description: At a time when many university endowments have been reporting lackluster or even negative returns, Yale has turned in a winning year.

title: Paramounts Vice Chairman to Leave, Adding to Upheaval at Viacom
description: The turmoil at Viacom is not letting up.

title: The Joyce Theater Confronts Its Own Staleness
description: As you make your way through the cramped lobby into the theater of the Joyce, one of New Yorks venerable dance spaces, its best not to look down. But there it is again  that carpet, with its hotel-chain print of zigzags and intersecting stripes in shades of beige, maroon and pink.

title: Arctic Climate Change Revealed in a Luxury Cruise and Haunting Wreck
description: In a short piece for the Opinion section this weekend, I explore how two maritime milestones this month encapsulate the profound changes that are under way in the Arctic  both climatic and cultural.

title: How Yahoos Data Breach Could Affect Its Deal With Verizon
description: The MAC might be back. And that would be bad news for the beleaguered shareholders of Yahoo.

title: Review: Kesha, Dodging the Past, but Still Relying on It
description: Pop songs in the modern era are the products of collaboration  singers, writers, producers, engineers and many more all have a part to play. That arrangement engenders a perennial pop-star anxiety: Is it the songs that have fans, or the singer? And can the singer go it alone detached from the ecosystem that laid the foundation for her success?

title: Can Teslas Autopilot Be Trusted? Not Always
description: LOS ANGELES  Driving a Tesla Model S with Autopilot technology can be frightening and exhilarating.

title: Charlotte, Syria, Ted Cruz: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Danzig on Getting the Band (the Misfits) Back Together. Briefly.
description: On Sunday night, Glenn Danzig fronted the Misfits  the band in which he sang lead for six years in his 20s but hadnt joined onstage since 1983  for the headlining slot of Chicagos Riot Fest. The second and, he said, final performance of a two-show reunion run, the set was a comprehensive, ecstatic summary of his time with the group, which is credited with developing and popularizing horror punk.

title: Review: Betty Buckley Digs Deep for the Autumn in Her Soul
description: September! November! To hear Betty Buckley cry out the names of the remaining months as the year wanes in September Song at Joes Pub on Thursday evening was to hear a great dramatic singer dig out the underlying anguish in a standard that is typically treated as a slice of senior nostalgia. Yes, the days may be dwindling down, but there is consolation. The words, These few precious days Ill spend with you give you an image of grandma and grandpa snuggling under a comforter by the hearth, not of a dazed oldster struggling with Alzheimers. Without overstating things, Ms. Buckley found alarm and impending grief in the song.

title: The Other 13 Women Testifying Against Cosby ... if the Court Lets Them
description: Some knew him for only a day. Others built friendships over months, even years, and introduced him to their mothers, an aunt, even a 9-year-old son, they say.

title: Review: In A Taste of Honey, Shes Having the Baby. How Quaint.
description: Shelagh Delaney was still a teenager when she sent her first script off to a London theater in 1958, enclosing a note that fairly bristled with a bold defensiveness.

title: Review: Hit the Body Alarm Finds Satan in a Jumpsuit
description: Satan, cast down from heaven, tries to make the best of his new home. Better to reign in hell, than serve in heaven, he says. Hell promises freedom, safety, power. Besides, do the denizens of paradise get to wear cool asymmetrical jumpsuits?

title: Adventures on the China Golf Tour
description: It was a foggy day in Chongqing, a metropolis in southwest China, and the driving range was almost empty. Out beyond the 250-yard marker, a cluster of new high-rise apartment buildings was barely visible, blurred by the haze into a mountainous shadow that made this decidedly urban setting feel unusually secluded.

title: Candy, Hashtags and Hate
description: This explainer first appeared in the Race/Related newsletter. Sign up.

title: Why We Are Protesting in Charlotte
description: Charlotte, N.C.  Since a police officer shot and killed Keith Lamont Scott in Charlotte, N.C., on Tuesday afternoon, the ensuing protests have dominated national news. Provocateurs who attacked police officers and looted stores made headlines. Gov. Pat McCrory declared a state of emergency, and the National Guard joined police officers in riot gear, making the Queen City look like a war zone.

title: Karl Dietrich Bracher, German Historian of Nazi Era, Dies at 94
description: Karl Dietrich Bracher, a World War II veteran of the German army who argued as a historian that the German people had to take responsibility for the rise of Nazism because of their embrace of Hitler and his racist agenda, died on Monday in Bonn. He was 94.

title: Ruling Means Most of Hillary Clintons Emails Will Come Out After Election
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge on Friday ordered the State Department to finish preparing roughly 1,000 pages of Hillary Clintons emails for release by Nov. 4, a more protracted timetable that means the bulk of Mrs. Clintons emails that were uncovered by the Federal Bureau of Investigation will not be released until after the election.

title: For Taiwan, Google Images of Disputed Island Are Too Clear
description: Satellite photos by Google can be a fun way to see your house  or your neighbors  from high above.

title: Knicks Face Questions About Derrick Roses Trial as Training Camp Approaches
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Phil Jackson appeared at a preseason news conference on Friday afternoon to discuss the Knicks revamped roster before training camp next week. He quickly found himself fending off questions about a potential civil trial involving rape allegations against Derrick Rose, one of his key off-season acquisitions.

title: Haitians, After Perilous Journey, Find Door to U.S. Abruptly Shut
description: TIJUANA, Mexico  They passed the corpses of other migrants who had tried to cross the Americas. They were cheated by smugglers and fleeced by armed bandits, and they suffered long stretches of hunger.

title: Hackers Trawl User Data in Hopes a Small Target Will Lead to a Big One
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In disclosing that at least 500 million of its user accounts had been hacked, Yahoo blamed an unnamed state-sponsored actor for the intrusion. While Yahoo customers were caught by surprise, officials in Washington were not.

title: Charlotte Is Pressured to Release Police Video of Mans Killing
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  This citys leaders, faced with mounting demands for transparency after a fatal police shooting of a black man led to rioting, resisted calls on Friday for the immediate release of video of the killing and argued that a rushed disclosure could compromise a criminal inquiry.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: It is the worst day that weve had for a very long time. They are calling it Dresden-esque.

title: Bridge Case Culprit Says Christie and Ex-Aides Used Port Authority as Goody Bag
description: NEWARK  The admitted mastermind of the mysterious George Washington Bridge lane closings broke a three-year silence on Friday, testifying in federal court here that everything he did in his job was at the direction and for the benefit of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

title: Henry Louis Gates Jr.: Restoring Black History
description: With the ringing of a bell and a speech from President Obama, the National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington is to officially open its extraordinary collection to the public on Saturday. But the museum can claim another, equally important achievement: helping resolve the protracted debate about the contributions of black people to American history and, indeed, about whether they had a history worth preserving at all. Those questions were at the heart of the nations original debate about whether, and how, black lives matter.

title: Mets Win Comes With a Big Loss, as Noah Syndergaard Has Strep Throat
description: As the Mets near the final week of the regular season chasing a playoff spot, they have come to resemble a triage unit housing a baseball team. Every day seems to bring a new injury and a new conundrum. Their September roster, bloated to 39 players, is not carrying unnecessary baggage but much-needed pieces to paper over new holes and to leverage in crucial moments.

title: Health Care Deserves More Attention on the Campaign Trail
description: The reaction to opening a medical bill these days is often shock and confusion  for the insured and the uninsured. Prices and deductibles keep rising, policies are drowning in fine print, and doctors are jumping on and off networks. So why hasnt the growing burden of health care gotten more attention in the presidential campaign?

title: Donald Trump the Philanthropist Is Known for His Reluctance
description: When Donald J. Trump made an appearance this spring at the New York Military Academy, his high school alma mater in Cornwall-on-Hudson, he spoke of it with gratitude and in glowing terms, describing it as one of the really great military academies.

title: Dustin Johnson Moves a Step Closer to FedEx Cup Title
description: ATLANTA  The bee sting hurt. Of course it did. But as Kevin Chappell shook his left hand in pain as he walked off the tee on the 11th hole at East Lake Golf Club Friday, he did his best to be pragmatic.

title: The Feckless F.E.C., Rebuked
description: In an era of unbridled campaign spending, the Federal Election Commission has consistently and shamefully ducked its responsibilities. It has made it possible for tax-exempt social welfare organizations to operate as partisan attack machines. And it has dismissed complaints and failed to police this rise of dark money from hidden donors that is pouring into elections.

title: Donald Trumps Shiny New Washington Hotel
description: WASHINGTON  When Donald Trump labeled Mexican immigrants rapists in announcing his candidacy in June of last year, he lost contracts with Nascar, Macys, NBC Universal, Univision, even Serta mattresses. Not surprisingly, his three eldest children  Ivanka, Donald Jr. and Eric  began worrying about whether the marketability of the Trump brand could survive the campaign undamaged.

title: Tulsas Prayers, and Past Scars, Softened Reaction to Police Shooting
description: TULSA, Okla.  White rioters poured into the streets, burning and looting homes, businesses and churches in a black neighborhood and leaving this city deeply traumatized. That was 1921.

title: And Now, Presidential Dog Days
description: I think its time to talk about the presidential candidates pets.

title: Americas Duty to Take In Refugees
description: This year the United States will take in 85,000 of the worlds most vulnerable so they can begin new lives in America, the highest number since 2001. But at a time when 65 million people have been displaced by violence, and 20 million of them are classified as refugees  more than half of them children  it is not enough.

title: In an Era of Hyperbole, Paul Bunyan Is as Tall as Ever
description: BEMIDJI, Minn.  Hes huge in Minnesota. Huge.

title: Liberty Players Childhood Bond Outlasts the Story of Their Rivalry
description: Tina Charles and Epiphanny Prince will take the court Saturday night for the Liberty with their season on the line, in a single-elimination second-round playoff game against the Phoenix Mercury at Madison Square Garden.

title: Steve Clevenger Suspended by Mariners for Tweets on Charlotte Protests
description: Steve Clevenger, a backup catcher for the Seattle Mariners, was suspended by the team without pay for the rest of the season on Friday after he posted messages on Twitter harshly criticizing the Black Lives Matter movement and President Obama.

title: Hasidic Man Found Guilty of Gang Assault in Beating of Black Student in Brooklyn
description: A Brooklyn man was convicted on Friday of participating in a racially charged beating of a black college student in fall 2013 that left the victim without vision in his right eye.

title: Going Around the Block
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Are you feeling warmed up for the solving weekend after the challenging but relatively merciful Andrew Zhou puzzle yesterday? Good, because today youre going to sweat.

title: Unpopular Portion Cut From Entry Test for New Yorks Elite High Schools
description: This week, education officials decided to make a change to the New York specialized high school entry exam, a standardized test that is the sole factor in whether students are admitted to some of the citys most competitive high schools, like Stuyvesant High School or Brooklyn Technical High School.

title: Wild Card Is Slipping Out of Reach of the Yankees Experienced Hands
description: TORONTO  There was little point, as Manager Joe Girardi saw it, to assess how many wins the Yankees needed in their four-game series here to stay afloat in the American League playoff race.

title: N.Y.C.F.C. on Brink of First Playoff Berth After Defeating Chicago Fire
description: It has taken two years, two coaches and millions of dollars, but New York City F.C. is nearly there. After a 4-1 victory over the Chicago Fire at Yankee Stadium on Friday, N.Y.C.F.C. will clinch the first playoff berth in team history with a single favorable result from other games Saturday.

title: Public Defender Says Prosecutor Denied Him Access to Ahmad Rahami
description: Since he was captured on Monday, Ahmad Khan Rahami, the man accused of carrying out bombings last weekend in Manhattan and on the Jersey Shore, has been hospitalized in Newark, recovering from gunshot wounds he sustained in a confrontation with the police.

title: 5 Dead in Shooting at Mall in Washington State, Police Say
description: A shooting at a mall north of Seattle on Friday night left five people dead and the police searching for the gunman, the Washington State Patrol said.

title: Hillary Clinton Aide Playing Donald Trump in Mock Debates
description: Philippe Reines, a longtime aide to Hillary Clinton and one of the most astute observers of her personal and political vulnerabilities, is playing Donald J. Trump in her mock debate sessions, according to people familiar with Mr. Reiness involvement.

title: Protests Continue in Charlotte
description: Demonstrators marched to protest the shooting death of Keith Lamont Scott who was killed Tuesday by a police officer.

title: Corrections: September 24, 2016
description: WEEKEND

title: Christina Rexrode and Nick Zaccardi: A Wayward Trip Pays Off
description: Christina Ann Rexrode, a daughter of Ellen Cromer Rexrode and Gary A. Rexrode of Princeville, Hawaii, was married Sept. 24 to Nick Zaccardi, a son of Linda M. Zaccardi and Bill C. Zaccardi of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. Brian Chadwick, a Church of Christ minister and a friend of the bride, officiated at La Marina, a restaurant in New York.

title: Allison Gans and Brian Fischer: Atop Masada, a Union Foreshadowed
description: Allison Gale Gans, a daughter of Donna J. Gans and Robert M. Gans of San Diego, was married Sept. 24 to Brian Michael Fischer, the son of Susan V. Fischer and Jay A. Fischer of Alamo, Calif. Rabbi Jerry Levy officiated at Nestldown, an estate in Los Gatos, Calif.

title: Milan Fashion Week, Days 4 and 5: Bottega Veneta Celebrates and a Rising Star Shines
description: And just like that, the end of Milan Fashion Week is nigh. But if you thought there would be a respite this weekend, think again. There are more shows than ever packed in on Saturday and Sunday, ahead of Tuesdays start in Paris of the final leg of fashion month.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Steve Jobs and Portlandia
description: Michael Fassbender, in the famous black sweater and jeans, is the title character in Steve Jobs, which has its TV debut on HBO. And catch up with Fred Armisen and Carrie Brownsteins high jinks in the latest season of Portlandia, now on Netflix.

title: A Humane Voice for a Cruel Regime
description: Seven years ago, I heard the name of a prominent Iranian diplomat, Mohammad Javad Zarif, at least 118 times. That was how many days I spent imprisoned in Iran for doing my job as a journalist  and how many days I was beaten by an intelligence officer in the hard-line Revolutionary Guards. He demanded that I falsely confess to being a C.I.A. agent and invent false stories that Mr. Zarif had connections to Western intelligence agencies. Rather than cooperate, I somehow withstood the daily torture.

title: Im a White Lady. Perhaps That Is Why I Am Not Dead.
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

title: In Australia, Chinas Appetite Shifts From Rocks to Real Estate
description: PORT HEDLAND, Australia  A lanky, dark-haired surfer, Lee Meadowcroft modeled on the runways of London, Milan and Singapore, then followed his dream of going home to Australia to sell herbal medicines. His store failed  he had chosen the wrong street, he says  and he lost almost all his savings. By then, the fashion world had found fresher faces.

title: Angelina Jolie Turns to Divorce Specialist Laura Wasser
description: In her hour of need, Angelina Jolie Pitt turned to the hard-charging Los Angeles divorce lawyer known to TMZ readers and viewers as the disso queen, the word disso being short for dissolution of marriage.

title: Why the Fashion World Is Obsessed With RuPauls Drag Race
description: Her shoes were thigh-high, bedazzled platform moon boots. Her outfit was encircled by a tutu tilted at a particularly rakish angle. Her capelet, cresting in tusklike spikes, appeared to be hand-wrought from aluminum foil.

title: 5 Volunteer Travel Options in Europe
description: Looking for a different way to visit Europe? An unpaid volunteer experience  at a farm or winery or archaeological site  can offer an insiders view of local culture. Here is a selection.

title: Dede Wilsey Is the Defiant Socialite
description: RUTHERFORD, Calif.  Dede Wilsey was fuming.

title: Aging and My Beauty Dilemma
description: When I was 21, I underwent breast reduction surgery, reducing my embarrassingly large chest to something that could at least fit inside a cardigan. Although there was some medical rationale for the procedure, the overwhelming reason was that I was sick and tired of every man on the planet being unable to look above my neck. Their fault, I know, not mine, and symptomatic of the baggage, both physical and psychological, women are forced to carry around with them. But once my own baggage was surgically removed, I felt amazing  lighter, prettier, healthier. Was this an indulgent move on my part? Maybe. Have I regretted it over the last 30 years? Not for a single moment. I had a problem, or at least what felt an awful lot like a problem, and I made it go away.

title: Bottega Veneta: Spring 2017
description: Tomas Maier presents his spring 2017 collection for the label, which is celebrating its 50th anniversary.

title: For Fall Foliage Season, Lower Prices at Hotels
description: Wherever the leaves change color, expect hotel rates to rise as fall color peaks. Still, there are a few deals in leaf-peeping season, especially if you can travel midweek.

title: Jeremy Corbyn Is Re-elected as Leader of Britains Labour Party
description: LONDON  Jeremy Corbyn strengthened his grip on Britains opposition Labour Party on Saturday, beating back a challenge to his leadership by members of Parliament with increased support from the partys rank and file.

title: Antonio Marras: Spring 2017
description: The designer will show his mens and womens collections together for the first time at his spring 2017 show.

title: A Little Variety
description: VARIETY PUZZLES  This weeks puzzles include:

title: Farhads and Pui-Wings Week in Tech: Yahoos Hacking, Self-Driving Cars and the Future of Twitter
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mike is off this week, so technology editor Pui-Wing Tam stepped in.

title: A Sex Offender in the Building
description: Q. A young woman moved into our co-op in Long Beach, N.Y., two years ago. At her board interview, she said she lived alone. But afterward, a man quietly moved in. Recently, police posted notifications around the building alerting tenants that a sex offender  the man who moved in with this woman  lives in the area. She has a premier apartment overlooking the pool where children swim. What can we do to get this man off our premises? Can we force the deceitful shareholder to sell?

title: Fashion Week Photo Diary: Versace and Marco de Vincenzo
description: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented in Milan on Friday.

title: Phone Makers Could Cut Off Drivers. So Why Dont They?
description: The court filings paint a grisly picture: As Ashley Kubiak sped down a Texas highway in her Dodge Ram truck, she checked her iPhone for messages. Distracted, she crashed into a sport utility vehicle, killing its driver and a passenger and leaving a child paralyzed.

title: Your Local 1-Percenters May Not Be as Rich as You Think
description: At the Democratic National Convention this summer, Hillary Clinton said 1-percenters were due for a tax increase.

title: Hillary Clinton for President
description: In any normal election year, wed compare the two presidential candidates side by side on the issues. But this is not a normal election year. A comparison like that would be an empty exercise in a race where one candidate  our choice, Hillary Clinton  has a record of service and a raft of pragmatic ideas, and the other, Donald Trump, discloses nothing concrete about himself or his plans while promising the moon and offering the stars on layaway. (We will explain in a subsequent editorial why we believe Mr. Trump to be the worst nominee put forward by a major party in modern American history.)

title: Jil Sander: Spring 2017
description: Creative director Rodolfo Paglialunga shows his latest collection.

title: Clinton-Trump Debate Expected to Be Rare Draw in a Polarized Age
description: The uniquely uncivil presidential campaign is about to produce one of the biggest civic gatherings in decades: For 90 minutes on Monday night, a polarized nation will pause to watch the first head-to-head encounter between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump.

title: Variety Puzzle: Puns and Anagrams
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Puns and Anagrams puzzles, a known gateway drug to cryptic crosswords, are probably the most self-explanatory of all the Variety puzzles, and if youve never tried one, I highly recommend them.

title: Young Rural Women in India Chase Big-City Dreams
description: BANGALORE, India  The factory floor is going full throttle when the new girls walk in. Everywhere is the thrumming of sewing machines, the hum of fans, the faint burning smell of steam irons. On narrow tables that run between the machines, half-assembled Marks & Spencer miniskirts are thrust forward by fistfuls. The tailors, absorbed in the task of finishing 100 pieces per hour, for once turn their heads to look.

title: How to Get Jil Sanders Pared-Back 80s Beauty Look
description: At Jil Sander, the designer Rodolfo Paglialunga used 80s power dressing as a starting point for his spring/summer collection: he took mens suiting and big shoulders and modernized them in soft, floaty materials.

title: Can Hillary Clinton Keep You Safe?
description: When youre scared, do you feel safer with Mommy or with Daddy?

title: A Week of Whoppers From Donald Trump
description: Mr. Trump has unleashed a blizzard of falsehoods, exaggerations and outright lies in the general election. Here's our analysis of 31 untruths from Sept. 15-21.

title: Man, 20, in Custody After Fatal Shooting of 5 People at Mall Outside Seattle
description: A 20-year-old man was taken into custody on Saturday night in connection with a shooting that killed five people on Friday at a mall north of Seattle, the authorities said.

title: Journey From Class Clown to Suspect in Chelsea Bombing
description: If there was one child Mohammad Rahami had to worry about bringing shame upon the family, it was Ahmad. In the fifth grade, his teacher complained to Mr. Rahami that Ahmad acted like a king in class. In junior high, he broke a friends nose. Even worse was high school  after Mr. Rahami arranged for Ahmad to marry a good Afghan girl from Kabul, Ahmad dated a Dominican girl, getting her pregnant in his senior year.

title: Donald Trumps Movement Ad: Positive Message, Subtle Dig
description: Cheering crowds and Trump-branded skyscrapers mark a new ad from Donald J. Trumps campaign, titled Movement, its first commercial of the general election that is uplifting in tone.

title: Chinese Jews of Ancient Lineage Huddle Under Pressure
description: KAIFENG, China  The rooms where ruddy-faced Chinese men and women once assembled to pray in Hebrew and Mandarin are silent. Signs and exhibits that celebrated centuries of Jewish life have disappeared. An ancient well, believed to be the last visible remnant of a long-demolished synagogue, was recently buried under concrete and a pile of earth.

title: With Wayne Rooney Benched, Manchester United Looks Sharp Once Again
description: MANCHESTER, England  On the back of two straight Premier League defeats, Manchester United named a team to face Leicester City that did not contain its captain, Wayne Rooney. By halftime, with Rooney watching from the substitutes bench at Old Trafford, United had a four-goal lead, Jos Mourinhos side exhibiting precisely the kind of zip and poise it had recently so sorely lacked.

title: What I Learned From a Stroke at 26: Make Time to Untangle
description: As an idealistic, knowledge-hungry college graduate and aspiring writer, I had grown tired of hopping from one office gig to the next. It was 2000 and technology was in full bloom. I wanted to cash in on the digital gold rush. Like many of my friends in Austin, Tex., I figured, why not join the internet economy?

title: Rarity of Tulsa Shooting: Female Officers Are Almost Never Involved
description: Betty Jo Shelby drew her gun and warned the man to stop walking. But Terence Crutcher continued moving toward his S.U.V., which he had left in the middle of the road, the drivers side door open and the engine running. He was mumbling to himself, but his hands were raised in the air.

title: You Have 540 Days to Request a Refund, Starting 541 Days Ago
description: Longtime readers may remember the strange and colorful tale of Premier Cru, a wine store in Berkeley, Calif., that stiffed hundreds of customers who had ordered prearrival cases of high-end vino. The Haggler had never heard of prearrival wine either, but he learned that it is a way to pay for it well in advance to secure good prices on coveted vintages.

title: The Curative Power of Water, Waders and a Fly Rod
description: Scott Tarrant, 46, is manager of fly-fishing at the Broadmoor, a resort and hotel in Colorado Springs.

title: Beyond the Stats, Asdrubal Cabrera Is a Met Admired
description: The toll inflicted by Asdrubal Cabreras balky left knee has manifested itself in several ways. And last Tuesday, in a game at Citi Field against the Atlanta Braves, Cabrera could not hide it.

title: Donald Trumps Hotel Chain to Pay Penalty Over Data Breaches
description: Donald J. Trumps hotel chain agreed to pay a $50,000 penalty and revamp its data security policies after a couple of breaches exposed 70,000 credit card numbers and other personal information of its customers.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: In Syrian War, Russia Has Yet to Fulfill Superpower Ambitions
description: If you held up two maps of Syria  one from last September, when Russian forces first intervened in the chaotic civil war there, and one today  you would see that the battle lines look quite similar.

title: The Stakes in the Election
description: Readers discuss what a President Trump would mean for Americas future.

title: Taking the Stealth Out of Editing
description: IN the history of do-overs at The New York Times, there is one example that may seem of no large consequence but nonetheless infuriated readers. It involved an obituary about a rocket scientist named Yvonne Brill. In its first incarnation, the obit referred to 88-year-old Brill in the first paragraph as a woman who made a mean beef stroganoff, followed her husband around from job to job and took eight years off to raise three children. In secondary fashion, it mentioned that Brill was a pioneering scientist who invented a propulsion system that kept communications satellites in orbit.

title: The Trouble With Tylenol and Pregnancy
description: If youre a pregnant woman and have a backache or headache, or a fever, your options for over-the-counter treatment basically boil down to one medication: the pain reliever acetaminophen, better known as Tylenol. Doctors advise against using nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories, like ibuprofen and aspirin, during late pregnancy because they can compromise fetal circulation and have other adverse consequences.

title: The Sweet Relief of Splenda in My Purse
description: I feel a special kind of relief when I walk into a fancy coffee shop and see Splenda alongside the simple syrup and almond milk. Nowadays its trendy to eat all-natural, organic, clean. Were told its healthy and morally superior, even. But all I want in my iced coffee is the contents of those little yellow packets, or the blue ones, or pink.

title: Am I Introverted, or Just Rude?
description: A good friend and colleague, a real extrovert, sent me a link to a shirt recently that she knew Id appreciate. Sorry Im late, the T-shirt reads. I didnt want to be here.

title: Who Gets to Write What?
description: When I was in graduate school, I remember a fellow writer bringing to a workshop a lynching scene. The writer was not black. He was, in fact, a Chinese-American man named Bill Cheng, who would go on to write a novel of the blues called Southern Cross the Dog.

title: The Political Magic of C.S. Lewis
description: WHEN I was on Christmas break from college in 1980, I wrote a letter to the editor of my hometown newspaper, The Tri-City Herald. It was published soon after I began to embrace Christianity, a gradual rather than a dramatic process that didnt come all that easily.

title: The Debate Mismatch
description: PUNDITRY, like most human occupations, depends on pattern recognition. Certain things happen regularly; other things rarely; others never. Probabilities emerge, assumptions are formed, scenarios are considered and ruled out.

title: How to Cover a Charlatan Like Trump
description: WITH presidential debates approaching, we in journalism are locked in a fierce dispute: How should we report on a duplicitous demagogue?

title: My Debate Nightmare? A Duller Donald Trump
description: There are predictions that Monday nights presidential debate will shatter records, as one recent headline put it, drawing a Super Bowl-size audience of more than 100 million viewers.

title: Hillary Clintons Final Exam
description: EARLY in 2007, Barack Obama met Hillary Clinton at a candidates forum on health care in Las Vegas in one of their first encounters on a debate-like stage, in what would become one of the longest nominating battles in presidential campaign history.

title: Where to Go From the Anger in Charlotte
description: Charlotte, N.C.  On Wednesday, I spent the day here teaching a workshop for senior police leaders from around the country  deputies and sheriffs who are one step away from taking control of police departments of their own. That night, I went back to the Omni Charlotte Hotel. From my window, I could see lines of police officers assembled, and I could see protesters throwing various objects. I watched the officers release tear gas into the crowd.

title: Where Ice Once Crushed Ships, Open Water Beckons
description: This month, as the luxury cruise ship Crystal Serenity completed its pioneering transit of the Northwest Passage, a Canadian expedition announced the discovery of the Terror, a British ship that vanished along the same general Arctic route some 170 years ago.

title: Jets Matt Forte Is Showing His Game Hasnt Aged
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Matt Forte hoped to be among the few N.F.L. players who closed their careers where they had opened them. Drafted by the Chicago Bears in the second round in 2008, he amassed a league-leading 12,718 yards from scrimmage over eight seasons  8,602 rushing, 4,116 receiving  and established himself as the second-most-prolific running back in franchise history, after Walter Payton.

title: Obama Says African-American Museum Will Tell of Suffering and Delight
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, dedicating the National Museum of African American History and Culture on Saturday, said it would tell an American story, one of suffering and delight, one of fear, but also of hope, of wandering in the wilderness, and then seeing, out on the horizon, a glimmer of the Promised Land.

title: On the Trail: Week of Sept. 17
description: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump responded to the New York and New Jersey bombings, prepped for Mondays debate and campaigned across the country.

title: From Paradise to Hell: How an Aid Convoy in Syria Was Blown Apart
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The familiar hum of a drone lingered overhead as Omar Barakat, the local chief of the Red Crescent, watched workers unload lifesaving cargo at a warehouse in the rebel-held town of Urum al-Kubra, Syria.

title: Once a Hockey Lode, Quebec Now Yields Few Top Prospects
description: When the two-day Quebec Hockey Summit took place in Montreal in 2011, it touched on issues including head injuries and ways to improve the game.

title: 2008 Crisis Deepened the Ties Between Clintons and Goldman Sachs
description: A blue-ribbon commission had just excoriated Goldman Sachs and other Wall Street banks for fueling the financial crisis. Prosecutors were investigating whether Goldman had misled investors. The company was a whipping boy for politicians looking to lay blame for the crash.

title: In Red Sox Magical Season, Rick Porcello Has Been the Hidden Ace
description: Rick Porcello would rather play down the magnitude of his comeback this season. If he is proud of his quick ascent from a losing pitcher to the majors top winner, it is not for his resilience.

title: Jack Garman, Whose Judgment Call Saved Moon Landing, Dies at 72
description: On July 20, 1969, moments after mission control in Houston had given the Apollo 11 lunar module, Eagle, the O.K. to begin its descent to the moon, a yellow warning light flashed on the cockpit instrument panel.

title: $5 Trillion and Rising
description: This Man Oversees $5 Trillion, by Landon Thomas Jr. (Sept. 18) looked at Laurence D. Fink and the asset management firm he founded and heads, BlackRock. BlackRock has grown to control $5 trillion in assets by emphasizing rules-based, data-driven investments through vehicles like exchange-traded funds.

title: Bobby Breen, a Child Star Who Hit a High Note in the 1930s, Dies at 87
description: In the 1930s, with the United States paralyzed by the Depression, a small army of child stars lifted the nations spirits, offering innocence, hope and oodles of sentiment. Shirley Temple led the pack of adorables, but in 1936, a small but powerful rival appeared on the scene: an 8-year-old boy with an angelic face and a celestial voice, first raised heavenward in the film Lets Sing Again.

title: Odell Beckham, Josh Norman and an Antidote to On-Field Antagonism
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Victor Cruz knows it is not unusual for veteran defenders to try to rile young receivers with choice words during games.

title: IndyCars Newest Champion, Simon Pagenaud, Had Fast Assimilation to America
description: Even after he started racing cars, Simon Pagenaud was known as the son of the grocer in Montmorillon, France, about 220 miles southwest of Paris. His father, Christian, also the son of a grocer, would make it big there, eventually running a hypermarket franchise for E.Leclerc.

title: Snapchat, Known for Ephemera, Proves Its Staying Power With Videos
description: The Summer Olympics was something of a coming-out party for Snapchat, the mobile storytelling and messaging app.

title: Yielding to Pressure, Charlotte Releases Videos of Keith Scott Shooting
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Under mounting pressure from politicians, community leaders and boisterous protesters who have brought this citys main business district to a near standstill, the Charlotte police chief on Saturday released body and dashboard camera videos of the fatal police shooting of Keith Lamont Scott, a black resident here.

title: Syrian Forces Tighten Siege of Rebel-Held Areas in Aleppo
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  As wave and after wave of bombs fell on areas of eastern Aleppo in Syria, ground forces loyal to the Syrian government seized a rebel-held neighborhood on Saturday, intensifying the siege against the rebels and the many civilians who live among them.

title: Prospect of Philippine Thaw Slows Chinas Plans in South China Sea
description: BEIJING  Chinas next big target for construction of an artificial island in the South China Sea has long been assumed to be a cluster of rocks poking above sapphire waters near the Philippines.

title: Adding On
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Many solvers skip reading bylines and the Sunday puzzle titles and such, but I think thats a mistake. You might not need the assistance they provide, but when you do, those pieces of information can really help a person out.

title: Gennifer Flowers at Debate? Just Making a Point, Says Team Trump
description: Donald J. Trumps campaign moved on Sunday to squelch reports  set off by the candidate himself  that Gennifer Flowers, the woman whose claims of an affair with Bill Clinton imperiled his 1992 presidential campaign, would be Mr. Trumps guest on Monday at his first debate with Hillary Clinton.

title: The First Gore-Bush Debate
description: In a pivotal moment during the 2000 presidential campaign, a series of missteps by Al Gore at the first of three debates with George W. Bush was said to have damaged the vice president's chances of winning the presidency.

title: Jose Bautistas Homer Leaves Yankees in First Three-Shutout Skid Since 1975
description: TORONTO  There was no preening. There was no signature bat flip. But as soon as Jose Bautista connected with Tyler Clippards right-down-Spadina-Avenue fastball, there was no doubt.

title: Liberty and Mercury Players Join Anthem Protest Before Playoff Game
description: Liberty guard Brittany Boyd arrived at Madison Square Garden on Saturday for the first W.N.B.A. playoff game of her career wearing a No. 7 San Francisco 49ers jersey to support Colin Kaepernick, the quarterback whose decision not to stand for the national anthem has made him a lightning rod in discussions about race, violence and policing.

title: Bill Nunn, Who Played Radio Raheem in Do the Right Thing, Dies at 63
description: Bill Nunn, a versatile actor best known for playing the role of Radio Raheem, the boombox-toting neighborhood philosopher killed by police officers in Spike Lees 1989 film Do the Right Thing, died on Saturday in Pittsburgh. He was 63.

title: Dustin Johnson Shares Lead, but FedEx Cup Title Is in Reach
description: ATLANTA  Midway through his postround news conference Saturday, Dustin Johnson peered out at the room as a journalist questioned him about his trainer, Joey Diovisalvi, a fitness coach who is known for highlighting biomechanics. The journalist asked if Diovisalvi often used science in communication with Johnson, and Johnson cocked his head.

title: In a Roundabout Way, a Maine Towns Future May Turn on a Traffic Issue
description: BOOTHBAY, Maine  The craggy coast of Maine, dotted with lobster shacks, tidal inlets and fishing villages, has long been a popular summertime destination.

title: Home Teams Are Israeli, but Turf Is in West Bank
description: MAALE ADUMIM, West Bank  The latest battleground in the age-old struggle between Israelis and Palestinians is a remote patch of green artificial turf surrounded by barren desert hills in a place where dust gathers in the mouth before the afternoon sun begins to set.

title: A Poised Diana Taurasi Helps the Mercury Oust the Liberty
description: With a minute and a half remaining and one teams season destined to end in Saturday nights W.N.B.A. playoff game between the Liberty and Phoenix Mercury, Diana Taurasi, one of the W.N.B.A.s most reliable playoff performers, decided she had seen enough.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I will go to Bangalore. If I come back, then you can get me married. If I dont come back, you cant get me married.

title: Stanley Dural Jr., Founder of Buckwheat Zydeco, Dies at 68
description: Stanley Dural Jr., better known as Buckwheat, the accordionist whose band carried zydeco music from the Louisiana bayous to a worldwide audience, died on Saturday in Lafayette, La., where he was born. He was 68.

title: Rui Cheng, Scott Huang
description: Dr. Rui Cheng, the daughter of Shiying Wang and Dr. Wanli Cheng of Wilmington, N.C., was married Sept. 24 to Scott Huang, the son of Joanne Huang and Chih Hsueh Huang of Great Neck, N.Y. Nicholas J. Mora, a college friend of the couple, became a minister of the American Marriage Ministries to preside; he officiated at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J.

title: Logan McClellan, Robert Eshleman
description: Logan Michael McClellan, the son of Julia A. McClellan and Michael L. McClellan of Chesapeake, Va., was married Sept. 24 to Charles Robert Eshleman, the son of Elizabeth A. Boh and Charles L. Eshleman III, both of New Orleans, and the stepson of Helen F. Eshleman. Shane L. Regier, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Bryant Park Grill in New York.

title: Amy Goldstein, Jonathan Farber
description: Amy Lauren Goldstein, the daughter of Ellen Keats and Irv J. Goldstein of Greenwich, Conn., was married Sept. 24 to Jonathan David Farber, a son of Deborah G. Farber and Judge Sidney T. Farber of Penfield, N.Y. Rabbi Vicki Axe officiated at the Belle Haven Club in Greenwich.

title: Francesca Antonacci, Frank Del Vecchio Jr.
description: Francesca Rosa Antonacci, a daughter of Rosa Antonacci and Francesco Antonacci of Brooklyn, was married Sept. 23 to Frank William Del Vecchio Jr., the son of Frank Del Vecchio of Tampa, Fla., and the late Esther Del Vecchio. The Rev. Louis Olivieri, who was ordained by the One Spirit Interfaith Seminary, officiated at the Royalton Mansion in Roslyn Heights, N.Y.

title: Karen Sklaire, Mark Watson
description: Karen Sarah Sklaire and Mark Thomas Watson were married Sept. 24 at the Brant Point Lighthouse on Nantucket in Massachusetts. Mitchell H. Cohan, a friend of the brides family, who received a one-day solemnization certificate from Massachusetts, led a ceremony that incorporated Jewish traditions.

title: Hannah Wirfel, George Jones IV
description: Hannah Elisabeth Wirfel, a daughter of June A. Eichbaum and Kenneth I. Wirfel of Westport, Conn., is to be married Sept. 25 to George Davenport Jones IV, a son of Mary-Elisabeth Jones and Mr. Jones III of Concord, Mass. Rabbi Devon Lerner is to officiate with the assistance of the Rev. William Eddy, an Episcopal priest, at the Wianno Club in Osterville, Mass.

title: Christina Kim, Mark Wagner
description: Christina Kay Kim, the daughter of Susan K. Kim and Young K. Kim of Huntsville, Ala., is to be married Sept. 25 to Mark Jason Wagner, a son of Robin M. Wagner and Eric M. Wagner of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Deborah Roth, an interfaith minister, is to officiate at the Liberty House Restaurant in Jersey City.

title: Jessica Flores, Peter Griffin
description: Jessica Dina Flores and Peter Suratos Griffin are to be married Sept. 25 in Sedona, Ariz. The Rev. Phillip Waring, a nondenominational Christian minister, is to officiate at the Sedona Golf Resort.

title: Sabrina Ross, Michael Grafton
description: Sabrina Boyson Ross and Michael Allen Grafton were married Sept. 24. Jarrett M. Robinson, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, officiated at Campovida, a winery in Hopland, Calif.

title: Ricardo Daziano, Rolf Noyer
description: Ricardo Daziano and Robert Rolf Noyer were married Sept. 24. The Rev. Erika L. Takacs performed the ceremony at St. Marks Episcopal Church in Philadelphia, where she is the associate rector.

title: Audrey Starkebaum, Jesse Bragg
description: Audrey Ann Starkebaum, the daughter of Julia A. Starkebaum and John C. Starkebaum of Haxtun, Colo., was married there Sept. 24 to Jesse Sumner Bragg II, the son of Margaret McMahon Bragg of Ayer, Mass., and the late Jonathan V. Bragg. Colby J. Starkebaum, a brother of the bride who was ordained by the Open Ministry Church for the occasion, officiated at the farm of the brides parents.

title: Felicia Quentzel, Daniel Albano
description: Felicia Caroline Quentzel, the daughter of Dr. Jill A. Wiener and Dr. Howard L. Quentzel of Westport, Conn., was married Sept. 24 to Daniel Anthony Albano, the son of Bridget C. Albano and Anthony G. Albano of Avondale, Pa. Rabbi Michael S. Friedman officiated at Birchwood Country Club in Westport.

title: Courtney Shelly, Quinton Farrar
description: Courtney Maureen Shelly, the daughter of Kathleen OBrien Shelly and William C. Shelly of Rochester, was married Sept. 24 to Quinton Cannon Farrar, a son of Priscilla M. Farrar and Quinton J. Farrar of Keene, N.H. The Rev. Robert VerEecke, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York.

title: Cassandra Johnson, Frederick Ilchman
description: Cassandra Snow Johnson and Frederick Andrew Crawford Ilchman were married Sept. 24 by the Rev. Dr. William W. Rich, an Episcopal priest, at Trinity Church in Boston.

title: Mary-Nicole Dorn, Sean OConnor
description: Mary-Nicole Dorn, a daughter of Ali Dorn and John G. Dorn of Ridgefield, Conn., was married Sept. 24 to Sean Patrick OConnor, the son of Elizabeth G. OConnor and John D. OConnor of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Russell Augustine, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Marys Roman Catholic Church in Ridgefield.

title: Temi Adeniji, Osifo Akhuemonkhan
description: Hameedat Temi Adeniji, the daughter of Oluwatoyin A. Adeniji and Lateph A. Adeniji of Arlington, Tex., was married Sept. 24 to Osifo Odili Akhuemonkhan, the son of Elizabeth A. Akhuemonkhan and Edward E. Akhuemonkhan of Abuja, Nigeria. The Rev. Donald Ours, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Catholic Church in Dallas. A traditional Nigerian Yoruba ceremony took place at Noahs Event Venue in Irving, Tex., on Sept. 22.

title: Emma Kynoch, Marc Lowenstein
description: Emma Catherine Kynoch and Marc Gabriel Lowenstein were married Sept. 24 at the Hill, a farm and estate in Hudson, N.Y., where Rabbi Richard S. Winer officiated.

title: Emily Woodward, Warren Michelsen
description: Emily Detwiler Woodward and Warren William Michelsen were married Sept. 24 by the Rev. David J. Ware, an Episcopal priest, at the Church of the Redeemer in Baltimore.

title: Claire Moriarty, Justin Schaeffer
description: Claire Creelman Moriarty, a daughter of Carol C. Moriarty and John J. Moriarty II of Winchester, Mass., was married Sept. 24 to Justin Harris Schaeffer, the son of Elisabeth H. Schaeffer and Peter N. Schaeffer of Essex Fells, N.J. Clayton S. Rose, a friend of the grooms family, officiated at the Wauwinet, a hotel on Nantucket in Massachusetts, having received permission from the state of Massachusetts to solemnize the marriage.

title: Elizabeth Su, Andrew Lee
description: Elizabeth Carter Su, a daughter of Christin Carter-Su and Dr. Eugene Yuan Su of Ann Arbor, Mich., was married Sept. 24 to Andrew Cheuk Ho Lee, a son of Karen Ka Ling Tse and Sunny Shing Kuen Lee of Vancouver, Wash. Nansee New, who was ordained by the Church of Divine Man, led a nondenominational ceremony at Hollys Ocean Meadow, a vacation rental property in Fort Bragg, Calif.

title: Brittany Marom, Zachary Chodorow
description: Brittany Paulina Marom, a daughter of Annette I. Marom and David Marom of Manhattan, was married Sept. 24 to Zachary Brian Chodorow, a son of Linda M. Chodorow and Jeffrey R. Chodorow of Miami. Rabbi Elliot M. Strom officiated at the vegetable and produce farm of the grooms parents in New Hope, Pa.

title: Tracy Dansker, Timothy Sacks
description: Tracy Suzanne Dansker, the daughter of Randi S. Ott of Hallandale Beach, Fla., and Lowell S. Dansker of Manhattan, was married Sept. 24 to Timothy Peter Sacks, the son of Judith K. Sacks and Dr. Michael H. Sacks of Manhattan. Cantor Nancy L. Bach officiated at the Roundhouse, an event space in Beacon, N.Y.

title: Chelsey Lutz, Timothy Kirby
description: Chelsey Nicole Lutz, a daughter of Kerry H. Lutz of Jupiter, Fla., and the late Barbara L. Lutz, was married Sept. 24 to Timothy James Kirby, a son of Dynda L. Andrews of Westhampton, N.Y., and John J. Kirby Jr. of Stamford, Conn. The ceremony took place at the home of the groom's father and stepmother, Susan R. Cullman. The groom's mother, a retired judge of the New York City Criminal Court, officiated.

title: Elizabeth Lohr, Daniel Vaughan
description: Elizabeth Mary Lohr, the daughter of Mary DeSales Lohr and Dr. Frederick T. Lohr of Chestertown, Md., was married Sept. 24 to Daniel Hugh Vaughan, a son of Karen P. Vaughan and John T. Vaughan of Mendham, N.J. The Rev. Andrew King, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patricks Cathedral in New York.

title: Stephanie Strohm, Max Lando
description: Stephanie Kate Strohm, a daughter of Mary Banks Strohm and Frank A. Strohm of Fairfield, Conn., was married Sept. 24 to Max Benjamin Lando, the son of Ruth Mayle Lando and Michael A. Lando of Sarasota, Fla. Michael R. Albert, a friend of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Barn at Flanagan Farm in Buxton, Me.

title: Tyler Infinger, Peter Ryan
description: Tyler Kathryn Infinger, the daughter of Anne S. Infinger and Glenn T. Infinger of Atlanta, was married Sept. 24 to Peter Francis Ryan, the son of Patricia A. Ryan and Thomas E. Ryan of Holden, Mass. The Rev. Emily Wilmarth, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Highlands, N.C.

title: Alexandra Levy, Robert Richardson
description: Alexandra Nicole Levy and Robert Anthony Richardson III are to be married Sept. 25 at Maritime Parc, an event space in Jersey City. Andrew J. Dolinsky, a friend of the couple who became a minister of American Marriage Ministries for the event, is to officiate.

title: Hibah Hussain, Timothy Grayson
description: Hibah Hussain and Timothy Hannon Grayson were married Sept. 24 at Riverside on the Potomac, an event space on a horse farm in Leesburg, Va. William Fox, a Virginia civil celebrant, officiated at a ceremony led by John S. Burnam, a friend of the groom, who incorporated some Bengali wedding traditions.

title: Jennifer Stephens, Gordon Lessersohn
description: Jennifer Anne Stephens, a daughter of Myna J. Stephens and Craig A. Stephens of Untergeri, Switzerland, is to be married Sept. 25 to Gordon James Lessersohn, the son of Louise N. Lessersohn and James C. Lessersohn of Oradell, N.J. The Rev. Kevin Cross, an Episcopal priest, is to perform the ceremony at the First Parish Church Unitarian Universalist in Portland, Me.

title: Kate Liberman, Eric Gershman
description: Kate Elizabeth Liberman, the daughter of Joni Levy Liberman and Jeffrey A. Liberman of Needham, Mass., is to be married Sept. 25 to Eric Robert Gershman, a son of Ellen Mendelsohn Gershman and Howard Gershman of Hopewell Junction, N.Y. Rabbi Carl M. Perkins is to perform the ceremony at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue in White Plains.

title: Katharine Planitzer, Michael Harper
description: Katharine Elizabeth Planitzer, a daughter of Ruth G. Fleischmann of Manhattan and Russell E. Planitzer of Carmel, Calif., was married Sept. 24 to Michael Joseph Harper, a son of Theresa A. Horney and L. Frederick Horney II of Fair Haven, N.J. The Rev. Sarah Stewart, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. James Church in Manhattan.

title: Mets Rally From 10-0 Deficit but Fall Just Short of Record Comeback
description: As Lucas Duda stepped to the plate with one out in the ninth inning Saturday night, Mets Manager Terry Collins thought his team was about to cap a wild game by securing the largest comeback victory in franchise history. So much zaniness had already happened that many in the stands at Citi Field must have felt so, too.

title: Hall Carlough, Michael Kriak
description: Hall Carlough and Michael Anthony Kriak were married Sept. 24 at the Storm King Art Center in New Windsor, N.Y. Shelly Eversley, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Katherine Peek, Conor Tochilin
Andreea Akerele, Khary Francis
description: Andreea Folasade Akerele, a daughter of Dr. Corina Dutcus of Wyckoff, N.J., and Dr. Evaristo Akerele of Mahwah, N.J., was married Sept. 24 to Khary Dexter Francis, a son of Dr. Rhonda McIntyre-Francis and Dexter Francis of Roseau, Dominica. The Rev. Dr. Leslie Mott, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Boscobel House and Gardens, an estate in Garrison, N.Y.

title: Elyssa Feins, Michael Nadler
description: Elyssa Beth Feins, the daughter of Marcy B. Feins of Ocala, Fla., and Jeffrey B. Feins of Naples, Fla., is to be married Sept. 25 to Michael Nadler, the son of Joyce Miller and Jerrold Nadler of Manhattan. Rabbi Marcelo Bronstein is to officiate at the Hilton Pearl River in Pearl River, N.Y., with Rabbi Rolando Matalon to take part.

title: Abra Metz-Dworkin, Evan Gogel
description: Abra Metz-Dworkin, the daughter of Cathy S. Metz and Jeffrey Dworkin of Montpelier, Vt., was married Sept. 24 to Evan Wood Gogel, the son of Georgia Wall Gogel and Donald J. Gogel of New York. Leah Gogel Pope, a sister of the groom who received authorization to solemnize the marriage from the State of Vermont, led a ceremony incorporating Jewish and Unitarian Universalist elements at Riverside Farm in Pittsfield, Vt.

title: Whats on TV Sunday: ABC Dramas and Overseas Opera
description: Fall television is in full swing as three dramas  Once Upon a Time, Secrets and Lies and Quantico  return on ABC. Opera lovers can tap into the European scene with Eugene Onegin, streaming online from a performance in Britain.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: Jewish and Chinese: Explaining a Shared Identity
description: The ancient Jewish community of Kaifeng, in central China, was experiencing a cultural and religious revival until a recent government clampdown, which has brought a ban on collective worship and forced out foreign Jewish groups. Moshe Yehuda Bernstein is a researcher based in Perth, Western Australia, who has studied this revival and written a coming book, Globalization, Translation and Transmission: Sino-Judaic Cultural Identity in Kaifeng, China. In an interview, Mr. Bernstein explained the background to the recent revival and official restrictions.

title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: 370 East 76th Street, #C609, Upper East Side

description: Edward Dolman is chairman and chief executive of Phillips, the international auction house.

title: Stanfords Flawless Finish Masks Its Need for a Quarterback
description: PASADENA, Calif.  Two end-of-game drives on Saturday  one here at the Rose Bowl, one across the country in Auburn, Ala.  turned out very differently. One extended a teams national championship aspirations, the other effectively ended the long tenure of one of college footballs most lovable, frustrating and just plain noticeable coaches.

title: Presidential Debate, Charlotte, Syria: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here are the weeks top stories, and a look ahead.

title: Debacle: What Al Gores First Debate Against George W. Bush Can Teach Hillary Clinton
description: The October 2000 showdown was seen by some as a deciding factor in that presidential race. Our oral history reveals lessons for the 2016 Democratic nominee.

title: China Hunts for Scientific Glory, and Aliens, With New Telescope
description: PINGTANG COUNTY, China  When hundreds of engineers and builders began clambering up a jagged hill in southwestern China to assemble a giant telescope in a deep, bowl-shaped basin, poor villagers sometimes crept over the sheer slopes to glimpse the countrys latest technological wonder.

description: When Eugene Richards opens his next exhibit, it will not be at a Chelsea gallery or a major Midtown museum. It will be at a location that he much prefers: the Bronx Documentary Center.

title: Writer Charged With Insulting Islam Is Killed as Extremism Boils Over in Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Some of the most extreme elements in Jordan made clear in recent weeks that Nahed Hattar should pay for a provocative cartoon he posted online depicting a bearded man in bed with two women ordering God to bring him cashews and wine.

title: Stella Jean: Spring 2017
description: The Haitian-born, Rome-based designer shows her spring 2017 collection.

title: Marlins Pitcher Jose Fernandez Is Killed in a Boating Accident
description: MIAMI  Major League Baseball lost one of its best pitchers this weekend when a boat carrying Jose Fernandez of the Miami Marlins struck a pile of rocks and capsized, killing him and two other men aboard.

title: How to Get Marnis Clean, Glowy Beauty
description: At Marni, Consuelo Castiglioni put forth a new spring/summer collection full of floaty accordion pleat dresses, and looks in single, all-over colors. Tom Pecheux, the makeup artist who has been collaborating with Castiglioni since she launched the brand in 1994, avoided distracting from the colorful clothes by creating a clean, purified beauty look, illuminated by layers of highlights. He eschewed foundation, mascara and lipstick, and added only coats of shimmer on the face.

title: Jane Pauley to Become Anchor of CBS Show Sunday Morning
description: The veteran television personality Jane Pauley will replace Charles Osgood as the anchor of the highly rated CBS show Sunday Morning. Mr. Osgood, who is retiring, announced the news on his last show on Sunday.

title: Activist in South Korea Dies of Injuries From Police Water Cannon
description: SEOUL, South Korea  An activist farmer who was expelled from school twice for protesting the rule of the military dictator Park Chung-hee of South Korea died on Sunday as a result of injuries he sustained while opposing Mr. Parks daughter, President Park Geun-hye.

title: N.F.L.: Heres What We Learned in Week 3
description: In the N.F.L. these days, young quarterbacks are all the rage. There once was a time when a team would have to wait two or three years for a young quarterback to develop, but not anymore. The Eagles, with 23-year old Carson Wentz at quarterback, are 3-0. The Broncos, behind 23-year old Trevor Siemian, are also 3-0. And the Cowboys, riding red-hot 23-year old Dak Prescott, are 2-1.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Good morning. Its a good day for a project dinner, something ambitious but not crazily so, the sort of meal to put a capstone on the weekend, mark it a success. Ill give you sensible recipes for weeknight fare, as always. But for this evenings meal, itd be great if you could plan big and then execute. Youll deliver incredible delight to whomever you serve.

title: 1941: Turkey Cool To Nazis
description: LONDON  Strong representations reportedly transmitted to Turkey by Fuehrer Adolf Hitler in an effort to make that country either withdraw from the Anglo-Turkish agreement or else enter the war actively on the side of the Axis apparently are meeting with little success, informed British sources said tonight [Sept. 25]. Turkey, admittedly in a precarious position, has shown no inclination to accept any of the recent German offers. One London authority on international affairs said: The Anglo-Turkish pact [the tripartite agreement by Great Britain, France and Turkey about six months after the start of the war] has made Germany proceed most cautiously in her relations with Turkey.

title: Everyone Knows Peter, Paul and Mary. But What About Bob?
description: The world is full of who-knew jobs, jobs you did not know were jobs until you found out that somebody did them. Who knew that Peter, Paul and Mary had a recording secretary?

title: Foreign Policy Questions to Ask Clinton and Trump at the Debate
description: The United States is still fighting a war in Afghanistan and has troops in Iraq, the Iranian nuclear deal remains controversial, the Islamic State is weakened but continues to be threatening, North Korea is launching missiles, Russia flouts international norms, and China has expansionary designs.

title: Threes a Trend: That 70s Suit
description: Threes a trend  or Threes Company? The 70s are alive and well in Milan this season, with a handful of designers showing new takes on the leisure suit. At Gucci, Alessandro Michele debuted grommet-embellished denim bell bottoms with a slim jacket with wide lapels; at Roberto Cavalli, Peter Dundas went hippie-by-way-of-Marrakech with patchwork jeans paired with a striped blazer and layered scarves and enamel jewelry. Finally at Giamba, prints clashed as floral funnel pants came mixed with a cropped jacket and a contrasting tie blouse.

description: When Donald Trump began his improbable run for president 15 months ago, he offered his wealth and television celebrity as credentials, then slyly added a twist of fearmongering about Mexican rapists flooding across the Southern border.

title: Review: Paris Opera Ballet Kicks Off New Season With Futuristic Choreography
description: PARIS  Tropical flowers dripped off the gilded balconies and balustrades of the Palais Garnier. Huge parrots presided over the brightly hued display, and a tiger prowled through the plant-filled basin of a fountain. French pop stars and actors posed for photographs; women in couture on needle-sharp heels negotiated the crowds. (The parrots and tiger were stuffed. The women were real.)

title: The Magnificent Seven Dominates Weekend North American Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES  An honest-to-goodness western, The Magnificent Seven, arrived to a solid $35 million in domestic ticket sales over the weekend, proving that studios can make hay from worn genres and remakes if they are conceived in a totally new way.

description: By Melanie Finn308 pages. Two Dollar Radio. $16.99.

title: Taking On Tristan, a Role That Demands Much of a Tenor
description: A few months after the premiere performances of Wagners Tristan und Isolde, the first Tristan, Ludwig Schnorr von Carolsfeld, fell ill. As he died, he reportedly began to sing fragments of his characters prolonged death scene. Wagner, struck with guilt, wrote: My Tristan! My beloved! I drove you to the abyss.

title: Review: The Choice 2016 Lets the Chips Fall Where They May on Clinton and Trump
description: Each presidential election since 1988, PBSs Frontline has produced The Choice, an in-depth bio-documentary on the two major-party nominees  governors, senators, vice presidents, incumbents. (The 1992 edition did not include the businessman and independent candidate Ross Perot.)

title: Yankees Bullpen Falters as Blue Jays Rally for Win in the Ninth
description: TORONTO  Once upon a time, the Yankees had a bullpen that was so indomitable that it sent fear into opposing dugouts, shortened games, and spawned T-shirt sales and pithy nicknames.
