description: Q. I just upgraded to iOS 10. Where did the shortcut camera icon in the bottom corner of the iPhone lock screen go? That was useful.

title: In Bruce Springsteens America, Many Turn Toward Donald Trump
description: Bruce Springsteen is often called the troubadour of white, working-class America, a landscape he explores  in his autobiography released this week. But this election, the Republican presidential nominee, Donald J. Trump, has captured many of those blue-collar voters hearts, with his denunciation of trade deals and promises to bring back manufacturing.

title: Wildlife Management: The View From Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: Donald Trump and Nuclear Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: Ohio, Long a Bellwether, Is Fading on the Electoral Map
description: ATHENS, Ohio  After decades as one of Americas most reliable political bellwethers, an inevitable presidential battleground that closely mirrored the mood and makeup of the country, Ohio is suddenly fading in importance this year.

title: After Outcry, Mir Collection to Stay in Portugal
description: MADRID  Portugals government has decided to keep a collection of works by the artist Joan Mir, more than two years after the pieces set off  a national debate over whether such cultural patrimony could be sold to help improve the countrys finances.

title: Fantasy Football: Players to Start in Week 4
description: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.

title: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
description: Andrew Rosenthal, a Times opinion columnist, on the latest Aleppo bombing, the presidential debate, Bridget Joness Baby and more. Susan Lehman is host.

title: New York City Starts $5 Million Fund for Women in Film and Theater
description: New York is set to become the first city in the country with a major municipal program geared toward helping female filmmakers and theater-makers. The Mayors Office of Media and Entertainment is to announce on Thursday a new five-part initiative to promote equality behind and in front of the camera, in film and television, as well as onstage.

title: Balmain: Spring 2017
description: Olivier Rousteing presents his spring looks.

title: Joseph Harmatz, Who Led Jewish Plot to Kill Germans After World War II, Dies at 91
description: Imagine a real-life version of Inglourious Basterds, Quentin Tarantinos quixotic movie about Jewish avengers in World War II  but in this case involving a plot by a band of refugees to kill millions of Germans just after the war by poisoning their water supply.

title: Share Your Experiences as a Female Police Officer
description: Wed like to hear from female police officers about how being a woman plays out while in the line of duty.

title: Breaking Bad News to Patients
description: I carried the knowledge like a millstone chained around my neck, my back aching from the emotional weight of bad news not yet imparted.

title: Alexis Mabille: Spring 2017
description: The labels spring 2017 collection.

title: Daily Report: When Artificial Intelligence Goes to the Dark Side
description: Computers really are becoming like people: Just because they are smart doesnt mean they wont do awful things.

title: Wine for the Ages, Without Artifice
description: Stanislao Radikon died of cancer a few weeks ago, on Sept. 11. He was just 62, and though most casual wine consumers may never have heard of him, his wines epitomized a level of beauty and truth sought by wine lovers every time they open a bottle.

title: Californias Hotel Bungalow Boom
description: Historic hotel bungalows have a timeless allure that dates back to the early 20th century, when they were first introduced to accommodate families needing more space and privacy. Today, three California properties are reviving the traditional Hollywood hide-out.

title: Mahmoud Abbas to Attend Shimon Peres Funeral, but Thaw With Israel Is Unlikely
description: JERUSALEM  In death as in life, Shimon Peres will bring together longtime adversaries. But no one expects reconciliation when Israeli and Palestinian leaders both attend his funeral on Friday.

title: Salesforce Is Said to Question Microsoft-LinkedIn Deal in Europe
description: Microsoft outmuscled its rival Salesforce.com this year to buy LinkedIn, the professional social network, for $26.2 billion.

title: Which Debate Clips Got Replayed the Most on CNN, Fox News and MSNBC
description: In the 24 hours after the candidates first confrontation, the three networks replayed several of the pivotal moments, often highlighting different clips.

title: Google Searches for Voter Registration Have Surged in Hispanic Areas
description: In the real world, demographic change is gradual: Every day, the country becomes a tad more diverse as babies are born, people immigrate, and others die.

title: Threes a Trend: Throwback Sportswear
description: Throughout the latter half of fashion month, designers have pulled out retro-inspired sportswear. First, in Milan, variations on old-school tracksuits (like this chevron-striped, half-zip sweater) came down the runway at Versaces show, which celebrated athleticism. On the first day of Paris, the up-and-coming designer Christelle Kocher showed a 90s-inspired windbreaker at her Koch show. And at Maison Margiela, John Galliano put his own spin on the trend with a navy and neon-yellow windbreaker paired with a matching skirt, labeled Tortuga.

title: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this podcast, Andrew Rosenthal, an Op-Ed columnist, shares his thoughts about the news  the good, the bad and that which makes him mad.

title: Youll Find Me in My Hammock, Inside
description: On a recent Saturday afternoon, a bit overtaxed from the mornings pancake making and the previous evenings socializing, I flopped into my hammock. To and fro I swayed, as if pushed by a beachy breeze.

title: Can Goodness and Prejudice Coexist?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bundy Brothers Defend Armed Occupation of Oregon Refuge
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Ammon and Ryan Bundy, who led an armed occupation to protest federal control of Western lands  much of which was captured on video and streamed online  began their defense in court this week.

title: Keep the Tax Returns, Trump; Just Give Us a Few Figures
description: Mr. Trump, I have a deal for you.

title: The Sweet Emotional Life of Bees
description: It is hard enough to figure out emotions in humans  but insects?

title: A New Chapter in Book Prizes: Readers Are the Winners
description: The rules of the competition are simple. Pick a book that means a great deal to you  more than any other book youve read (a caveat: It must have been published for the first time in English within the last 80 years, so no Austen, no Lampedusa, no Sir Gawain and the Green Knight). Submit its name to the London bookstore Heywood Hill, which is celebrating its 80th birthday this year, sometime before midnight Oct. 31.

title: Chaos at Hoboken Station After Train Flew Through the Air
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  New Jersey Transit train No. 1614 just did not stop.

title: Eerie Historical Parallels?
description: To the Editor:

title: What Wells Fargos C.E.O. Told Congress
description: Nine days ago, the leader of Wells Fargo faced a skeptical Senate committee for more than two hours. Today, he was denounced for more than four hours at a House panel.

title: Meditation Journeys
description: Download the NYT VR app and allow yourself to be transported to some of California's most spectacular vistas and take a moment to meditate on the tranquil sights and sounds of nature.

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Every week, editors at the Book Review pick our favorites of the books reviewed in the previous issue and call them Editors Choice. Its our chance to heap extra praise on books that got stellar reviews and to give books that didnt get a great review an endorsement of our own. One book that famously got a negative review  All the Light We Cannot See, by Anthony Doerr  went on to be an Editors Choice, a massive best seller (125 weeks on the hardcover fiction list and counting) and one of our 10 Best Books of 2014.

title: Canada Stuns Europe in Final Minutes to Sweep World Cup
description: TORONTO  The problem with being Sidney Crosby is that he can never be ordinary. Others will not let him, and he will not stand for it.

title: Mary Weber Novak, Top California Vintner, Dies at 84
description: Mary Weber Novak, who took over Spottswoode, her familys Napa Valley vineyard, after her husbands death and turned it into one of Californias top producers of cabernet sauvignon and sauvignon blanc, died on Sunday in St. Helena, Calif. She was 84.

title: Grappling With a Teenagers Accidental Pregnancy
description: My 18-year-old daughter will soon give birth, a month after she was to begin college on an academic scholarship. The pregnancy was accidental. The boy, who was in recovery, has relapsed into drug use and is not seeing her. (He is in treatment.) But his parents, whom I have never met, have been very kind to her and want to be active grandparents. We will probably meet them at the hospital. This will be awkward, and I worry that their involvement will bring their unstable son back into our orbit. How should I handle this?

title: In By the People, Designing for the Underserved and Overlooked
description: A few years ago, while Chattanooga, Tenn., made headlines for revitalizing its downtown, residents, mostly African-Americans, living just a few miles away in the Glass Farms neighborhood, were struggling to cope with years of disinvestment and decline. Storefronts were empty, buildings abandoned. Crime was through the roof.

title: Transparent Season 3: Watched It All? Lets Talk
description: Now that weve watched the third season of Transparent  and sobbed over Shellys cabaret rendition of Alanis Morissettes Hand in My Pocket from the finale  its time to take stock of yet another season of the Pfeffermans ceaseless navel-gazing.

title: Nineties Supermodels, Paired With Satire
description: A new exhibition and book combine Miles Ladins starry black-and-white photos of Kate Moss, Naomi Campbell and more with tongue-in-cheek excerpts from Bret Easton Elliss Glamorama.

title: Rick Owens: Spring 2017
description: Mr. Owens, who recently opened an outpost in New York City, presents his spring looks.

title: Isabel Marant: Spring 2017
description: The labels spring 2017 collection.

title: Review: Passage to Mars, an Otherworldly Voyage on Earth
description: Take Ice Road Truckers, mix it with The Martian and blend in a book of verse, and youve got something that resembles Passage to Mars, a beguiling documentary thats concerned as much with images as it is with information.

title: How to Get Home After the Hoboken Train Crash
description: Thursday mornings fatal train crash at the Hoboken Terminal in New Jersey, a hub used by nearly 60,000 people a day, crippled mass transit in the area and is likely to snarl the evening commute.

title: Building Zaha Hadids Bold Afterlife
description: ANTWERP, BELGIUM  For architects, or at least for Zaha Hadid, there is an afterlife. On Sept. 22, nearly six months after this British architects sudden death at 65, one of her boldest buildings, Port House, opened in a ceremony on the newly christened Zaha Hadid Square in Antwerp. Under the soaring prow of a dynamically angled glass-and-steel structure drifting like an airship over a palatial brick firehouse, a chorus and orchestra performed the Ode to Joy from Beethovens Ninth Symphony.  The score and backdrop amounted to a curtain rising on the second act of Ms. Hadids career, as operatic as any since Frank Lloyd Wrights.

title: Beethovens Wig Combines Classical Music With Seussian Whimsy
description: Instrumental music tends not to charm children, unless an ice cream truck is playing the tune. And a classical piece like Beethovens Fifth Symphony? Not a good bet.

title: Wells Fargos Reaction to Scandal Fails to Satisfy Angry Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON  He is forfeiting at least $41 million in pay. He vows that his bank will drop its sales incentive program  blamed for prompting bankers to set up illegal and unauthorized bank and credit card accounts to meet their sales goals  by the end of the week, not in January, as he had previously promised.

title: The Secrets Behind Sargents Intimate Portrait of a Jewish Family
description: I have not recovered from the joy of Shortgrove being ours and we enrolled among the landed gentry of England, the British society figure and philanthropist Adle Meyer wrote to her son, Frank, in 1903.

title: Review: Never Surrender: The Ed Ramsey Story, an Overdue Paean to a War Hero
description: Never Surrender: The Ed Ramsey Story introduces one of the hundreds  if not thousands  of inspiring military heroes from World War II whose valor and courage have rarely gotten wide notice and appropriate appreciation.

title: Och-Ziff to Pay Over $400 Million in Bribery Settlement
description: Africa once represented a lucrative new market for a giant New York hedge fund.

title: American Airstrike Killed Afghan Civilians, U.N. Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The United Nations mission in Afghanistan on Thursday condemned an American airstrike it said had killed at least 15 civilians in eastern Afghanistan, a day after American and Afghan officials said they had targeted a gathering of Islamic State affiliates.

title: Luke Cage Puts Race at the Center of the Story
description: In the connected series of movies and television shows known as the Marvel Cinematic Universe, which occupies an inordinate amount of territory in our popular culture, theres a quiet corner that belongs to Netflix. The Netflix-Marvel series, focusing on a mostly second-tier group of heroes  so far Daredevil, Jessica Jones and, beginning on Friday, Luke Cage  have been a laboratory in turning comic books into live-action TV without the noisy battles and tag-team group heroics of Marvel mainstays like the Avengers, X-Men and Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.

title: Harvest Lunch to Celebrate Hudson Valley
description: Glasses will be raised next month in the Hudson Valley to toast the harvest, a chef and an anniversary. On Oct. 8, the chef Terrance Brennan will prepare a three-course lunch as part of Celebrate Our Love of the Hudson Valley, an event to benefit the FarmOn! Foundation, which supports educational programs and local family farms. The meal will include local cheeses and charcuterie, pumpkin bisque, chicken grilled over wine vines and an array of apple desserts. The wine pairing will feature vintages from Clinton Vineyards, which is hosting the event and celebrating its 40th anniversary.

title: Chains, Whips and Misery: Studying and Preserving Old Lunatic Asylums
description: Mental hospitals have an unsettling history, which is the subject of many museum exhibitions and books this fall. The scholarship illuminates how for centuries reformers tried to prevent cruel treatment of the mentally ill and worked to develop architecture that would provide comfort while keeping patients away from the public. Historians and preservationists are trying to save the isolated buildings that resulted from these efforts and are poring over sometimes-forgotten archives.

title: Review: Masterminds, a Tale of Grand Larceny and Meager Gray Matter
description: I blame popular culture, Zach Galifianakis says at the start of this comedy, the ridiculousness of his Southern accent rivaling that of his very fluffy hairstyle. His character, David Ghantt  a real-life felon who took part in an ostentatious crime in the late 1990s  is rationalizing his own miscreant deeds for the audience of Masterminds, a would-be memorable piece of popular culture that applies the TV-sketch-show-surreal-farce approach to a based-on-true-events caper picture.

title: Review: The Rolling Stones Ol, Ol, Ol! Captures Tour Euphoria in Latin America
description: Early in The Rolling Stones Ol, Ol, Ol!, Mick Jagger notes that several Latin American nations in the 1960s and 70s censored rock music. The Rolling Stones, being part of this rebellious movement, he adds, was anathema to a lot of these regimes.

title: A Bold New Landing for Modern Art at the National Gallery
description: WASHINGTON  Supposedly, we live in a great age of collecting, though the greatness is strictly in volume. Art fairs and auction houses keep product coming: painting, sculpture, some photography, stuff you can stick a price tag on. It seems impossible that there were times when unknown artists could make untaggable art and survive.

title: Slouching Toward Accountability at Wells Fargo
description: In testimony on Thursday before the House Financial Services committee, John Stumpf, chairman and chief executive of Wells Fargo, largely stuck to the script from a week before, when he appeared before the Senate Banking committee to answer questions about phony customer accounts at the bank. But in one way, he was a changed man: He was less wealthy by tens of millions of dollars.

title: Julie Mehretu on Her Influences, Auction Pressure and New Paintings
description: At first glance, the paintings on the walls may not look all that different from what Julie Mehretu has done before. There are the marks, the layering, the allusions to current events.

title: Review: In Amanda Knox, a Murder and Journalism Run Amok
description: You dont have to remember the gutter headlines inspired by its namesake to find the true-crime documentary Amanda Knox completely riveting. And not because of the lip-smacking speculations surrounding Ms. Knoxs eight-year battle with the Italian legal system after being charged with the 2007 murder of a housemate and fellow exchange student, Meredith Kercher. Rather, the directors, Brian McGinn and Rod Blackhurst, have produced a tightly edited, coherently structured and ultimately moving reassessment that burrows beneath the lurid in search of the illuminating.

title: Review: Songs of Lear, We Hear Cordelia Singing
description: The King Lear evoked in Songs of Lear shares so little with Shakespeares tragedy that the shows director, Grzegorz Bral, delivers an explanatory introduction onstage. This is doubly helpful because Songs of Lear also shares little with traditional, linear storytelling, and large parts of it are in untranslated Latin and Polish  in other words, its hard to tell whats going on. While you dont need to know King Lear to appreciate the show, it certainly helps.

title: Video of Fatal Police Shooting of Louisiana Boy, 6, Is Released
description: The police video footage of the last moments of 6-year-old Jeremy Mardiss life shows deputy marshals firing a barrage of bullets at his fathers S.U.V. after a car chase on the dark streets of central Louisiana. It shows his father slumped over the open car window, injured and bleeding.

title: Dance Listings for Sept. 30-Oct. 6
description: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

title: Bartolo Colons Secret: Its the Wrist, Not the Waist
description: MIAMI  The best vantage point from which to truly appreciate how Bartolo Colon pitches is behind home plate. Focus on the ball, as a batter would, even though it temporarily disappears behind Colons head as he prepares to throw.

title: Theater Listings for Sept. 30-Oct. 6
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: She Bested the Bully: Readers on Gender and the Debate
description: As women watched the presidential debate earlier this week, many saw their own experiences of everyday sexism reflected as Donald Trump repeatedly interrupted Hillary Clinton.

title: Review: In A Man Called Ove, Dont Let That Scowl Fool You
description: Swedens official entry for a best foreign-language film at the Academy Awards proves that Swedish pictures can be just as sentimental and conventionally heartwarming as Hollywood ones. Granted, few Hollywood films would deign to tell the story of a protagonists life through a series of flashbacks brought on by unsuccessful suicide attempts. But still.

title: New York Tonight: Hoboken Train Crash and Wet Weather
description: Good evening on this rain-riddled Thursday.

title: Review: The Animated Long Way North Finds a Girl on a Journey
description: The story isnt flashy and neither is the animation in Long Way North, qualities that give the film a certain low-key charm in an age of fast-moving sagas eye-poppingly served. This tale, which in its theatrical release is being shown in both English- and French-language versions, has a young heroine, but you wont mistake it for Frozen.

title: Review: Crisis in Six Scenes, a Mere Ghost of Woody Allen Past
description: Were in the midst of a revolution in American television comedy, and one important source for the dark humor and cinematic style of shows like Louie and Transparent is undoubtedly the films of Woody Allen. Its especially disappointing, then, that Crisis in Six Scenes, Mr. Allens first TV show, feels instantly forgettable.

title: 400-Pound Hacker? Trump Comments Fuel Dialogue on Fat-Shaming
description: It was a casual remark tossed off by Donald J. Trump that jolted Johanna Kandel from her seat during the recent presidential debate.

title: Angered by 9/11 Victims Law, Saudis Rethink U.S. Alliance
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Throughout President Obamas time in the White House, Saudi Arabia and its allies in the Persian Gulf have watched with dismay as the kingdoms decades-old alliance with the United States seemed to be slipping.

title: Off/White: Spring 2017
description: Virgil Abloh shows his spring looks.

title: Maria Semples Today Will Be Different Serves Up Screwball With Soul
description: Maria Semples Whered You Go, Bernadette was the kind of instant classic that earns its author a loyal readership in perpetuity. For anyone who needs reminding, it was a novel that skewered all things Seattle; used an epistolary format to riotous advantage; took a huge whack at Microsofts corporate culture; made terrific fun of the Mom Wars at an especially ridiculous grade school; and guaranteed that you, the reader, would never look at a blackberry bush in quite the same way.

title: Review: Harry & Snowman Recalls a Man and a Horse of Powerful Haunches
description: The Snowman of Ron Daviss documentary Harry & Snowman is a horse that melts the heart. Purchased in the 1950s for $80 off a truck bound for the slaughterhouse, Snowman became a champion show jumper. And that was only one surprise in the long friendship that began when this scruffy white gelding locked eyes with Harry deLeyer, who raised horses and taught riding at a girls school in Long Island.

title: Microsoft Reorganizes Its Research Efforts Around A.I.
description: SEATTLE  Microsoft said on Thursday that it was reorganizing part of the company to better position itself as one of the significant players in the emerging field of artificial intelligence.

title: Review: Do Not Resist, or When a Police Force Becomes an Army
description: Its easy to fault the one-sidedness of Do Not Resist, Craig Atkinsons documentary about the militarization of the police in the United States, but thats missing the point. Sure, plenty of local police officers  a majority, even  have more in common with Andy Taylor (Andy Griffith), the genial television sheriff of the 1960s than they do with a storm trooper. But this unsettling film is about the planting and nurturing of a mind-set, one grounded in hostility and fear.

title: Review: In Tomorrows Parties, Visions of the Planets Future
description: It was a deep-sleep snore with a snort at the end. Rising out of the darkened auditorium at Florence Gould Hall on Wednesday night, near the end of Tomorrows Parties by the British company Forced Entertainment, the sound was too loud to ignore. An infectious case of the giggles rippled through the audience, and kept rippling.

title: Trade Ban to Protect Pangolins: Enough to Save Them?
description: JOHANNESBURG  Representatives from more than 100 countries have agreed to ban worldwide trade in pangolins, which are now threatened with extinction because of illegal trafficking in Asia and Africa.

title: At the New York Film Festival, a Defense of Human Dignity
description: The second most memorable scene in Toni Erdmann  which is to say one of the two or three most remarkable moments you will encounter on a movie screen this year  consists of an impromptu amateur performance of The Greatest Love of All. I hesitate to say anything about who sings that notorious anthem to self-reliance or under what circumstances, but I will note that one line stands out, capturing with an impossible blend of excruciating irony and disarming sincerity one of the movies great themes: No matter what they take from me, they cant take away my dignity.

title: Qualcomm Is Said to Be in Talks to Buy NXP Semiconductors
description: Qualcomm is in discussions to buy NXP Semiconductors in what would be another act of consolidation in the chip-making industry, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

title: Review: Danny Says, a Paean to a Rock Gadfly and Tastemaker
description: To hear it from the new documentary Danny Says, Danny Fields had a hand in the breakup of the Beatles and the discovery of the Ramones. He palled around with the photographer Linda Eastman (a.k.a. Linda McCartney). He tried playing matchmaker for Jim Morrison and Nico, an introduction that resulted in a strange stare-down. He signed MC5 and the Stooges to Elektra in one swoop. He tripped on acid on the floor of Leonard Cohen and Judy Collinss hotel room.

title: Review: In Among the Believers, a Cleric Holds Sway
description: Once we train their minds, theyll never change until they die, the dean of the Red Mosque madrasa says casually and, for the viewer, chillingly, in Among the Believers.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Sept. 30-Oct. 6
description: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

title: This Weeks Movies: Sept. 30, 2016
description: The New York Times film critics review Deepwater Horizon, American Honey and Denial.

title: Donald Trump Proves Perversely Good for The Peso
description: Tired of tracking the presidential election through the soporific data analyses of political pundits? Try the Mexican peso instead. The currencyturns out to be inversely tied to the fortunes of Donald Trump as he makes a daily punching bag of Mexico in his campaign. Experts who saw the peso reach an all-time low against the dollar just before the presidential debate Monday reported that it rose immediately after the debate, going up 2.3 percent in tandem with opinion polls in which viewers pronounced Mr. Trump the loser.

title: Fall Brings Operas, Harvest Festivals and a Bounty of Galas
description: Last weeks top events included opening night of the Metropolitan Opera, Mehregan at Untermyer Park and the New-York Historical Societys gala.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Sept. 30-Oct. 6
description: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.

title: Review: In Denial, Confronting a Holocaust Revisionist in Court
description: No courtroom fireworks detonate in Denial, a sober, methodical recounting of a 1996 libel suit brought by David Irving, a discredited British historian, against Deborah E. Lipstadt, author of the 1993 book Denying the Holocaust: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory.

title: Hoboken, Wells Fargo, F.C.C.: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Review: In Girl Asleep, Floating Through a Teenage Fantasia
description: How might it feel to be a shy 14-year-old wallflower going to a new school in an Australian suburb in the late 1970s? Rosemary Myerss charming offbeat fantasia, Girl Asleep, offers a giddy approximation. Much of this uncategorizable hybrid of a movie and childrens theater piece is played out on an elaborate stage set.

title: Comedy Listings for Sept. 30-Oct. 6
description: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

title: Ex-A.I.G. Chief Parries Inquiries on Offshore Reinsurer in Fraud Trial
description: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of American International Group, told the judge presiding over his civil accounting fraud trial on Thursday that the motive for one key transaction was to help certain A.I.G. employees get continuing losses off their back in a competitive corporate culture.

title: Fall Brings Operas, Harvest Festivals and a Bounty of Galas
description: In a high point of the fall social calendar, the Metropolitan Opera held its opening night gala Sept. 26, with a production of Wagners Tristan und Isolde. In Yonkers, the Untermyer Gardens Conservancy celebrated Mehregan, the ancient Persian harvest festival. And the New-York Historical Society honored the filmmakers Ken Burns and Ric Burns at Cipriani 42nd Street.

title: Drawings? Maybe, but Certainly the Art of Frustration
description: When youre hot youre hot  and Jean Dubuffet is ablaze. Dubuffet Drawings, 19351962, a hefty and insightful exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum, is the fourth here in less than two years to examine the Frenchmans rough, unrefined, war-scarred creations, and his advocacy of art from outside the mainstream. The Museum of Modern Arts excellent Soul of the Underground concentrated on the technical processes Dubuffet used for his disquieting prints and impressions. The American Folk Art Museum last fall presented 200 works from Dubuffets own collection of Art Brut  objects made by untrained or nonprofessional artists. Earlier this year, a significant show at Acquavella Galleries on the Upper East Side covered about the same period as this one: from the hardships of World War II to the booming first years of Frances Fifth Republic.

title: The Ways Clinton or Trump Can Win the Election
description: Explore the paths to victory available for the presidential candidates.

title: With Glut of Vice Captains at the Ryder Cup, Will Tiger Woods Fetch Lunch?
description: CHASKA, Minn.  Golf might be losing market share and the millennials, but the Ryder Cup keeps expanding: more sponsor pavilions, more merchandise, more venues on the European continent (Paris and Rome are next).

title: Worlds Fair, and Queens, in the Meadows Festival Spotlight
description: The Bronx is known as the birthplace of hip-hop and Brooklyn nurtured the indie-rock explosion of the early 2000s, but Queens has also produced enough influential artists to build its own rock n roll hall of fame: Musicians who grew up there range from Simon and Garfunkel to the Ramones, Nicki Minaj to Nas, Cyndi Lauper to Anthrax. But to find a live audience, they often ventured across the river, to Greenwich Village or the Lower East Side.

title: How the Balmain Show Came Together
description: Olivier Rousteing takes T behind the scenes in the 48 hours before his spring/summer 2017 show.

title: Forty-Eight Hours in Paris With Balmains Olivier Rousteing
description: Twenty hours before Balmains creative director, Olivier Rousteing, was due to present his spring/summer 2017 collection in Paris, the reality television star Kris Jenner crossed paths with the model Isabeli Fontana in the labels Parisian atelier. The latter was on her way into a fitting, the former  in a black patent trench, bodyguard in tow  was on her way out.

title: Movie Listings for Sept. 30-Oct. 6
description: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series. A complete list of new releases is at nytimes.com/intheaters.

title: Review: In Miss Peregrines Home, Chasing Grandpas Stories Down a Rabbit Hole
description: The movies have long made room for phantasmagoric visionaries, the strange ones, the different ones, who like to peek under rocks (or peel back the skin) to peer at what squirms beneath. Fitting their deliriums into bright, shiny, commercially palatable vehicles can be difficult, as Tim Burtons career attests. Time and again, Mr. Burton has tried to smooth down his singular art, rather like one of Cinderellas stepsisters sawing off a bit of her foot to squeeze into a happily-ever-after slipper. Mr. Burton should never hack off his strange bits; they can be glorious.

title: Classical Music Listings for Sept. 30-Oct. 6
description: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.

title: Jazz Listings for Sept. 30-Oct. 6
description: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

title: How Do You Make Turbo Engines More Efficient? Just Add Water
description: FOR decades, automakers have relied on turbocharging, which uses energy captured from exhaust gases to force additional air into the cylinders, to increase the power and efficiency of some gasoline engines.

title: Around Town for Sept. 30-Oct. 6
description: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Galerie Buchholz17 East 82nd Street Through Oct. 22

title: Offshore Wind Farms See Promise in Platforms That Float
description: ORONO, Me.  The sun was beating down on the leafy campus of the University of Maine one afternoon last month. But inside a hangarlike laboratory, a miniature hurricane was raging.

title: Talking Across Divides: 10 Ways to Encourage Civil Classroom Conversation On Difficult Issues
description: So begins an article from June 2016, which described a problem that has only deepened as the weeks of this unprecedented, vitriolic presidential campaign have gone on.

title: Spare Times for Children Listings for Sept. 30-Oct. 6
description: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

title: Clemson Quarterback Deshaun Watson Stays Cool While Taking the Heat
description: ATLANTA  In early September, two days after No. 5 Clemson squeezed past Troy in a surprisingly close nonconference game, Tigers quarterback Deshaun Watson apologized for displaying what he described as negative energy in the 30-24 victory. A spotlight is always placed on a star player when a team with immense expectations appears to sag, it seems, and when Clemson did not obliterate Troy, Watson offered up himself as a sacrifice.

title: U.S. Paid Insurers Funds Meant for Treasury, Auditors Say
description: WASHINGTON  Federal auditors ruled on Thursday that the Obama administration had violated the law by paying health insurance companies more than allowed under the Affordable Care Act in an effort to hold down insurance premiums.

title: Progress? Depends on Which Party Is Doing the Talking
description: WASHINGTON  To be fair, Congress averted a government shutdown a full two days before the lights were set to go out. So by contemporary standards, they are making great progress. There will be money to combat the Zika virus  seven months after President Obama asked for it and following a predictable fight over Planned Parenthood  and a promise of money to fix the water systems in Flint, Mich., at some point, probably.

title: Concern Over Deutsche Banks Health Shakes Markets
description: Stock markets were rattled on Thursday after reports emerged that some clients of Deutsche Bank, the struggling German lender, were reducing their exposure.

title: A Very Fair Exchange
description: Dear Diary:

title: An $8 Million Arena Sculpture to Usher In Civilization 3.0
description: Art installations have long been a requirement for developers who want to show off their panache and good taste.

title: C.D.C. Advises Against Travel to Zika-Affected Countries in Southeast Asia
description: Federal health officials on Thursday advised pregnant women to consider postponing nonessential travel to 11 countries in Southeast Asia where the Zika virus was circulating.

title: Leaderless and Underfunded, N.J. Transit Had Troubles Well Before Fatal Crash
description: Even before one of its trains crashed in Hoboken Terminal on Thursday morning, killing one woman and injuring more than 100 others, New Jersey Transit was an agency in distress.

title: Credibility of Chris Christies Enforcer Challenged During Bridge Scandal Trial
description: NEWARK  A defense lawyer tried to undermine the credibility of the confessed culprit in the George Washington Bridge lane closings in federal court on Thursday, suggesting that he was a serial schemer and braggart who had hoped to take credit for the scheme  but now, as the star witness for the prosecution, could not keep his story straight.

title: After Acquittal in Boys Killing, Potsdam Sighs With Relief and Resignation
description: POTSDAM, N.Y.  In front of the building at 100 Market Street, where a 12-year-old boy, Garrett Phillips, was murdered nearly five years ago, a small sign, one of hundreds that once dotted the area, had called for Justice for Garrett.

title: In Hacked Audio, Hillary Clinton Rethinks Obamas Nuclear Upgrade Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Hillary Clinton expressed doubts about whether the United States should go forward with a trillion-dollar modernization of its nuclear forces at a fund-raiser in February, questioning an Obama administration plan that she has remained largely silent on in public.

title: Why New Jerseys Trains Arent Safer
description: Why did a New Jersey Transit train crash into Hoboken Terminal on Thursday morning, killing at least one person and injuring more than 100 people?

title: A Wild-Card Spot, and More, Is Within the Mets Reach
description: The Mets did not play Thursday, allowing them to savor their situation heading into the final weekend of the regular season, a wild-card spot clearly within their grasp.

title: I.P.O. Values Cloud Company Nutanix at $2.18 Billion
description: It was one of the few venture-backed start-ups brave enough to file for an initial public offering last year. But Nutanix, which provides cloud-based data storage for businesses, was faced with about nine months of choppy markets that discouraged many private companies from making their stock debuts.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: It all flipped, so fast. Suddenly, we were in the minority. That was kind of a scary feeling. It makes you wonder where the Christians went.

title: Ex-Marine Describes Violent Hazing and the Lies That Covered It Up
description: PUTNAM COUNTY, Fla.  In Marine Corps boot camp, Thomas Weaver learned to endure punches, kicks and choking by drill instructors in the Third Recruit Training Battalion at Parris Island, S.C. When one instructor repeatedly bashed his head against a doorway, he kept quiet and acted as if it were no big deal. But what he eventually could not take was the lying that covered up the abuse.

title: Red Sox Have Bright Hopes as David Ortizs Era Comes to an End
description: David Ortiz was the last of the old lions in this rivalry, the final link to the autumn that changed everything. Alex Rodriguez left with a whimper at Fenway Park last month. Ortiz, still roaring, said goodbye to Yankee Stadium on Thursday.

title: What Is Russia Up To, and Is It Time to Draw the Line?
description: WASHINGTON  Escalating airstrikes in Syria. Sophisticated cyberattacks, apparently intended to influence the American election. New evidence of complicity in shooting down a civilian airliner.

title: Fire Dept. Chief Killed in Bronx Explosion Is Promoted
description: A 44-year-old battalion chief with the New York City Fire Department who was killed by debris after a house exploded in the Bronx this week has been promoted to deputy chief, the mayor and the fire commissioner said on Thursday.

title: No Stranger to Marital Strife, Rudy Giuliani Wags a Finger at the Clintons
description: Most people probably cant identify any senior advisers to presidential candidates, but one member of Donald J. Trumps brain trust has been skywriting his name across the national news.

title: Claims of Saudi Role in 9/11 Appear Headed for Manhattan Court
description: WASHINGTON  Saudi Arabia paid millions of dollars to Washington lobbyists to keep it out of court. They have been unsuccessful. And now it is up to the kingdoms lawyers to limit the damage.

title: Caregiver Who Abused 4-Year-Old Boy Pleads Guilty to Murder
description: The abuse that 4-year-old Myls Dobson suffered  the beatings, burnings and deprivation  lasted for three weeks and ended with his death in January 2014. The prison term his killer faces will be far longer than the life the little boy had.

title: David Ortiz Exits Yankee Stadium for Final Time With a Walk, a Painting and a Standing Ovation
description: The Yankees spent a little over two minutes honoring David Ortiz on Thursday, and Ortiz used two inconsequential plate appearances to say goodbye to Yankee Stadium.

title: A Tribute Dinner for the Chef Gerry Hayden
description: Among the events at this years New York City Wine and Food Festival, scheduled for Oct. 13 to 16, is a dinner on Oct. 14 to honor Gerry Hayden, a chef who died last year from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrigs disease. Charlie Palmer, with whom Mr. Hayden worked for many years, will be the host and will cook along with Michael Mina, David Burke, Bryan Voltaggio and Mr. Haydens widow, Claudia Fleming: 7 p.m. Oct. 14, Charlie Palmer at the Knick, Knickerbocker Hotel, 6 Times Square (42nd Street), $300, nycwff.org.

title: City Officials Are Questioned Over Changes to Nursing Homes Deed
description: The questions came steadily, for six hours, at a City Council hearing on Thursday that tried to get to the heart of why officials had lifted a deed restriction on a nursing home and let it be sold to a luxury condominium developer.

title: Rezoning Plan for Manhattan Elementary School Draws Anger From All Sides
description: One man threatened to marshal 1,000 votes against any elected official who dared to disagree with him. A woman who took an opposing stance was warned about making enemies. Another was so distressed she broke down in tears in front of her 4-year-old.

title: A Show to Indulge in All Things Chocolate
description: It has been four years since a chocolate show has been an autumn attraction in Manhattan. Wizard Studios of Bushwick, Brooklyn, brings its Big Chocolate Show to Terminal Stores in Chelsea on Oct. 8 and 9, with tasting classes, hourly cooking demonstrations and other events included in the admission. Tickets are sold for half-day segments, from 9 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. and from 2:30 to 7 p.m., and reservations for various classes are available with ticket purchase.

title: Review: La Bohme, in All Its Excessive Glory
description: Franco Zeffirellis production of Puccinis La Bohme at the Metropolitan Opera undoubtedly had years added to its life in 2012, when Peter Gelb, the Mets general manager, scrapped the widely beloved Zeffirelli Tosca in favor of a new staging by Luc Bondy. Public and critical uproar was immediate and lasting.

title: American Fan at Ryder Cup Heckles European Players, Then Out-Putts Them
description: The Ryder Cup had not yet started.

title: Taking the Plunge
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Its Friday and the living is, if not easy, at least theme-free and fairly open in terms of white space.

title: Review: 13TH, the Journey From Shackles to Prison Bars
description: Powerful, infuriating and at times overwhelming, Ava DuVernays documentary 13TH will get your blood boiling and tear ducts leaking. It shakes you up, but it also challenges your ideas about the intersection of race, justice and mass incarceration in the United States, subject matter that could not sound less cinematic. Yet Ms. DuVernay  best known for Selma, and a filmmaker whose art has become increasingly inseparable from her activism  has made a movie thats as timely as the latest Black Lives Matter protest and the approaching presidential election.

title: Review: The Encounter Is a High-Tech Head Trip Through an Amazon Labyrinth
description: See that scruffy-looking guy up there on the stage, the one messing around with the microphones and the plastic water bottles? It turns out that hes a world-class head shrinker  and head enlarger, too, an all-purpose mind-bender. He is going to retune, rearrange and reproportion your senses, while taking you places you never expected to visit.

title: Harvard Hires New Endowment Manager From Columbia
description: Harvard has brought in a new manager from Columbia University to run its $36 billion endowment, the largest of any university.

title: Richard D. Trentlage, 87, Who Wrote The Oscar Mayer Wiener Song, Dies
description: The name Richard D. Trentlage may not roll off the tongues of most Americans, but generations of them, for good or ill, can no doubt sing along with some of the catchiest advertising jingles that he wrote for companies like Oscar Mayer and McDonalds.

title: Yankees Eliminated From Postseason Contention Despite Beating Red Sox
description: The last faint ember of hope was snuffed out on an unusual Yankees season Thursday night. Perhaps appropriately considering the upside-down nature of their 2016 campaign, it came during a win.

title: The Last Call of a Vanished Tropical Frog
description: A tree frog species new to science in 2008 is already gone.

title: Lady Gaga to Headline Super Bowl Halftime Show
description: The Super Bowl stage will once again belong to a pop diva.

title: A Call for Review of Chinese Purchases of U.S. Companies
description: Members of Congress have urged the Government Accountability Office to review the effectiveness of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS). In a letter, they called for greater scrutiny of Chinese corporate purchases, including movie theaters and studios.

title: Rosetta Mission Ends With Spacecrafts Dive Into Comet
description: Rosetta, the first spacecraft to orbit a comet, is dead, setting down in a final embrace with its companion of the past two years.

title: Wayne Rooney, Fresh Off Bench, Delivers Key Assist in Manchester United Win
description: Wayne Rooney finally made a difference for Manchester United this season, setting up a goal by Zlatan Ibrahimovic two minutes after being summoned off the bench on Thursday and helping host United beat Zorya Luhansk, 1-0, in the Europa League.

title: Danny Fields Loved Punk Rock. It Loved Him Back.
description: In certain circles, Danny Fields is a mythical figure. Hes a rock n roll mover, shaker, influencer and scene maker  a Harvard Law School dropout who eventually fell in with Andy Warhols Factory crowd and went on to manage the Stooges and the Ramones. And yet, when it came time to watch Brendan Tollers new documentary, Danny Says, about his life, Mr. Fields had to brace himself.

title: Word + Quiz: incorporeal
description: : without material form or substance

title: Paris Fashion Week, Day 4: Theyre Coming!
description: T.G.I.PFWF. It may be Friday, but the shows keep coming. Heres what to watch for today.

title: In the Studio With Christian Louboutin
description: PARIS  In the finale of this seasons series about designers private working worlds, Christian Louboutin, shoe maestro, reveals why he cant throw anything away, hates going out at night and loves small spaces. This conversation has been condensed and edited.

title: Whats on TV Friday: Woody Allens Crisis in Six Scenes and Marvels Luke Cage
description: Woody Allen tackles television for the first time with Crisis in Six Scenes. The Marvel superhero Luke Cage gets a show of his own. And High Maintenance goes to the dog.

title: In the Studio: Christian Louboutin
description: The shoemaker Christian Louboutin gives a tour of his quirky Paris studio.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Week in Pictures: Sept. 30, 2016
description: Photos from The New York Times and photographers around the world.

title: World Leaders Gather to Mourn Shimon Peres, and Possibly His Dream
description: JERUSALEM  From across the ocean and across the Green Line, they came on Friday to the mountaintop sanctuary of Mount Herzl to bid farewell to Shimon Peres, marking what one called the end of the era of giants. But the question of the moment was whether it was a funeral for a man or for his dream.

title: The Week in Pictures: Sept. 30, 2016
description: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

title: An Uncharitable Foundation
description: In addition to being the Republican nominee for president, Donald J. Trump is president of the relatively small Donald J. Trump Foundation and chairman of the relatively large Trump Organization. Although the foundation is a charitable organization, it appears to have been used for less than charitable purposes.

title: The Death of Idealism
description: This presidential election is a contest between the oldest of the baby boomers. Yet Donald Trump, 70, and Hillary Clinton, 68, represent two very different decades in the formation of that generation. Donald Trump became famous as a classic 1980s type, while Hillary Clinton first attained public notice as a classic 1960s type.

title: Candidate Obama Kept His Promise to Native Americans
description: President Obama campaigned hard in 2008 for the votes of American Indians. He vowed that his administration would pay special attention to their grievances about federal mismanagement and the governments recurring neglect of treaty obligations. Few have been ignored by Washington for as long as Native Americans  the first Americans, he told the Crow Nation in Montana, promising a change.

title: Fat-Shamer in Chief
description: Apparently, millions of Americans dont care that a man now within a nose-hair of the presidency may be the most prolific liar in modern political history. Nor do they care about the authoritarian policies he espouses, his truly scary embrace of dictators abroad and crackpots at home, or his monumental ignorance on every subject.

title: How the Clinton-Trump Race Got Close
description: Mondays presidential debate was a blowout, surely the most one-sided confrontation in American political history. Hillary Clinton was knowledgeable, unflappable and  dare we say it?  likable. Donald Trump was ignorant, thin-skinned and boorish.

title: A Flimsy Legal Attack on Clean Air
description: In eight years, President Obama has established a strong record in fighting climate change, including ambitious fuel efficiency standards aimed at reducing carbon dioxide emissions from cars and trucks.

title: Why Its Safe to Scrap Americas ICBMs
description: In recent years, Russia and the United States have started rebuilding their Cold War nuclear arsenals, putting the world on the threshold of a dangerous new arms race. But we dont have to repeat the perilous drama of the 20th century. We can maintain our countrys strength and security and still do away with the worst of the Cold War weapons.

title: Chinese Purchases of U.S. Companies Have Some in Congress Raising Eyebrows
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Movie theaters and studios are rarely the focus of geopolitical conflict.

title: A Battle to Define Democracy
description: LONDON  At one point during their first television debate, Donald J. Trump repeated his suggestion that Hillary Clinton lacked the stamina to lead the worlds greatest superpower. In Britain, the question found its echoes in an equally acrid discussion of leadership and power.

title: Sneaker Collection
description: Whats the story behind this photo?

description: Article: Reykjavik Briefly Swaps Its City Lights for Northern Ones

title: South Korea Investigates Deaths of 3 Chinese Fishermen in Crackdown
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korean Coast Guard officials said Friday that they were investigating the deaths of three Chinese fishermen whose boat caught fire during a crackdown on illegal fishing.

title: Duterte, Citing Hitler, Says He Wants to Kill 3 Million Addicts in Philippines
description: MANILA  President Rodrigo Duterte said Friday that he would like to kill millions of drug addicts in the Philippines, defying international criticism of his countrys bloody war on narcotics and escalating his brutal rhetoric with a reference to the Holocaust.

title: The President Has Never Said the Word Black
description: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.

title: Judge John Hodgman Rules on Diet Mountain Dew
description: Amy writes: My husband drinks what I consider to be excessive amounts of Diet Mountain Dew. He goes through a 12-pack every few days. Not only is this unhealthy, I associate the drink with a gamer/extreme-sports/redneck culture that I dont like. I propose a 12-pack per week limit.

title: Does Voting for a Third-Party Candidate Mean Throwing Away Your Vote?
description: In our winner-take all presidential election system, two parties dominate: Democrats and Republicans. In fact, while third parties have gained traction at times in history, no third-party candidate has ever won the presidency.

title: Can New Technology Bring Baseballs Data Revolution to Fielding?
description: Wearing a plaid flannel shirt and a backward Astros cap, Daren Willman went upstairs in his home just outside Houston one Sunday afternoon this summer. He sat down behind a tabletop desk in an office decorated with framed sports jerseys and flicked on a TV across the room. Im at work, he said.

title: The 9.8.16 Issue
description: RE: FIRST WORDS

title: Is New York Ready for Solar Power?
description: Solar power in New York City may finally be having its moment.

title: How to Walk in High Heels
description: Start with the right shoes. Finding them should be not unlike finding a lover. Go toward the thing that excites you the most, says Alexandra Billings, a transgender actress and theater-arts professor at California State University, Long Beach, who plays the role of mentor to Jeffrey Tambors character on Transparent. Billings does all her shoe shopping in brick-and-mortar stores, never online. Youve got to walk around in them, touch them, spend some time, she says. Feel even the hint of a pinched toe or wobble? Take them off. You cannot be your true self if youre in pain. Plus, Billings says, nobody wants to see you fall.

title: Lousy Libidos: Why Do Pandas Have So Little Sex?
description: Pandas are cuddly, but not to each other. They muster about as much enthusiasm for sex as a human does for a root canal.

title: At Shimon Peres Funeral, a Lineup of U.S. and Israeli Leaders Who Tangled
description: WASHINGTON  When Bill Clinton took his place on Friday at Mount Herzl in Jerusalem for the state funeral of Shimon Peres, he was part of a tangled tableau: leaders from Israel and the United States who came together to mourn a giant of peace but who nurse their own political feuds and rivalries, stretching back two decades.

title: From Torahs to Tchotchkes, J. Levine Books & Judaica Is a Go-To Store
description: Although its in the crush of Midtown Manhattan and surrounded by storefronts hawking perfume and leather goods, J. Levine Books & Judaica will take you back to the shtetl.

title: How to Pick the Best Credit Card, Based on Rewards
description: Free trips. Triple cash back. Or would you prefer first dibs on tickets for Beyoncs world tour, or a private dinner cooked by a Top Chef winner?

title: Dear Dad: Weve Been Gay for a Really Long Time
description: The first letter was not mine, although my brother Charles and I had spent so much time talking about it that I felt some ownership. I was in San Francisco for the Thanksgiving holiday, and we had read and reread the letter he was planning to send to my father, changing a word here and there, rearranging sentences.

title: Democrats Rake In Money, Thanks to Suit by Republicans
description: Democrats denounced it as an assault on democracy and a sop to billionaires when the Supreme Court issued a ruling two years ago that loosened limits on campaign giving.

title: For an Odd Couple, the Ryder Cup Offers a Chance to Reminisce
description: CHASKA, Minn.  Friends for nearly 20 years, Lee Westwood and Darren Clarke are back together again for the Ryder Cup.

title: Immigrants Eager to Vote Obeyed All the Rules. It Didnt Pay.
description: They stayed up late studying for civics tests. They went to classes, paid hefty fees and underwent background checks.

title: Colombias 52-Year War Is Ending. Now Comes the Hard Part.
description: It was a five-decade war  and it ended with a party on Colombias southern plains.

title: How to Get to Work After the Hoboken Train Crash
description: The morning commute via Hoboken is part back-to-normal after Thursdays train crash and part still a mess. Heres whats running and whats not:

title: What You Should Know Before Going Solar
description: How do home solar systems work?

title: 1891: Boulanger Commits Suicide
description: BRUSSELS  At noon today [Sept. 30] the rumor spread like wildfire throughout Brussels that General Boulanger had committed suicide. What first appeared like a joke was soon afterwards confirmed. The Herald correspondent can also vouch for the fact that his funds were getting very low, and that his appeals for financial aid to his old friends had of late been quite in vain. This morning, at eleven oclock, after breakfasting with his nieces, he ordered his carriage and drove to the cemetery.

title: Posting Political Signs in the Window Is Your Right  Isnt It?

In other election years, they had hung signs for Barack Obama and placards opposing George W. Bush and the Iraq war. But this time, their exercise in political engagement was thwarted.

title: Review: Pandaemonium Gives Unhappiness a Light Touch
description: Somewhere in the American desert, a man and a woman recline on beach chairs under a drive-in movie screen. Something is not right between them. Soon, shell break out divorce papers; hell break out the booze. Its a scene of emptiness and estrangement. But in Pandaemonium, a clever hybrid of physical theater and cinema that had its local debut at New York Live Arts on Wednesday, much of the alienation is treated lightly. When the show is working, the unhappiness is enjoyable.

title: One English Villages New Garden Retreat
description: In an English village, just inland from the rugged Suffolk coast, something close to Arcadia is being created. Under the watch of the revered British landscape artist Kim Wilkie, three historic estates  Heveningham, Sibton Park and Cockfield Hall  are being slowly re-imagined as one luxurious rural retreat. The idea is to take what have been rather run-down and fractured places, where ownership has been split up, and restore them to what was a very balanced and harmonious whole, says Wilkie of Wilderness Reserve, a 5,000-acre expanse of pasture, lake and woodland thats dotted with an idiosyncratic set of rentable lodgings. Now the already up-for-rent Moat Cottage, Cartshed and electricity-free Hex Cottage have been joined by the Walled Garden, a palatial eight-bedroom bolthole wrought from one of Suffolks few surviving walled kitchen gardens.

title: A Civil War Classic Endures
description: The cover of the Book Review on Oct. 30, 1955, was split in two. On one side, the historian Henry Steele Commager reviewed MacKinlay Kantors Andersonville, calling it the greatest of our Civil War novels. On the other side, Kantor himself wrote an essay about the more than two decades he spent researching and writing his densely peopled 750-page epic about the notoriously inhumane Confederate prisoner of war camp in Georgia. The book, which won the Pulitzer Prize in 1956, was recently republished in a new edition.

title: After Van Gogh Recoveries, Remembering Other Tales of Art Lost and Found
description: LONDON  Two missing van Gogh paintings were recovered this week in Italy, nearly 14 years after being stolen from an Amsterdam museum. Only 5 to 10 percent of stolen art ever returns, so its very good that they got these back, Arthur Brand, a Dutch independent art crimes investigator, said. Here is a sampling of other masterworks that have been lost, and improbably found:

title: The Latest and Best in Crime Fiction
description: Karin Fossum may be the most unsentimental crime novelist since Ruth Rendells alter ego, Barbara Vine. On the very first page of HELL FIRE (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $24), a young mother and her 4-year-old son lie dead of multiple stab wounds in the ramshackle little trailer in the Norwegian woods where they had spent the night. Not far into the story, were introduced to a character who, well very soon deduce, is almost certainly the killer. Surprisingly, anticipating the ending doesnt destroy the suspense; in fact, imagining the horror that awaits actually increases our sense of dread.

title: 1966: Caribbean Hurricane Kills 110
description: MIAMI  Haiti and the Dominican Republic suffered hundreds of deaths and disastrous destruction from Hurricane Inez, first reports indicated today [Sept. 30]. The killer Hurricane then slashed across eastern Cuba on a course aimed at the Bahamas. A government spokesman for the Dominican Republic late today listed 110 known dead. The casualty toll was expected to grow higher. An air-force spokesman said several small cities in the interior had not been heard from.

That sensibility translated to glowing, luminous skin, with little interference.

title: Why Wont Midcentury Design Die?
description: In 1998, The New York Times noted a new design trend. Cool creative types were tossing aside their thrift store dcor in favor of midcentury modern. Out went the funky votive candles and wrought-iron beds, and in came the clean-lined furniture of Arne Jacobsen, Eero Saarinen, Charles and Ray Eames, and Florence Knoll. The looks adherents were labeled Generation Wallpaper, after the magazine.

title: Its Auctions vs. Galleries
description: LONDON  Frieze Week, which begins here on Monday, is a uniquely frantic moment in the art-world calendar. At no other time does such a concentration of high-quality fairs, auctions and dealer shows jostle for the attention  and spending  of the worlds art collectors.

title: Poor, Transgender and Dressed for Arrest
description: Measured in terms of cultural attention, it can seem like a very enlightened time to be living with an unconventional gender identity. The rights of transgender people have been a concern of presidential politics; Transparent, the comedy about a middle-aged male political scientist in the process of becoming female, is popular and in its third season; gender-neutral bathrooms are on the rise, and opposition to them puts challengers in the position of seeming benighted and cranky, as though they hankered for a world still dominated by three television networks.

title: How to Take Legal Recourse When Dodging Food Delivery Motorbikes Fails
description: Q. Im all for fast food  the faster, the better. But if one of these deliverymen for New York restaurants and groceries on their little electric motorbikes runs me down, what is my legal recourse? They have no license plates or signs indicating the business they are delivering for. Do they have insurance? If one hits me, whom do I sue? The poor working person riding the bike, or the business he or she works for?

title: Who Gets to Vote?
description: In recent years, youve needed a scorecard to keep track of voting laws in the United States. For nearly a decade, Republican-dominated state legislatures have been churning out strict voter ID laws and other measures likely to reduce access to the ballot box. But the pace of activity quickened after June 2013, when the Supreme Court disabled a vital provision of the Voting Rights Act, the so-called preclearance provision, opening the door to restrictive legislation in the nine states (and parts of six others) that had been covered by the law.
